tgt_text.9: Theodoric the Great established his Gothic King­ dom upon the ruins of the Roman Empire, his people had not attained those settled habits which are requisite for the firm establishment of a state ;

tgt_text.14: After him there never existed a leader amongst the Ger­ mans whose personal influence was sufficiently powerful to keep united under one sceptre a great nation composed of so many different races.
tgt_text.15: Although the boundaries esta­ blished by him between bia kingdom and the Sclavonians, Moors, and Scandinavians, became in later times rather en­ larged than confirmed, and although his great and power­ ful laws and institutions still continued for many centuries to be reverenced, especially amongst the Franks, still his kingdom always continued to descend in a divided form to his posterity.
tgt_text.16: It was not so much the freshly-awakened influence of Rome, as an impulse originating from the Ger­ man people themselves, which led them to endeavour to ob­ tain a division of races, and a geographical distribution of the ands which had now become their own, and with the political knowledge communicated to them by Charlemagne, to form single independent states.
tgt_text.17: Alfred of Wessex, the only ruler of England ever sur­ named the Greatl, had to endure infinitely greater trials, and during the principal part of his life, to wage a far more difficult war, than any of the other celebrated kings of the German race;
tgt_text.18: notwithstanding this, with the most unwearied perseverance, he founded institutions which remain to this day, and constitute one of the most important links in the progressive political development of the powerful Saxon people on the British island.

tgt_text.320: We have seen that, although Ceawlin had many sons, he was succeeded, after his complete overthrow, by his brother Ceolric, who, although he was not childless, was followed by his brother Ceolwulf.
tgt_text.321: After the death of the latter, in 611, the kingdom passed again into his elder brother's line;
tgt_text.322: still it was split into a great many portions, for Cynegils by no means reigned alone.
tgt_text.323: Cwichelm and others were quite independent of him;
tgt_text.324: each ruled a part of West Saxony, and only united in enterprises against the common foe, as they did in the battle of Beamdune2.
tgt_text.325: This division of the same nation, under different leaders, must have seriously impaired the national strength, and its effects are soon perceptible.
tgt_text.326: The same evil consequences that precisely at the same time attended the division of the kingdom of the Frankish Merovingians, also affected the West Saxons, but in a much less degree ;
tgt_text.327: for their state, as we have seen, bore within it from the first the germs of union and centralisation.
tgt_text.328: It was owing to this splitting asunder of their own strength, that the danger which now menaced from without assumed an aspect which became more and more serious.
tgt_text.329: It seems as if the West Saxon kings, the true descendants of Woden, never, until their final conversion, abandoned the idea that they ought to stand forward as champions of the old Teutonic Paganism.
tgt_text.330: Animated by his hatred of the Christian faith, Cwichelm despatched a murderer to the court of King Edwin of Deira (Northumbria), where already the Gospel had found- access.
tgt_text.332: King Edwin's servant LiRa saved him with his own life.
tgt_text.333: Edwin, now justly enraged against the West Saxons, attacked them, and slew five of their kings1, and then became a con­ vert to Christianity in the year 626.
tgt_text.334: Penda, a powerful heathen prince, began to reign in Mercia in the same year.
tgt_text.335: In an inconceivably short time he raised his kingdom, which included Christians and heathens, Germans and Welsh, to a high state of importance.
tgt_text.336: In 628, he entered into an alliance with the West Saxons.
tgt_text.337: Cynegils had resisted him most desperately at Cirencester, so that the battle remained un­ decided, and the two commanders concluded a treaty.
tgt_text.338: A faint glimmering of the old Paganism long remained among the Mercians, but the apostles of the true faith soon dispersed the light of the Gospel among the West Saxons.
tgt_text.339: Their close family connexion with Oswald, King of the Northumbrian Bernicians, might have been the chief cause of this.
tgt_text.340: It fur­ ther appears, that Bishop Birinus, the delegate of Pope Honorius, and fully commissioned by him to preach the Gospel to the uttermost limits of the island, at this time also passed the boundaries of heathen West Saxony.
tgt_text.341: And he was not mistaken in his judgment of the moment when the disputed supremacy of the sons of Woden seemed to be declining.
tgt_text.342: In the meagre records of the Chronicle, we read that Cynegils was baptized in the year 6351, and Cwichelm in 636.
tgt_text.343: Cuthred, the son and successor of the latter, also em­ braced Christianity, and established Birinus at Dorchester in the first West Saxon bishopric.
tgt_text.344: As it happened in all the newly-converted Anglo-Saxon countries, a reaction now ensued in favour of the old faith amongst the West Saxons.
tgt_text.345: Kenwalk, the son of Cynegils, had scarcely assumed the kingdom when he openly professed heathenism, and married a sister of Penda, the mighty Pagan monarch.
tgt_text.346: But his own rashness proved his ruin;
tgt_text.347: he repudiated his wife, and Penda invaded and drove him from his kingdom in 645.
tgt_text.348: It is probable that many of the West Saxons were already zealous disciples of the preaching clergy, and therefore lent no aid to Kenwalk.
tgt_text.349: During his three years' exile, which he passed with King Annas of East Anglia, he also embraced Christianity.
tgt_text.350: It seems that he brought down that destroyer of all weak states, the wild Penda, on the head of his Christian host;
tgt_text.351: but Kenwalk himself returned to his home, and received a fraternal welcome from his relation Cuthred, whom he re­ warded for this conduct by conferring on him lands and the title of viceroy.
tgt_text.352: For the next twelve years, Kenwalk seems to have been chief ruler of West Saxony;
tgt_text.353: and the period during which he reigned is, on many accounts, not without importance.
tgt_text.354: In the first place, he may rightly be considered as the founder of the ecclesiastical constitution of Wessex.
tgt_text.355: It here manifested an endeavour to assume a national character before it did so in any other part of the island.
tgt_text.356: After Birinus, a foreigner named Egilbert was appointed bishop ;
tgt_text.357: he was a Frank, and it was soon asserted that the strange prelate could not speak to the people in their own language.
tgt_text.358: At the same time, King Kenwalk proposed, on account of the great extent of Wessex, to divide it into two dioceses-he elevated Win­ chester to be a new episcopal see, and placed there as bishop, Wini, a Saxon who had been educated abroad.
tgt_text.359: The Frankish bishop was bitterly aggrieved at this;
tgt_text.360: he resigned his office and went back to his own country, where he was shortly after­ wards created Archbishop of Parish
tgt_text.361: But the capricious king did not long keep on friendly terms with Wini;
tgt_text.362: at the end of three years he deprived him of his situation, which was once more occupied by a foreigner, Leutherius, a nephew of Egilbert, who himself recommended him.
tgt_text.363: Besides this first ecclesiastical perplexity, Kenwalk had to contend with difficulties in his secular affairs.
tgt_text.364: Although the Mercian kingdom had at length become Christian, the hostile position it occupied with regard to Wessex remained the same.
tgt_text.365: Penda's Christian son, Wulfhere, repeatedly attacked the neighbouring country ;
tgt_text.366: he even once took the Isle of Wight from Kenwalk and gave it to the King of Sussex1.
tgt_text.367: But on the whole, Kenwalk knew how to protect his kingdom;
tgt_text.368: in the contests with the Britons he was always victorious, and thus strengthened and established his northern and western boundaries.
tgt_text.369: When he died in 672, his energetic wife Sex­ burgs held the reins of government for the space of a year, which proves to us that at that time the royal race could furnish no more worthy successor.
tgt_text.370: This queen, whose name is recorded as the pride and support of her nation, takes her place, and by no means the lowest one, in that wonderful array of rare women, who, from Boadicea to Elizabeth, have from time to time passed over the pages of British history;
tgt_text.371: and we cannot avoid joining in the praise and admiration which William of Malmesbury bestows on her2.
tgt_text.372: Unfortunately, at the expiration of a year Sexburgha again disappears from the scene.
tgt_text.373: She left the kingdom in a great state of confusion as regarded the succession, in which it continued for fifteen years.
tgt_text.374: According to the scarcely more than genealogical records of the Year-books, Cenfus, a great-grandson of Ceolwulf, possessed the sovereignty for the next two years.
tgt_text.375: We may venture to place the more reliance on this fact, as King Alfred himself mentions it, probably in his Manual, from which William of Malmesbury and others were some­ times accustomed to copys.
tgt_text.376: From 674 to 676, Cenfus was succeeded by his son Escwin, who, like his predecessors, fought with Wulfhere of Mercia.
tgt_text.378: Whilst he was yet reigning, Kentwine, the brother of Ken­ walk, assumed the title of king.
tgt_text.379: His attention was especially directed towards the south-west boundaries of his kingdom, where the Britons of Cornwall, incited and supported by their brethren in Armorica beyond the sea, profiting by internal dissensions among the West Saxons, were endeavouring by force of arms to make good their old claims to the possessions which had been torn from them.
tgt_text.380: They were, however, subdued by the courage and skill of the German warrior;
tgt_text.381: and we do not hesitate in attributing to Kentwine the merit of laying the first foundation of the submission of the counties of Devon and Cornwall to the West Saxon crownl.
tgt_text.382: The numerous connexions with the Celtic principalities of the West, and even the influence which their national character had at this time on that of the Germans, become particu­ larly evident through the frequent mixing up of events and names in the history of both which appears in the Annales Cambriæ ;
tgt_text.383: this has long since been skilfully pointed out2.
tgt_text.384: The similarity of names between Cædwalla, a relation of Kent­ wine, who revolted against him, and Cadwallader, the Welsh prince, is no mere accident.
tgt_text.385: Certainly the British annalists may have taken pains to transfer the deeds and history of the Saxon to their own similarly-named hero;
tgt_text.386: the Celtic sound in the name of the former cannot be denied.
tgt_text.387: He and his brother Mul were sons of the inferior King Cenbert, most probably by a British mother3.
tgt_text.388: Their own history must bear witness to this.
tgt_text.389: The youth Cædwalla, the last Saxon who adhered to the old idol-worship, was outlawed after the failure of his ambitious designs on the throne, by King Kentwine.
tgt_text.390: He secreted himself in the Andredswald, which marked the boundary between Sussex and Wessex.
tgt_text.391: Concealed by the thickets, he assembled a daring band, composed partly of real Britons, and partly of a mixed race, who had fallen back into the old Paganism, and who, as renegades, troubled them­ selves but little, if at all, about matters of faith.
tgt_text.392: When we remember that, in the commencement of all Germanic states, the offspring of the marriages between the Germans and the people conquered by them enjoyed no perfect freedom, and if we assume that King Ina1 was the first to make arrange­ ments for this equality of rights among the West Saxons, we can no longer wonder that, in so short a time, Cædwalla took so threatening a position.
tgt_text.393: His companions, who joyfully followed him as their leader, were in a similar condition with himself - their origin, their unbelief, the ban which suc­ ceeded their revolt, were all alike.
tgt_text.394: With this band, who fought for life and honour, Cædwalla kept the South Saxons, whose land was an established apple of discord between Wessex and Mercia, in a constant state of fear and terror, until, after the death of the reigning king, the Ealdermen Berthun, and Ethelhun, succeeded in driving him from his fastnesses.
tgt_text.395: But his power was not yet subdued;
tgt_text.396: he still continued as before to strive for the royal crown of Wessex.
tgt_text.397: Then, without our being able to assign any particular rea­ son for the step, Kentwine abdicated, entered a monastery2, and Cædwalla took his place as King of the West Saxons.
tgt_text.398: Still he was not baptized, although he had been already favourably disposed towards Christianity by the zealous Bishop Wilfrith of York (who, exiled from his own church and office, then dwelt in Sussex), and by his own Christian motherS.
tgt_text.399: But inspired by the old wild fury, he first took fearful revenge upon his enemies amongst the South Saxons ;
tgt_text.400: and then, in conjunction with his brother Mul, a beautiful and athletic youth, he made a fierce attack on the Jutish in­ habitants of the Isle of Wight, who were also still heathens.
tgt_text.401: At last he yielded to the entreaties of Mul, who was animated by as obstinate a spirit as his own, and invaded Kent with fire and sword.
tgt_text.402: Mul, who in his excessive rashness ventured too far into the enemy's country, was, with twelve of his companions, surrounded in a hut by the men of Kent, and burnt,alive1.
tgt_text.403: For this deed his brother took terrible revenge by blood and rapine.
tgt_text.404: But suddenly he abandoned all, relin­ quished the crown in favour of his kinsman Ina, and, im­ pelled by an irresistible inward impulse, departed for Rome.
tgt_text.405: There he was baptized by Pope Sergius in the Easter of the year 689;
tgt_text.406: and eight days afterwards, April 20th, he died, still clothed in the white robes of baptism2.
tgt_text.407: Is not this like reading a Welsh or British legend ?
tgt_text.408: Thus, like a fiery meteor, which, presaging war and desolation, burns brightly for a moment, and then suddenly disappears, Cædwalla, more Celt than German, flashes across the History of Wessex.
tgt_text.409: Ina's descent and degree of relationship to his kinsman Cædwalla3, are not easily traced, on account of the contradic­ tions in the only genealogical table which we possess;
tgt_text.410: his rule, which lasted six-and-thirty years, presents a great con­ trast to the other governments of the little state, which were rendered so unsettled by perpetual feuds and changes of their supreme head.
tgt_text.411: But contests with the neighbouring king­ doms were by no means wanting during his period of power.
tgt_text.412: The same warlike relations subsisted as before with the Britons ;
tgt_text.413: the historical records of the Welsh have connected Ina with their own Ivor;
tgt_text.414: but according to some Saxon genealogies, Ina was a brother of the Saxo-Britons, Cædwalla and Mul.
tgt_text.415: For the murder of the latter, he, at any rate, required additional satisfaction from the King of Kent, whom he compelled to pay a heavy were-geld, which the Chronicle indicates as a very considerable sum according to the stan­ dard of coinage at that time.
tgt_text.416: There were continual con­ tests with the hated Mercians;
tgt_text.417: in the year 715 another battle was fought at a place called Wodensbeorg (Wen­ borough in Wilts).
tgt_text.418: But it is gratifying to find this prince, the first of all the Saxon kings, active in the civil affairs of his state amidst the constant din of war.
tgt_text.419: According to the example of the King of Kent, he caused the laws of his people to be recorded;
tgt_text.420: and these we still possess, as they were collected and revised by Alfred.
tgt_text.421: We shall consider the tenour and importance of these laws in a suitable place.
tgt_text.422: We might naturally look, during his life, for a rapid rise in the development of the Church in Wessex, and of that civilisation which was so intimately connected with it;
tgt_text.423: and this rise assuredly could not have taken place without the sanction of the sovereign.
tgt_text.424: The strife between native and foreign influence in the young Church had continued un­ interruptedly since the days of Kenwalk.
tgt_text.425: We have already spoken of Cædwalla's intercourse with Wilfrith.
tgt_text.426: This rest­ less man had been banished from his diocese at York on account of his enthusiastic zeal for the extension of the national Church, in opposition to the wish of the Archbishop of Canterbury, Theodore the Greek.
tgt_text.427: For many years, inces­ santly brooding on his wrongs, he wandered from one dio­ cese to another, and came into Wessex, in company with, and under the protection of his yet unconverted patron.
tgt_text.428: His mind was still busy and restless there, and after some time he was invested with one of the two bishoprics.
tgt_text.429: There is no further mention of the foreigner Leutherius, and we find Hedde, a native, at the head of this diocese towards the close of the seventh century.
tgt_text.430: After his death in 703, Ina was advised to separate another see from Winchester, and to establish it at Sherborne, in Dorsetshire.
tgt_text.431: He placed there, as the first bishop, a highly distinguished man, whom we may, with good reason, suppose to have been personally intimate with him, the learned priest and poet, Aldhelm.
tgt_text.432: It is well known1, that he, a youth of high rank, and probably even of the royal family of the West Saxons, was led by his desire of learning to Canterbury;
tgt_text.433: that there, where alone they were to be learnt, at the feet of Theodore and the Abbot Hadrian, he attained perfect mastery over the classic lan­ guages of Greece and Rome,-and then returned home to the solitude of the forest by the Avon, and to his cloister Malmesbury;
tgt_text.434: and from thence, by word and writing, by ballads in his native tongue, and by Latin poetry, he in­ fluenced, instructed, and improved his countrymen and the Church, both at home and abroad.
tgt_text.435: The same undertaking, namely the protection of learning and education, both threatened with destruction, which his great contemporary Bede by various means attempted to achieve in the North of England from his tranquil cell at Wearmouth-an under­ taking whose consequences soon became evident with the diffusion of his works throughout Europe-Aldhelm per­ severingly carried on in the South, only in a different and somewhat more practical manner.
tgt_text.436: His Latin writings and poems were of much value to the Catholic Church, the lever and prop of all education in those times;
tgt_text.437: and we learn from our Alfred himself, that Aldhelm preached on the high­ roads and on the bridges to the people, and sang Christian hymns, whose old poetical form and familiar tones must have produced a wonderful effect on the sturdy, half-barbaric audience.
tgt_text.438: If Bede penetrated into a different and more speculative field of knowledge, Aldhelm possessed a pure lyrical nature, which by its energy and deep German earnest­ ness could not fail in making an impression on the most rugged characters.
tgt_text.439: Of the good he effected as Bishop of Sherborne, until his death in 709, we know scarcely any­ thing ;
tgt_text.440: but he must have sown many of those seeds which, in Alfred's days, bore such glorious fruits.
tgt_text.441: That Ina, in his endeavours for the good of the Church, was also intimately connected with Winfrid, the subsequent great Apostle of North-West Germany-and that, indeed, he made him his deputy to the Archbishop of Canterbury-we learn from the biography of this celebrated manI.
tgt_text.442: The last years of the king's reign were disturbed by internal dissensions, and by the conspiracies of the two presumptive heirs to his throne.
tgt_text.443: But he withstood these dif­ ficulties also, chiefly strengthened by the courageous support of his consort Ethelburga, a woman of a masculine spirit.
tgt_text.444: Soon afterwards, in the year 725, weary of the burden of sovereignty, and in compliance with the wishes of his queen, he abdicated the throne, and made a pilgrimage with her to Rome, where they both closed their lives in prayer and penance1.
tgt_text.445: Ina was succeeded by Ethelherd, the brother of his wife.
tgt_text.446: It seems that the passing of the crown into the female line, although the present king belonged to the royal race of Cerdic2 , entailed many internal strifes and sufferings of a serious nature on the kingdom;
tgt_text.447: which, at Ina's abdication, ought to have passed to a male relation of his own, and all the succeeding kings had to contend against the insurrec­ tions of princes of the royal blood.
tgt_text.448: During the first years of his reign, Ethelherd had to struggle against the pretensions of the Atheling Oswald.
tgt_text.449: It is no matter of wonder therefore, that encouraged by discords of such a nature, the so-often vanquished Britons sought to free themselves from their bondage ;
tgt_text.450: and they actually gained some victories over Ethel­ herd3, who was only able by great efforts to protect himself and his boundaries against another enemy, whose power was continually on the increase-King Ethelbald of Mercia.
tgt_text.451: After the death of Ethelherd in 739, Cuthred, a prince of his family, assumed his difficult and responsible position.
tgt_text.452: At first he could alone obtain the ascendancy over the neigh­ bouring Britons by an alliance with his hereditary Mercian foe.
tgt_text.453: But the Mercian soon proved a more dangerous ad­ versary than before;
tgt_text.454: for the Angles, the South Saxons, and the Welsh, became willing followers of his conquering army.
tgt_text.455: Almost at the same time, a still worse enemy arose in Cuthred's immediate vicinity, the overbearing Ealderman Ethelhun4.
tgt_text.456: According to a credible account, this most valiant warrior of his time was only subdued after a desperate conflict, and when a severe wound compelled him to lay down his arms ;
tgt_text.457: soon afterwards he performed a service to his king, whose consequences were of incalculable value to Wessex.
tgt_text.458: It was to Ethelhun that, in the year 752, was intrusted the supreme command of the Saxon troops against Ethelbald of Mercia.
tgt_text.459: At the head of his warriors, with the banner of the kingdom on which the golden dragon shone, in his hand, he rushed into the midst of the enemy's army at Burford;
tgt_text.460: the Mercian stan­ dard-bearer fell beneath his sword, and Ethelbald, who had never before met his equal in the field, trembled at the sight of such valour, and by his sudden flight decided the issue of the contestl.
tgt_text.461: This day, on which the West Saxons fought for their independence, also bestowed on them the so-long con­ tested supremacy of which the Mercians were deprived;
tgt_text.462: and which from this time exalted Wessex, in spite even of an Offa, to be the first state in the island.
tgt_text.463: Two years after this victory, which had decided so important a point, Cuthred died, leaving no direct heirs, to the great disadvantage of his country.
tgt_text.464: His successor, who on account of the similarity of his name, seems to have belonged to the royal family of Essex, and not to the race of Cerdic, was so intoxicated with the pride of his power, that he was guilty of cruel tyranny towards the free-born West Saxons;
tgt_text.465: and soon afterwards, driven by them from house and home, he perished as an outlaw in the Andredswald.
tgt_text.466: His short reign, as well as that of the Cerdician Cynewulf, who was raised to the throne in his stead by the assembled nobles, and which lasted three-and-thirty years, show us in a striking manner that the internal affairs of the state were not well arranged for a long period, and that the succession especially needed a fixed arrangement which might secure the kingdom from tyrants, and the princes from usurpers.
tgt_text.467: Only very slight in­ formation remains to us of the last ruler, with the exception of some casual mention of his campaigns against Wales and Mercia.
tgt_text.468: His violent end is almost the only circumstance which the native Year-books relate with unwonted circumstantiality.
tgt_text.470: Cynewulf was prosecuting a secret amour at Merton, in Devonshire, not suspecting that the Prince Cyneard, a brother of the Sigebert whom he had dethroned, was plotting against his life and his crown.
tgt_text.471: The traitor, with his adherents, surrounded the castle where the king was staying;
tgt_text.472: and when the latter was about to place himself at the gates to defend them against the assailants, Cyneard perceived him, and he was immediately disarmed and slain.
tgt_text.473: The shrieks of the women roused the few atten­ dants from their sleep:
tgt_text.474: bravely fighting, they also fell, disdain­ ing Cyneard's offers of life and reward.

tgt_text.483: By election, the crown now devolved on Bertric, who belonged to another branch of the royal race, passing over those who had better-founded claims to the sovereignty.
tgt_text.484: For example, there was in existence a great grandson of Ingild, King Ina's brother, whose name was Elmund, and who had obtained possession of the kingdom of Kent, we may suppose, by force of a similar enterprise to that by which Cædwalla had formerly attained Wessex.
tgt_text.485: Elmund's son Eg­ bert, a daring and ambitious young man, remembered his old rights to the crown of his hereditary lands;
tgt_text.486: the new ruler could only maintain his power by forcing the pretender to leave the kingdom, and even the island;
tgt_text.487: and Egbert did not venture, during Bertric's life, to make any attempt in favour of his claims.
tgt_text.488: Meanwhile, the West Saxons had not been deceived in their choice of a sovereign ;
tgt_text.489: for the reign of Bertric, unlike that of either of his predecessors, was throughout peaceful and prosperous.
tgt_text.490: It is true, however, that at this time, harbingers of evil days appeared on the coast of Dorsetshire­ the first three ships of the pirate Northmen, who, in the course of a few years, were destined to overwhelm the whole fertile island;
tgt_text.491: but they committed then no further outrage than some robberies, and the murder of the chief officer of the king and his people, who had gone to meet them from Dorchester, in order to oppose their landing unless the customary toll was paidl.
tgt_text.492: There now existed a lasting peace with Mercia;
tgt_text.493: for, im­ mediately after his accession to the throne, Bertric had married Eadburga, the daughter of the great King Offa a.
tgt_text.494: The sword and spear now had a long resting time, and the hands which had wielded them found more useful occupation in hold­ ing the plough.
tgt_text.495: But in his wife, the king nourished a viper in his bosom.
tgt_text.496: She came from a mother who had once plunged a dagger into the heart of her own son-in-law;
tgt_text.497: and imagining that her influence over her husband-which she well knew how to turn to the advantage of her native land-was de.
tgt_text.498: creasing, she did not hesitate to mix poison in the drink of the Ealderman Warr, a young and talented favourite of the king.
tgt_text.499: But Bertric also drank of the cup, and died a victim to the crime of his wife2.
tgt_text.501: and after a long and restless life, met a miserable and ignominious end in Italy3.
tgt_text.502: Bertric ended his life exactly at the time when Charle­ magne set off for Rome to claim the imperial crown from the hands of the Pope.
tgt_text.503: During his absence, Egbert, who had passed his thirteen1 years of exile in the Frankish camp, complied with the summons of his adherents, and resolved to return home with all speed, to take possession of that throne which in future no one dared dispute with him.
tgt_text.504: His long residence in the immediate neighbourhood of Charlemagne had not been without the most decided and lasting influence on the development of his own personal character, and on the history of his government.
tgt_text.505: There had for a long time existed an extensive commerce between the Franks and the Anglo-Saxons, but the two nations not only exchanged their productions in a trading intercourse, they had also many political relations of a friendly nature, and were bound together by common spiritual interest.
tgt_text.506: Both fought against the same enemy:
tgt_text.507: for the continental Celts maintained unbroken their ancient connexion with those of the Island of Britain;
tgt_text.508: and it also seemed probable that the Christian Germanic tribes, on both sides of the Channel, would be threatened by the dangerous foe which now first began to appear on the seas.
tgt_text.509: The requirements of the Church and her ministers also induced Charlemagne, as they had done his forefathers, to remain in a close alliance with the learned and zealous islanders, and not to allow the ties of friendship which bound him to the different courts of Mercia and Northumberland to be loosened.
tgt_text.510: The Franks always bore in mind what they and their mighty state owed to a Bonifacius;
tgt_text.511: after him, they had seen what had been effected by Willehad;
tgt_text.512: and now they followed their teacher Alcuin, full of astonishment at the extent of his learning.
tgt_text.513: When Charlemagne, animated by a feeling of gratitude, willingly afforded an asylum to the fugitive prince, the latter was also indebted to him for much instruction and many benefits.
tgt_text.514: The rough, honest Saxon not only learnt from the more refined Frank a greater dexterity in the use of arms, and a more polished demeanour, but he marked attentively what was passing before his eyes;
tgt_text.515: he saw how, in a skilful hand, the reins of government might be made to unite and hold in a straight course the numerous Teutonic races, be­ tween whom, originally, no political connexion subsisted;
tgt_text.516: he learnt the means by which the most obstinate enemy was in­ spired with terror and dismay, even at the furthest extremi­ ties of the kingdom;
tgt_text.517: and he could not but have admired the care and ability by which the greatest ruler of his nation endeavoured to maintain order and lasting peace.
tgt_text.518: Egbert did not neglect to profit by these excellent and important lessons.
tgt_text.519: From the moment when he set foot on his native land as its king, the idea was uppermost in his mind of forming one entire kingdom which might be able to keep its enemies in check, and effect much internal good, out of the numerous small states, which, in their present state of isolation, had the greatest difficulty in main­ taining their existence.
tgt_text.520: Directly on his arrival, however, his northern neighbours endeavoured to place difficulties in his path ;
tgt_text.521: a band of Mercian Hwiccas passed over the boun­ dary river, the Isis, but this attack was defeated by a brave troop of Wiltshire men, and a treaty was provisionally con­ cluded with King Cenwulf of Mercia1.
tgt_text.522: No opposition was raised to Egbert's accession, and thus, after many unquiet reigns, during which one descendant of Cerdic strove against another, the sceptre at last devolved on the true heir, who was able to ensure its succession to his own family.
tgt_text.523: That he closely followed the example of the emperor, and was anxious to bring into operation those plans which he had already matured abroad, is clearly evident from the fact, which, however, rests on somewhat modern authority, that one of the first acts of his reign was to bestow the name of England upon his kingdom and those provinces over which his influence extended, at a Witenagemote held at Winchester.
tgt_text.524: Assuming that this account, in its present form, is merely a confused fabrication of the following century, we cannot doubt that it contains a germ of truth.

tgt_text.564: The kingdom of Wessex now commanded the respect of all the remaining provinces by its geographical situation and extent;

tgt_text.569: Egbert, nevertheless, succeeded in uniting all these separate districts by the ties of a common interest;

tgt_text.2827: Apparently, the purpose of the heathen was to go across the Thames and to reach Essex, whither their ships had already sailed.
tgt_text.2828: Alfred im­ mediately went with his troops in order to cut off their retreat.
tgt_text.2829: At Farnham, in Surrey, he compelled them to fight, completely defeated them, and took from them all the spoil they had amassed.
tgt_text.2830: The Prince Edward gloriously dis­ tinguished himself in the bloody conflict;
tgt_text.2831: the heathen king (Björn ?) fled wounded from the battle-field.
tgt_text.2832: His army rushed in wild confusion towards the north, and passed over the Thames, being unable to discover more than one ford, which was probably between Hampton and Kingston.
tgt_text.2833: They re­ turned into Essex, and first reassembled in the island of Thorney, which lies at the outlet of the Colne, where their vessels had previously gone.
tgt_text.2834: Alfred at once despatched a part of his army in the same direction.
tgt_text.2835: For a long time the Saxons blockaded the Danish ships, but at length their provisions failed;
tgt_text.2836: the time of service of that division which maintained the siege had expired, and in all probability they had no ships with which to approach the enemy by sea.
tgt_text.2837: The soldiers, by whom the siege had been commenced and then relinquished, were re­ turned home, and Alfred was himself approaching with the troop appointed to take their place, to keep the besieged army in check, and fully to annihilate it, when he received intelli­ gence of a sudden attack which had been made by the faithless Northumbrians and East Angles upon the western coasts of his kingdom.
tgt_text.2838: The Danes, who had not yet recovered the heavy losses which they had sustained at Farnham, and being impeded by their severely-wounded king, who could not keep up with them, had, in order to overtake their allies, collected together several hundred vessels, in which they sailed for some distance along the south coast, and threatened to take possession of Exeter, whilst a fleet of forty ships went into the Bristol Channel, and commenced an attack upon a citadel in the north of Devonshire.
tgt_text.2839: The scheme was cunningly devised, for that part of the kingdom was then entirely destitute of every means of defence.
tgt_text.2840: When this intelligence was conveyed to Alfred, he resolved to return immediately with the principal part of the troops then remaining with him, to make preparations for defending his western pro­ vinces, and to prevent the enemy from every attempt at gaining possession of them1.
tgt_text.2841: But whilst the king provided for the accomplishment of this object, he had at the same time to carry on the warfare in the east.
tgt_text.2842: For this purpose he had left behind a strong body of his forces, which marched towards London, and with other auxiliary troops hastening thither from the west, re­ inforced the garrison already there.
tgt_text.2843: Unquestionably this army, commanded by the Ealderman Ethelred, on whom de­ volved the duty of protecting the eastern parts of the king­ dom, penetrated into Essex as far as Bamfleet.
tgt_text.2844: Thither Hasting had gone with his troops, shortly after the battle at Farnham, again occupying that fortress which he had abandoned in the year 885.
tgt_text.2845: The large army which had been formerly settled at Appledore, and had then been driven to the mouth of the Colne, was also opposed to him ;
tgt_text.2846: it was now within the citadel, and Hasting was engaged in a plundering expedition, when the Saxons appeared before it in all their strength.
tgt_text.2847: They easily overcame the resistance attempted against them, stormed the fortress, and took possession of all they found therein, women and children, as well as every kind of property, and returned home to London enriched with much spoil.
tgt_text.2848: The ships which they had found ashore at Bamfleet, were partly broken to pieces or burned, partly taken to London and Rochester.
tgt_text.2849: Amongst the prisoners were the wife and the two sons of Hasting, who were sent to King Alfred;
tgt_text.2850: he did not avenge himself upon them, however, but once again showed his generous and Christian nature by sending them back to the treacherous Dane, with costly presents.
tgt_text.2851: Hasting, who had violated his oath to the godfather of his children, could not yet be won to improvement and conversion.
tgt_text.2852: Even after his fortress was taken, and he had experienced the most bene­ volent treatment from Ethelred and Alfred, he did not ab­ stain from devastating in the wildest manner the dominions of his benefactors1.
tgt_text.2853: He knew that his brave opponent was busily engaged in the distant west, and, in a short time, he effected a union of the scattered hordes in Essex, which be reinforced by fresh allies from the coasts of Northumbria and East Anglia.
tgt_text.2854: He formed with them a strong entrench­ ment at Shobury, somewhat to the east of Bamfleet.
tgt_text.2855: He soon considered his forces sufficiently strong to attack Mercia;
tgt_text.2856: then marched up the left bank of the Thames, and passed across the country, until he reached the Severn, intending to follow the course of that river towards the south.
tgt_text.2857: But Ethelred did not look idly on during these disturb­ ances, he collected together all the troops under his com­ mand ;
tgt_text.2858: Ethelhelm, the Ealderman of Wiltshire, Ealderman Ethelnoth, and the royal Thanes who occupied the garrisons, also came with their forces.
tgt_text.2859: Those places east of the river Parrot, and east and west of Selwood, sent their soldiers, as did the countries north of the Thames and west of the Severn, and even North Wales.
tgt_text.2860: With this great army Ethelred marched against the Danes, and encountered them at Buttington, on the banks of the Severn, where they were secured behind their fortifications.
tgt_text.2861: He immediately sur- rounded them on every side, and for many weeks1 prevented them from making any attempt to escape.
tgt_text.2862: As all means of conveyance were cut off, a fearful famine ensued amongst the besieged army;
tgt_text.2863: they had already devoured the greater number of their horses, and many had died of starvation, when Hasting found himself compelled to risk a sally to­ wards the east.
tgt_text.2864: A fearful battle ensued, in which many royal
tgt_text.2865: Thanes were killed, amongst them one named0rdheh;
tgt_text.2866: but the Christians were victorious, and scattered the North­ men in wild flight2.
tgt_text.2867: If that is true which we gather from the incomprehen­ sible words of Ethelwerd, Hasting concluded a treaty, by which he promised to quit Mercia.
tgt_text.2868: It is clear that he was obliged to do so without delay;
tgt_text.2869: and his victors appear to have permitted him to depart unmolested.
tgt_text.2870: He reached his fortress in Essex;
tgt_text.2871: but before the winter3, he hastily gathered together the dispersed remnant of his countrymen, and fresh troops of East Angles and Northumbrians, and formed them into a large army.
tgt_text.2872: They gave their women, their ships, and all their property, into the charge of the East Angles, and then journeyed, day and night, in unbroken marches back again to the north-west.
tgt_text.2873: The pirate seems to have laid much stress upon effecting his passage to the western coast;
tgt_text.2874: perhaps he purposed advancing to the assist­ ance of the great fleet on the coast of Devonshire, which was in the mean time hard pressed by Alfred.
tgt_text.2875: Immediately after the victory at Buttington, Ethelred had dismissed the Mercian troops according to custom.
tgt_text.2876: Thus Hasting met with no opposition to his departure, and he reached Chester, which lies at the entrance of the penin­ sula of Wirral4.
tgt_text.2877: But he did not succeed in surprising the garrison, which was safe behind the walls;
tgt_text.2878: and the Danes contented themselves with besieging the city for two days, killing the few people whom they found without the walls, and driving all the cattle from the fields.
tgt_text.2879: They burnt the corn which fell into their hands, or consumed it themselves with their horses1.
tgt_text.2880: Hasting passed the winter at Wirral;
tgt_text.2881: in the spring of the year 895 he made preparations for going into North Wales, for the supplies of cattle and corn had either been exhausted by his troops or again taken from him2.
tgt_text.2882: In Wales they advanced towards the south, and especially ravaged Gwent, Brecknock, and many other adjacent dis­ tricts3.
tgt_text.2883: With the plunder which they obtained there they returned to the north, passed inland across Northumbria and East Anglia, so that the Mercians who went in pursuit could not overtake them.
tgt_text.2884: They probably approached York, and then went through the Mercian territory towards the south.
tgt_text.2885: Near Stamford, on the river Welland, in Northamp­ tonshire, a battle must have taken place between Hasting and the Ealderman Ethelnoth, who advanced against him from the west4.
tgt_text.2886: The greater number of the heathens re­ turned, however, to Essex, and established themselves -in the island of Mersey.
tgt_text.2887: At the same time that Hasting went into Wales, a pirate named Sigeferth sailed with his fleet from Northumbria, and devastated and pillaged along the coasts, after which he re­ turned home laden with booty6.
tgt_text.2888: Meanwhile Alfred had kept the field in Devonshire for a whole year, although no decisive event appears to have taken place in this part of the kingdom;
tgt_text.2889: but he prevented the germ of his state, the old West Saxon province, from being devastated by the Danes, and at length compelled the great fleet which had vainly attempted to blockade Exeter to put to sea again and to sail homewards.
tgt_text.2890: On their way thither, the Danes and East Angles made a sudden onslaught upon the coast of Sussex, not far from Chichester;
tgt_text.2891: but the citizens of that place attacked them, put them to flight, killed several hundreds of them, and seized some of their ships;
tgt_text.2892: the remainder joined their comrades in the island of Merseyl.
tgt_text.2893: Before the end of the winter, the Danish encampment there was in motion;
tgt_text.2894: they had left their ships afloat, and now towed them up the Thames, and thence up the Lea.
tgt_text.2895: The winter was passed in erecting a fort at a distance of four German miles north of London, in the neighbourhood of Hertford or Ware.
tgt_text.2896: With the summer of 896 a considerable number of Saxons and others came out of the garrison in London and assailed the fortress;
tgt_text.2897: but they were repulsed by the Danes, and four royal Thanes were killed.
tgt_text.2898: About the time of harvest, Alfred, with a powerful army, encamped in the vicinity of London, in order that the people might carry their crops without molestation from the Danes.
tgt_text.2899: One day, when the king was riding by the side of the little river Lea he discovered a place where the channel might be very easily disturbed, so that the stream could be diverted from its course, thus preventing the enemy from bringing out their vessels.
tgt_text.2900: He began by causing two forts to be constructed on both sides of the Lea2.
tgt_text.2901: His soldiers had encamped near the spot, and were busily engaged in the work, when the Danes observed that the water was flowing off, and that it would be impossible for them to take away their ships.
tgt_text.2903: they had before left their women in the charge of the East Angles, and they then hastened to- wards the north, and again marched through the country to­ wards the Severn, and encamped near Bridgenorth1 in Shrop­ shire.
tgt_text.2904: Whilst Alfred despatched his army in pursuit for Mine distance, the inhabitants of London took the forsaken ships into their possession.
tgt_text.2905: Such as were useless were all destroyed, but the serviceable ones were taken to London2.
tgt_text.2906: In the summer of the following year, the great army of Northmen left the Severn, and divided into three parts, one of which returned home into East Anglia, and another went into Northumbria.
tgt_text.2907: The third division, which was in the greatest need, procured ships, and led by Hasting, went southwards across the sea to the mouth of the Seine3.
tgt_text.2908: Here the old pirate understood how to compel King Charles the Simple to give up a piece of land in the province of Chartres, the possession of which was quietly enjoyed by Hasting until fifteen years later, when Rollo conquered Normandy4.
tgt_text.2909: Thus, after three years' valiant defence, the kingdom of the West Saxons was delivered from the destructive foe who had endeavoured to penetrate into it from all sides, by land and by water, and who at last were forced to abandon their purpose, and to depart as poor as they came.
tgt_text.2911: Thanks be to God," writes the old Saxon chronicler, " this time the heathen did not so utterly despoil the English people5.”
tgt_text.2912: And we may venture to conjecture from Alfred's character, that he and all his people celebrated a joyful festival of thanksgiving in the restored and well-guarded churches.
tgt_text.2913: But another evil, from which the Saxons suffered greater loss than in the battle-field, was the contagious sickness, which, in consequence of the ravages and other distresses attendant on war, raged amongst men and beasts.
tgt_text.2914: Even the highest classes of the community were not exempt from the pesti­ lence, and amongst the most honoured dignitaries and officers in the kingdom who died at that time were the Bishops.
tgt_text.2915: Swithulf of Rochester, and Ealheard of Dorchester;
tgt_text.2916: the Ealdermen Ceolmund of Kent, Beorhtulf of Essex, and Wulfred of Hampshire ;
tgt_text.2918: Beomwulf, the Burggrave of Winchester, and Ecgulf, the king's riding- master ;
tgt_text.2919: all of whom belonged to those important ranks upon which depended the welfare and security of the country.
tgt_text.2920: Yet the courage of the people and of their king by no means failed;
tgt_text.2921: once more, and, indeed, for the last time in Alfred's life, they were obliged to make preparations for de­ fence.
tgt_text.2922: The hostile troops, which came from Bridgenorth into Northumbria and East Anglia, and which consisted of the faithless inhabitants of those parts, and of many homeless Danes, ventured again to attack the West Saxon territory, and endeavoured especially to reach the southern coast, where hitherto they had gained but little plunder, in the light vessels fabricated by them long since, in anticipation of such an enterprisel.
tgt_text.2923: Alfred, who had learnt to meet the enemy with their own weapons, and who had always succeeded, now resolved to attack them with all his power upon the sea itself.
tgt_text.2924: Amidst so many other cares, it had been until now impos­ sible for him to arrange a fleet.
tgt_text.2925: A great many ships had been, indeed, repeatedly seized by his people in past years, and now lay in the harbours of London and Rochester.
tgt_text.2926: He might have very well employed them for his purpose, but the Danish vessels were small and frail;
tgt_text.2927: besides, the Saxons were not such bold and hardy mariners as the Danes.
tgt_text.2928: Alfred sought in the stores of his inventive and persevering mind for means to remedy this evil.
tgt_text.2929: He caused long ships to be built, nearly twice the length of the Scandinavian ships2, most of them propelled by sixty or even more oars.
tgt_text.2930: He proposed to gain stronger, higher, and at the same time more rapid vessels;
tgt_text.2931: and in this aim he copied neither from Frisian nor Danish models, but produced an entirely national result, and furnished his country with a means of defence which, in later years, became the pride of the island and made her the sovereign of the seas.
tgt_text.2932: Thus in the history of England's naval power, also, Alfred is found to have taken an important onward step.
tgt_text.2933: In order to man this new fleet, be obtained, besides the mariners on his own coasts, certain Frisians who were particularly good sailors, and had not only lived and traded peaceably with the opposite island, but in the continual conflicts with the same foe must have acquired considerable skill in maritime war.
tgt_text.2934: Frisians and Saxons were both Low Germans and Christians;
tgt_text.2935: they agreed together admirably, and endeavoured unanimously to repel heathenism.
tgt_text.2936: When the Danes in their old manner commenced their ravages on the south coast, Alfred determined to chastise them with his new fleet.
tgt_text.2937: Six hostile ships were stationed off the Isle of Wight, and disturbed by unexpected landings the opposite coast as far as Devonshire1:
tgt_text.2938: they had even en­ tered a port of that province, when nine of Alfred's galleys appeared at the entrance, and blocked up their egress by sea.
tgt_text.2939: The Danes rowed against them with three of their ships, the three others remained aground somewhat further up the stream, where the tide had ebbed, and permitted the rapacious troops to land.
tgt_text.2940: The Saxons immediately began the conflict in six of their ships, seized upon two of the three Danish vessels and killed the crews;
tgt_text.2941: the third escaped, after losing all its men excepting five.
tgt_text.2942: But in the heat of the battle the Saxons had failed to notice the shallowness of the water;
tgt_text.2943: three of their ships went ashore before the commence­ ment of the affray, on the same side as the three Danish ves­ sels were stranded, and the Saxons succeeded in landing there.
tgt_text.2944: The other Saxon ships ran in upon the opposite shore, and this gave one of the enemy's ships an opportunity to escape, but all means of communication with their comrades was cut off.
tgt_text.2945: Meanwhile the Danes who reached the land had acquired knowledge from the past, and as the sea had so far receded that all the ships which lay ashore on their side were by this time at a great distance2 from the water, in the fury of desperation they hastened to attack the Saxons.
tgt_text.2946: Upon the shore a furious conflict ensued between the two forces, in which one hundred and twenty Danes were killed ;
tgt_text.2947: but on the Saxon side, Lucumon, the king's reeve;
tgt_text.2949: the Frisian seamen, Wulfheard, Aebbe, and Ethelhere, with sixty-two other brave men, were slain.
tgt_text.2950: Those Saxons whose ships remained immovable on the other bank of the river, so that they could not hasten to the rescue, were almost desperate when they were obliged to witness such a disaster1.
tgt_text.2951: Already the victory seemed nearly decided in favour of the Danes, when they perceived that their ships began to be afloat before those of their opponents.
tgt_text.2952: They hastily rushed into them, seized the oars, and guided them out to sea.
tgt_text.2953: They had gained an important advantage when the nine large Saxon ships were released and able to follow them.
tgt_text.2954: The vessels of the pirates were so much injured, that they could not venture to take them along the dangerous coasts of Sussex:
tgt_text.2955: the sea cast two of them on shore, where the inhabitants seized the crews, and took them prisoners to Winchester.
tgt_text.2956: Alfred, who was at that place, caused the cap­ tives to be hanged together on the gallows.
tgt_text.2957: The crew of the remaining ship came sorely wounded into East Anglia.
tgt_text.2958: In the same summer twenty Danish vessels were wrecked upon the south coast, and every soul on board perished2.
tgt_text.2959: These are the last-recorded hostilities during Alfred's reign.
tgt_text.2960: His attempt to cope with the enemy by sea could not in this instance be called successful — his people had gained the battle only after severe losses, and his large ships had been taken into a channel for which they were certainly not fitted.
tgt_text.2961: Much was still needed before the Saxons could com­ pete with their adversaries by sea, in boldness and ability, yet they ventured to do so, and were able to defend their coasts from hostile attacks with the new fleet, especially in the ensuing year.
tgt_text.2962: The Danes were now exhausted in the British island, they were kept in perfect restraint by the vigilance of Alfred.
tgt_text.2963: Posterity knows scarcely anything of the four last years of the king'is life:
tgt_text.2964: after peace was restored, the old authorities had nothing more important to record than the death of some exalted personages, such as the Marshal Wulfric, the brave Ealderman Ethelhelm, and Eahstan, Bishop of London1.
tgt_text.2965: But besides what we know and have already minutely consi­ dered respecting Alfred's diversified sphere of action, we may confidently venture to fill up the chasm still left, by assuming that the king continued to enjoy the leisure time of peace by advancing his own mental improvement and that of those who belonged to him, as far as he was permitted by the affairs of his office and his bodily sufferings.
tgt_text.2966: He pro­ moted the welfare of his country by a just administration of his laws ;
tgt_text.2967: the instruction of his youthful subjects prospered under his special superintendence;
tgt_text.2968: and the time that was left at his disposal, after the fulfilment of his other duties, was devoted as before to study.
tgt_text.2969: After the years of peril had passed, he undoubtedly resumed his long-suspended literary labours in conjunction with his learned companions, and per­ haps completed many works which had been previously com­ menced.
tgt_text.2970: But the bodily weakness caused by an insidious disease, from which Alfred suffered during the most precious years of his life, and which must have been much aggravated by severe privations and rigorous weather throughout a long­ sustained war, brought, in all probability, a premature age upon him ;
tgt_text.2971: his powers, which he had so greatly exerted with unwearied energy in spite of all obstacles, now failed, and he died, on the 28th of October, 901, at the early age of fifty- three years and six months2.
tgt_text.2972: The exact particulars relating to his death were never recorded.
tgt_text.2973: But he died, as he had lived, happy in the consciousness of having fulfilled his duty to his best ability.
tgt_text.2974: His body was buried in the monastery founded by him at Winchester, in which place most probably his death occurred, and which had risen rapidly of late to be the chief city of the kingdom;
tgt_text.2975: here also his father and most of his ancestors were interred.
tgt_text.2976: According to a more recent account, he was previously buried in the epis­ copal cathedral where these graves actually were, because the new monastery of the Virgin Mary was not yet finished;
tgt_text.2977: but when the canons of the Church, excited by their national credulity, and by hostile feelings towards the clergy of the new monastery, declared that the spirit of the great king might be seen wandering about at night, his son ordered the coffin to be removed into the adjoining build­ ing, which was nearly completedl.
tgt_text.2978: In the reign of Henry I. the ashes were again removed into Hyde Abbey, opposite the northern gate of Winchester, where they were preserved until the Reformation, and the destruction of that edifice2.
tgt_text.2979: The country enjoyed a happy peace, when it had recovered from the grief occasioned by the death of its deliverer.
tgt_text.2980: He had been able to keep under his sceptre the whole of the English nation, excepting the east coast, where, before his accession, the Danes had succeeded in establishing them­ selves;
tgt_text.2981: but they, too, were dependent on him, and Wales obeyed without resistance.
tgt_text.2982: The eldest son of Alfred followed the course destined for him by his father, and immediately claimed his right of inheritance ;
tgt_text.2983: more fortunate than Alfred had been at his accession, when the enemy occupied the land, and engaged him in lengthened battles.
tgt_text.2984: Edward had already attained his majority, his father had educated him to rule, and had proved that he was worthy.
tgt_text.2985: It is known that in 898 he took part in the affairs of government3.
tgt_text.2986: During his reign he always justified the confidence placed in him by his father, and he quickly gained that of his subjects also.
tgt_text.2987: Even in the first year he showed his efficiency.
tgt_text.2988: His cousin Ethelwald, the second son of King Ethelred, yet a child at the time of Alfred's accession, and excluded from the throne by his father's express regulation4, attempted to claim his rights :
tgt_text.2989: he was actuated by feelings in favour of a direct succession, which hitherto had never been fully re­ cognised in the kingdoms of Christendom.
tgt_text.2990: Without the ap­ proval of all the people acknowledging him as the legiti­ mate successor of Alfred, and without the consent of the Witan, he took possession of two royal domains.
tgt_text.2991: He en­ deavoured to maintain them with a troop of audacious ad­ venturers, but he could find no party to his cause through­ out the country of the Saxons.
tgt_text.2992: Besides, he was, in the opinion of the world, guilty of a heinous sin, having taken a maiden, who had been previously consecrated a nun, to be his wife, without permission from the king or the bishop.
tgt_text.2993: When Edward had advanced with his followers, and en­ camped in the neighbourhood of Wimborne, the beleaguered prince swore that he would either live or die there ;
tgt_text.2994: but in the night he stole secretly out of his fortress, and escaped to join the Danes in Northumbria.
tgt_text.2995: With their help, joined with that of the enemy within the country, he believed that he could establish his claims.
tgt_text.2996: They indeed acknowledged him as their ruler, and obeyed his commands1.
tgt_text.2997: According to the custom of the pirates, he visited the domains of Edward with repeated devastations, but it was not until the year 905 that he ventured to invade Mercia with a large army, commanded by Eohric, King of the East Angles.
tgt_text.2998: He reached the Thames at Cricklade, and crossed the river, intending to carry home his plunder eastward through his cousin's territory.
tgt_text.2999: At length he was attacked by Edward, near the Ouse.
tgt_text.3000: Unfortunately for the king, and notwithstanding his commands, the Kentish men, who con­ sidered that the term of their service was expired, and who had gone home, could not be induced to return.
tgt_text.3001: They were punished for this refusal by a defeat from the Danes;
tgt_text.3002: but immediately afterwards, the foe was completely vanquished by Edward, and amongst many other hostile leaders, King Eohric and the Prince Ethelwald were slain2.
tgt_text.3003: This victory was of no slight importance.
tgt_text.3004: The Pretender himself, whom none of the Christian people would accept, and who had thrown them into the power of the heathen, had fallen in battle, and his colleagues were also conquered and punished.
tgt_text.3005: Shortly after, Edward compelled the Danes in East Anglia and Northumbria to conclude the treaty of Yttingaford1 , wherein he, with the new prince, Guthorm II., entered into those resolutions which we have already recorded, as a ratification of the peace of Wedmore, concluded by Al­ fred.
tgt_text.3006: However, this peace was not sufficiently durable to secure the country from fresh invasions;
tgt_text.3007: in connexion with events in France, and particularly with Rollo's conquest of Nor­ mandy, the Danes, who had been converted to Christianity, moved to the east coasts, especially in the years 911 and 918, and invaded them repeatedly both by sea and land, but Ethelred of Mercia and King Edward always repulsed them with great loss.
tgt_text.3008: The king, who was strong and brave, like his father, was on all occasions fortunate and successful;
tgt_text.3009: the people prospered under his government, and they reso­ lutely opposed the foe whenever they appeared.
tgt_text.3010: The mind of Alfred lived and operated both in king and subjects, and brought to perfection that of which he had laid the founda­ tions amidst toils and dangers.
tgt_text.3011: Edward effected the security of the country not only by the construction or restora­ tion of a large number of fortresses, but he fortified many towns, which contributed greatly towards its prosperity.
tgt_text.3012: As proofs of this, the authorities give such names as Chester, Hertford, Stafford, Tamworth, Warwick, and others-.
tgt_text.3013: Towns like Towcester were for the first time surrounded by stone walls, and it was decreed in the laws of Edward that all labour and traffic should be only carried on within fortified places2.
tgt_text.3014: Like a careful prince, he endeavoured to secure his subjects and their property from every disadvantageous alliance with the deceitful foe.
tgt_text.3015: He gained for the kingdom itself prosperity as well as pro­ tection.
tgt_text.3016: For in 912, when his brother-in-law, Ethelred, died, London and Oxford immediately appertained to Wessex, and Edward gladly seized on both these places, taking them into complete and lasting possession.
tgt_text.3017: The remainder of Mercia continued under the powerful sway of his sister Ethel­ fleda, who governed and ruled like a true daughter of Alfred.
tgt_text.3018: She built fortresses in conjunction with Edward, marched to the field herself, and in particular, defeated the Welsh prince, Owen, who had revolted and entered into a league with the Danes.
tgt_text.3019: Allied with this daring woman, the king was enabled to extend the eastern boundaries of the king­ dom, and to resist the encroachments of the Northmen.
tgt_text.3020: This occurred especially at Derby, Leicester, Huntingdon, and also at Essex, where the citadel of Witham adjoined Maldon.
tgt_text.3021: Beyond the boundaries, the Danes in Northumbria and East Anglia again submitted to the supremacy of the West Saxons.

tgt_text.3223: Providence had sent him upon earth at a time when the nature of the kingdom was undergoing a decided change.

tgt_text.3227: We have compared Egbert to Charlemagne, but among the Franks the disturbances and alterations only began to make rapid progress with the decline of the Carlovingian race, whilst Alfred still continued to preserve the German nation in all its purity during this century, so that it was only by degrees that it was disturbed by the influence of a new and powerful system.

tgt_text.3236: His efforts for the diffusion of the latter were at least as great as his evident desire to attain high temporal authority as a Christian monarch.

tgt_text.3239: The roots of all the evils of the Saxon and Low German national character, sluggishness and indolence, he distin­ guished, with his keen glance, above all other failings, and endeavoured to combat them in every possible manner;
tgt_text.3240: now by kind teaching and exhortation-now, when his patience became exhausted by repeated disobedience, by well-meant punishment.
tgt_text.3241: His active mind was needed to set in motion the slumbering strength of his people, and to see justice done to its real value, as well as to drive out stubborn pre­ judices1.
tgt_text.3242: When the aged were not willing to receive in.
tgt_text.3243: struction, and especially when they retarded the execution of justice, he shamed them by the industry of youth, in which he knew how to sow the seeds of knowledge and a better comprehension of the right.
tgt_text.3244: By his own example alone was he able to induce the people to apply themselves • to the strengthening and defence of the country.
tgt_text.3245: He car­ ried his point, and Saxons of all ranks rejoiced in the re­ conquered freedom which Alfred had given them, a freedom whose nature was more secure than before, and the nume­ rous class of serfs, who until then had been treated as living property, received the invaluable gift of liberty of choice in their masters;
tgt_text.3246: and, in common with their noble and free countrymen, held the memory of their king in grateful re­ membrance long after his death.
tgt_text.3247: So stands the image of Alfred, shining brightly in the book of the world's history, never defaced by malice or igno­ rance, nor dimmed by his own errors.
tgt_text.3248: These he necessarily possessed, but they have been entirely forgotten in the blaze of his virtues, over which the lapse of centuries has cast no cloud.
tgt_text.3249: Severe trial and purifying cleansed him like a noble metal from all dross.
tgt_text.3250: Praise can never degenerate into flat­ tery in the case of a great man whose strong sense of duty and exalted principles of morality have led him to employ his time in a truly noble manner.
tgt_text.3251: No king nor hero of an­ tiquity or modern times can be compared with Alfred for so many distinguished qualities, and each so excellent.
tgt_text.3252: Princes more renowned for power and glory, and reigning over greater nations, have always had some defect in their moral character, which forcibly contrasts with our high esti­ mation of their mental qualities;
tgt_text.3253: and although by the side of Alfred, ruling in his narrow Wessex, their forms appear to tower high amongst the stars, yet his figure, in its smaller proportions, remains one of the most perfect ever held up by the hand of God as a mirror to the world and its rulers.
tgt_text.3254: As such a noble example he has lived in the memory of a thousand years, and during that period the people whom be governed have spread over the earth, making homes for themselves, and establishing freedom and independence of thought and deed to its most remote bounds.

tgt_text.3271: OUR forefathers divided all the orb of this earth, eaith Orosius, which is encircled by the ocean that is called Garsecg, into three, and named those three parts Asia, and Europe, and Africa, though some men have said that there were only two parts;
tgt_text.3273: Asia is bounded to the southward, northward, and eastward, by the ocean, and thus comprises half of all this earth from the eastern part.
tgt_text.3274: Then in the north part, that is of Asia, and on the right side, Europe and Asia join together in the river Tanais;
tgt_text.3275: and then from this same river Tanais, south along the Mediterranean, and west of Alexandria, Asia and Africa join together1.
tgt_text.3276: Europe begins, as I said before, from the river Tanais, which takes its source from the northern parts of the Riphæan mountains, which are near the ocean that is called the Sarma­ tian;
tgt_text.3277: and the river Tanais thence runs directly south, on the west side of Alexander's temples2, to the nation of the Rho­ covasci.
tgt_text.3278: It forms the fen which is called Mæotis, and thence forth with a great flood, near the city called Theodosia, flows to the eastward into the sea called the Euxine, and then with a long narrowness south from thence passes east of Constantinople, the Greek city, and thence out into the Mediterranean.
tgt_text.3279: The boundary of the south-west end of Europe is in Spain westward at the ocean, and especially at the island called Cadiz, where the Mediterranean flows from the ocean where Hercules's pillars stand.
tgt_text.3280: In this same Me­ diterranean, to the westward, is Scotland.
tgt_text.3281: Of Africa and Asia the land-boundaries begin from Alex­ andria, a city of Egypt, and that boundary lies south from thence over the river Nile, and then over the Ethiopian desert, as far as the Southern Ocean.
tgt_text.3282: And the north- western boundary of Africa is at the same Mediterranean sea, which flows from the ocean where Hercules's pillars stand;
tgt_text.3283: and its right western boundary is at the mountain called Atlas, and at the island called the Fortunate.
tgt_text.3284: Now I have shortly spoken of the three parts of all this earth;
tgt_text.3285: and I will now, as I before promised, tell of the boundaries of those three regions, how with their waters they lie to each other.
tgt_text.3286: Towards the middle of Asia, in the eastern part, lies the mouth of the river called Ganges, out in the ocean.
tgt_text.3287: This ocean is called the Indian.
tgt_text.3288: To the southward of that mouth, on the ocean is the port called Caligardamana.
tgt_text.3289: To the south-east of that port is the island Taprobane;
tgt_text.3290: and then to the north of the mouth of the Ganges, where mount Caucasus ends, near to the ocean, is the port of Samara;
tgt_text.3291: to the north of that port is the mouth of the river called Octorogorra.
tgt_text.3293: These are the boundaries of India:
tgt_text.3294: there mount Caucasus is to the north, the river Indus to the west, and the Red Sea to the south, and the ocean to the east.
tgt_text.3295: In the land of India are four-and-forty nations, besides the island of Taprobane, which has ten cities in it, besides many other inhabited islands.
tgt_text.3296: From the river Indus, which lies to the west of all that country, betwixt the river Indus, and the river to the west of it, called the Tigris, both which flow south into the Red Sea, are the countries of Aracosia, Parthia, Assyria, Persia, and Media, though writings often name all these lands Media or Assyria;
tgt_text.3297: and these lands are very mountainous 1, and there are very sharp and stony ways.
tgt_text.3298: The northern boundaries of those lands are at the mounts Caucasus, and on the south side the Red Sea;
tgt_text.3299: and in that country are two great rivers, the Hydaspes and the Arbis;

tgt_text.3304: Their north boundaries are the mounts Taurus and Caucasus, and their south boundaries lie on the Red Sea.

tgt_text.3307: Then to the north of Syria are the mountains called Taurus, and to the north of those mountains are the countries of Cappadocia and Armenia, and rmenia is to the east of Cappadocia, and to the west of Cappadocia is the country called the Lesser Asia, and to the north of Cappadocia is the plain called the Themiscyrian;

tgt_text.3311: and the Mediterranean is on the south.

tgt_text.3416: Eastland is very large, and there are init many towns, and in every town is a king;
tgt_text.3418: also a great quantity of honey and fishing, and the king and the richest men drink mares' milk, and the poor and the slaves drink mead.
tgt_text.3419: They have many contests amongst themselves, and there is no ale brewed among the Esthonians, for there is mead enough."
tgt_text.3420: And there is a custom among the Esthonians, that when any one is dead there, be lies unburnt with his relations and friends for a month, sometimes two, and the kings and other great men, as much longer as they have more wealth;
tgt_text.3421: sometimes it is half a year that they are unburnt, and lie above ground in their houses.
tgt_text.3422: And all the while that the corpse is in the house there are drinking and sports till the day on which it is burnt.
tgt_text.3423: Then the same day that they carry it to the pile, they divide his property which is left, after these drinking bouts and sports, into five or six, some­ times into more, according to the value of the property.
tgt_text.3424: They then lay the largest part about a mile from the dwell­ ing, then another, then a third, until it is all laid within the mile \ and the least portion must be nearest to the dwelling in which the dead man lies."
tgt_text.3425: Then shall be assembled all the men who have the swiftest horses in that country, that is, within five or six miles from the property.
tgt_text.3426: They then all run towards the property;
tgt_text.3427: then he who has the swiftest horse comes to the first and largest portion, and so each after other, till the whole is taken, and he takes the least portion who takes that which is nearest the dwelling, and then every one rides away with the pro­ perty, and they may have it all;
tgt_text.3428: and, on this account, swift horsesare there excessively dear.
tgt_text.3429: And when his wealth is thus dispersed, then they carry him out and burn him, with his weapons and clothes;
tgt_text.3430: and chiefly they spend the whole wealth of the deceased, by the dead man's (continuing so long in the house, and because they lay on the way that to which the strangers run and take."
tgt_text.3431: And it is a custom with the Esthonians, that people of ;
tgt_text.3433: and if any one finds a bone unconsumed, they must make compensation with a large sum.
tgt_text.3434: And there is among the Esthonians, a tribe that can produce cold, and therefore the dead, in whom they produce that cold, he so long there and do not putrefy;
tgt_text.3435: and if any one sets two vessels full of ale or water, they contrive that one shall be frozen, be it summer or be it winter.
tgt_text.3436: "Now will we speak concerning the south of the river Danube, about Greece.
tgt_text.3437: To the east of Constantinople, a Greek city, is the Propontis, and to the north of Constanti­ nople an arm of the sea issues due west from the sea called the Euxine to the westward, and to the north-west of that city, the mouth of the river Danube flows out south-east into the Euxine sea, and on the south side and west side of this mouth are the Mœsians, a Greek nation, to the west of that city are the Thracians, and to the east of that city the Mace­ donians ;
tgt_text.3438: and to the south of that city, on the south side of the arm of the sea called the Ægean, are the lands Athens and Corintb, and to the south-west of Corinth is the land of Achaia, near the Mediterranean.
tgt_text.3439: These countries are Greek nations, and to the west of Achaia, along the Mediterranean, is the land of Dalmatia;
tgt_text.3440: on the north side of that sea, and to the north of Dalmatia are Bulgaria and Istria, and to the south of Istria is the mediterranean sea called Adriatic;
tgt_text.3441: and to the west the mountains called Alps;
tgt_text.3442: and to the north that desert which is between Carinthia and L garia.
tgt_text.3443: Then is Italy long to the north-west and south-east, and the Mediterranean surrounds it on every side but the north- west.
tgt_text.3444: At that end it is inclosed by the mountains called Alps, which begin west from the Mediterranean in the Nar­ bonese country, and end east in the land of Dalmatia, at the sea, those lands that are called Gallia Belgica.
tgt_text.3445: To the east of it is the river called Rhine, and to the south the mountains called Alps, and to the south-west the ocean called the British, and to the north, on the other side of this arm of the ocean, is Britain.
tgt_text.3446: The land to the west of Liguria is Aquitaine;
tgt_text.3447: and to the south of Aquitaine is some part of the Narbonese country, and to the south-west is the land of Spain, and to the west of the ocean, to the south of the Narbonese, is the Mediterranean, where the river Rhone flows out, and to the east of it the Provence sea;
tgt_text.3448: and to the west of the Provence sea, over the wastes, is the nearer part of Spain, to the north-west of it Aquitaine, and Gascony to the north.
tgt_text.3449: The Provence sea has to the north of it the mountains called Alps, to the south of it is the Mediterranean, and to the north-east of it the Burgundi, and to the west the Gascons.
tgt_text.3450: The land of Spain is triangular, and all about surrounded with water, and also over the country inclosed either by the ocean or by the Mediterranean.
tgt_text.3451: And of the three angles one lies south-west opposite to the island called Cadiz;
tgt_text.3452: another east towards the land of the Narbonese;
tgt_text.3453: and the third north-west towards Brigantia, a town of Gaul, and towards Scotland, over the arm of the sea, and opposite to the mouth of the Seine.
tgt_text.3454: That [part of] Spain, which is farthest from us, has to the west and the north the ocean, the Mediterranean to the south and to the east.
tgt_text.3455: The [part of] Spain nearer to us has to the north Aquitaine, and to the north-east the wold [called] Pyreni, and to the east the Narbonese, and to the south the Mediterranean.
tgt_text.3456: The island of Britain is long towards the north-east, and it is eight hundred miles long and two hundred miles broad:
tgt_text.3457: then to the south of it, on one side of the arm of the sea, is Belgic Gaul, and on the west side, on the other side of the arm of the sea, is the island of Ireland, and on the north side the Orcades.
tgt_text.3458: Ireland, which we call Scotland, is sur­ rounded on every side by the ocean, and because it is nearer to the setting sun than any other country, the seasons are milder than in Britain.
tgt_text.3459: Then to the north-west of Ireland is that utmost land called Thule, which is known to few, on account of its distance.
tgt_text.3460: Now have we said concerning all the boundaries of Europe, how they are divided ;
tgt_text.3461: now we will [speak] of Africa, how those boundaries are divided.
tgt_text.3462: Our forefathers said that it was the third part of this earth;
tgt_text.3463: not because there was so much of this land, but because the Mediterranean has so separated it, because it breaks with greater force on the south part than it does on the north part;
tgt_text.3464: and theheat has con­ sumedmore of the south part than the cold of the north;
tgt_text.3465: becauseevery creature may withstand cold better than heat;
tgt_text.3466: for which reason Africa is less than Europe, both in lands and men.
tgt_text.3467: Africa, as we have before said, begins from the east west­ ward from Egypt at the river called Nile;
tgt_text.3468: and the most eastern nation is called Libya Garamantica;
tgt_text.3469: to the east of which is the [part] of Egypt nearest to us, and to the north the Mediterranean, which is called Libya AEthiopica, and to the west the Syrtes Majores.
tgt_text.3470: To the west of Libya Æthiopica is the farther Egypt, and to the south the ocean called Æthiopicum, and to the west of Rogathitus is the nation of Tripolitania, which is called by another name, Arzuges, this nation has to the east of it the Syrtes Majores, and the land of Rogathiti;
tgt_text.3471: to the north the mediterranean sea, which is called the Adriatic, and the nation called the Syrtes Minores;
tgt_text.3472: and to the west of Byzacium, to the salt mere;
