tgt_text.3473: and to the south of it the Natabres, Getuli, and Garamantes, to the sea of Byzacium.
tgt_text.3474: The principal sea-ports there are Hadnimetum and Zeuges, and the principal large town there is Carthage.
tgt_text.3475: And the - people of Numidia have to the east of them the country of the Syrtes Minores and the salt mere, and to the north of them is the Mediterranean, and to the west of them Mauri­ tania, and to the south of them the mountains of Uzara, and to the south of the mountains the ever-wandering Ethiopians, to the Mauritanian ocean.
tgt_text.3476: To the east of them is Numidia, and to the north the Mediterranean, and to the west is the river Malva, and to the south the Astrix, near the mountains which divide the fruitful country from the barren and welling sands, which lie south towards the Mauritanian ocean, which by another name is called the Tingetanian.
tgt_text.3477: To the east of it is the river Malva, to the north the mountains of Ab­ benis, and Calei, another mountain;
tgt_text.3478: there the end of the ocean flows between the two mountains eastward, where Hercules's pillars stand;
tgt_text.3479: and to the west of them is Mount Atlas, as far as the ocean ;
tgt_text.3480: and to the south the mountains called Hesperius, and to the south of them the nation of the Auloli, as far as the ocean.
tgt_text.3481: We have now said concerning the boundaries of Africa;
tgt_text.3482: we will now speak of the islands that are in the Mediter­ ranean.
tgt_text.3483: The island of Cyprus lies opposite to Cilicia and Isauria, on that arm of the sea called the Mesic;
tgt_text.3484: and it is a hundred and seventy-five miles long, and a hundred and twenty-two miles broad.
tgt_text.3485: To the east of the island of Crete is the sea called the Carpathian, and to the west and north the Cretan Sea, and to the west the Sicilian, which by another name is called the Adriatic;
tgt_text.3486: it is a hundred miles long, and a hundred and twenty miles broad.
tgt_text.3487: There are three-and-fifty of the islands called the Cyclades;
tgt_text.3488: and to the east of them is the Risca Sea, to the south the Cretan ;
tgt_text.3489: to the north the Ægean, and to the west the Adriatic.
tgt_text.3490: The island of Sicily is triangular, at each angle there are mountains;
tgt_text.3491: the north angle is called Pelorus, near which is the town of Mes­ sina ;
tgt_text.3492: and the south angle is called Pachytum, near to which is the city of Syracuse;
tgt_text.3493: and the west angle is called Lily­ bæum, near to which is the city called Lilybæum;
tgt_text.3494: and it is a hundred and fifty-seven miles long, south and north, and the third angle is a hundred and seventy-seven long west;
tgt_text.3495: and to the east is the mediterranean sea, called the Adriatic, and to the south of it the African, to the west the Tyrrhenian, and to the north the sea is both narrow and rough.
tgt_text.3496: Opposite to the land of Italy a small arm of the sea sepa­ rates Sardinia and Corsica, which is two-and-twenty miles broad;
tgt_text.3497: Sardinia is three-and-thirty miles long, and two-and- twenty miles broad;
tgt_text.3498: to the east of it, is [that part of] the Mediterranean called the Tyrrhenian Sea, into which the river Tiber runs;
tgt_text.3499: and to the south, the sea which lies oppo­ site to the land of Numidia;
tgt_text.3500: and to the west the two islands called the Balearic ;
tgt_text.3501: and to the north the island of Corsica.
tgt_text.3502: To the east of Corsica is the city of Rome, and Sardinia to the south, and on the west the Balearic islands, and the country of Tuscany to the north;
tgt_text.3503: it is sixteen miles long, and nine miles broad.
tgt_text.3504: Africa is to the south of the two Balearic islands, and Cadiz to the west, and Spain to the north.
tgt_text.3505: Thus have we now shortly spoken the positions of the islands that are in the Mediterranean Sea.
tgt_text.3506: Thirteen hundred years before the building of Rome, Ninus, king of Assyria, began first of men to reign in this world;
tgt_text.3507: and having great desire of power, he committed de­ vastations, and carried on wars for fifty years, till he had re­ duced all Asia to the south of the Red Sea into his power, and to the north as far as the Euxine.
tgt_text.3508: Not to mention that he likewise often invaded hostilely the north countries of Scythia, who are considered the hardiest men, although in the goods of this world they are the poorest.
tgt_text.3509: By his making war against them, however, they straightways became war­ like, although they had previously lived a life of innocence;
tgt_text.3510: and they paid him dearly afterwards for the art of war, which they had learned from him;
tgt_text.3511: and then it became as plea­ sant to their minds to see man's blood shed, as it was the milk of cows, on which they chiefly live.
tgt_text.3512: And Ninus over­ came and slew Zoroaster, king of Bactria, who first of men understood the magic arts, and and then at last he was fighting against the Scythians, against a town, and was there shot with an arrow ;
tgt_text.3513: and after his death his queen, Semiramis, succeeded both to the war and to the kingdom;
tgt_text.3514: and that same war which she had drawn on him by her manifold sinful passions, she carried on for two-and-forty years;
tgt_text.3515: and still the empire which Ninus had conquered appeared to her too small.
tgt_text.3516: But she, with feminine hate, made war on the inno­ cent Æthiopians, and also on the Indians, whom no one, neither before nor since, overran with war, except Alexander.
tgt_text.3517: She was very desirous to subdue them by war, although she could not effect it.
tgt_text.3518: Cupidity and wars were then fiercer than they now are, because they had no previous examples, as men now have, but had passed their lives in innocence.
tgt_text.3519: This same Queen Semiramis, after the empire was in her power, was not only constantly thirsting for human blood, but was also with boundless lust perpetrating manifold that titutions, so that every one of those she might hear of that was of royal race, she enticed to her for her lewdness, and afterwards deceived, and put them to death;
tgt_text.3520: and then at last took her own son to lie with her;
tgt_text.3521: and because she could not follow her sinful lusts without the reproach of men, she established throughout her realm that there should be no obstacle to intercourse between any relations.
tgt_text.3522: AA thousand and sixty years before the building of Rome the fruitful land on which Sodom and Gomorra stood was burnt by heavenly fire.
tgt_text.3523: It was between Arabia and Palestine those mam­ fold fruits were, because the river Jordan annually over­ flowed the midst of the country with a flood a foot thick, with which it was afterwards manured.
tgt_text.3524: Then was that na­ tion enjoying to the utmost this great prosperity, till enor­ mous sinful lust waxed within them, and for that sinful lust God's vengeance came on them, so that he burned the whole country with sulphureous fire;
tgt_text.3525: and afterwards water was standing over the land as the deluge had formerly overflowed it;
tgt_text.3526: and that part which the flood did not touch, is to this day fertile in every kind of fruit, and which are very fair and delightful to look upon;
tgt_text.3527: but when any one takes them into his hand, then they turn to ashes.
tgt_text.3528: In the year a thousand and seventy before the building of Rome, the Telchises and Carsathii began a war between them, and carried it on till they were all slain except a very few, and yet those of the Telchises who survived, abandoned their country, and went to the island of Rhodes, hoping that they had escaped from all war;
tgt_text.3529: but there the Greeks found them, and entirely destroyed them.
tgt_text.3530: Eight hundred years before the building of Rome there was a vast plenty, for seven years, in Egypt, and after that for the next seven years there was a terrible famine;
tgt_text.3531: and Joseph, a righteous man, much assisted them by the divine support.
tgt_text.3532: Of this Joseph, Pompeius, the heathen poet, and his servant, Justin, thus sang.
tgt_text.3533: Joseph was the youngest of his brethren, and also wiser than them all;
tgt_text.3534: so that his brethren, dreading him, took Joseph and sold him in the land of Egypt.
tgt_text.3535: Pompeius then said that he there learned magic, and through that magic was wont to work many wonders;
tgt_text.3536: that he could well interpret dreams, and also that he was beloved by Pharaoh, the king, for that craft:
tgt_text.3537: and he said that by magic he had learned heavenly wis­ dom, so that he foretold the seven years of fruitfulness, and the other seven years of famine which came after;
tgt_text.3538: and how he gathered in the first seven years, through his wisdom, so that in the second seven years he protected all the people against the great famine, and said that Moses was this Joseph's son, from whom he learned magic, because he wrought many wonders in Egypt.
tgt_text.3539: And on account of the plague which happened in that land, the poet says that the Egyptians drove Moses out with his people;
tgt_text.3540: because, said Pompeius and the Egyptian bishops, that those miracles of God which were performed in their land were done that they might be ascribed to their own gods, who are devils, not to the true God, because their own gods are teachers of magic.
tgt_text.3541: And that nation still follows that token of Joseph's ordinance, that is, that they every year give a fifth of the fruits of the earth to their king for a tax.
tgt_text.3542: This famine happened in the days of the king of Egypt, called Amasis;
tgt_text.3543: though it was their custom to call all their kings Pharaoh.
tgt_text.3544: At the same time King Baleus ruled in As­ syria, where Nimus had been previously.
tgt_text.3545: Over those people, who are called Argivi, King Apis ruled.
tgt_text.3546: In those days there were no governments of kings but in these three kingdoms ;
tgt_text.3547: but afterwards the example of them was [followed] over all the world.
tgt_text.3548: But is it to be wondered at, that the Egyptians showed so little gratitude to Joseph for having delivered them from famine, that they so quickly dishonoured his kin, and made them all their slaves.
tgt_text.3549: So, however, it still is in this world;
tgt_text.3550: though God permits every one to have his will for a long time, and he then suffer for a short time, he soon forgets the good which he had before, and remembers the evil which he then has.
tgt_text.3551: Eight hundred and ten years before the building of Rome, King Amphictyon reigned in Athens, a city of Greece.
tgt_text.3552: He was the third king that reigned after Cecrops, who was the first king of that city.
tgt_text.3553: In the time of this Amphictyon, there was so great a flood over the whole world, and particu­ larly in Thessaly, a Greek town, near the hills called Parnas- Bus, where King Deucalion reigned, that almost all the folk perished ;
tgt_text.3554: and the King Deucalion received and fed all those who fled to him for refuge in ships to the mountains.
tgt_text.3555: It was said of this Deucalion, as if told as a fable, that he was the parent of mankind, as Noah was.
tgt_text.3556: In those days there was the greatest plague in Ethiopia, a nation of Africa, so that few of them survived.
tgt_text.3557: In those days also it was, that Liber Pater subdued the innocent Indian people, and almost entirely destroyed them, either by drunkenness and sinful lusts, or slaughters;
tgt_text.3558: though after his day they held him for a god, and said he was ruler of all war.
tgt_text.3559: Eight hundred and five years before the foundation of Rome, it happened that Moses led the people of Israel out of Egypt, after the many miracles that he had performed there.
tgt_text.3560: The first was, that their water was turned to blood.
tgt_text.3561: The second was, that frogs came over the whole land of Egypt, so many that no one could do any work, nor prepare any meat, so that there were not reptiles as much as meat before it could be dressed.
tgt_text.3562: The third evil was, that gnats came over all the land, both within doors and without, with bites smarting like fire, and both men and cattle were un­ ceasingly pained.
tgt_text.3563: Then was the fourth, which was the most shameful of all, that dog-flies came over all that people, creeping between men's thighs, yea, over all their limbs ;
tgt_text.3564: so that it was also well fitting that God should humble the greatest pride with the most ignominious and most humi­ liating vengeance.
tgt_text.3565: The fifth was the plague of their cattle.
tgt_text.3566: The sixth was, that all the people had boils, which burst very virulently, and thence issued corruption.
tgt_text.3567: The seventh was, that hail came mixed with fire, which killed both men and cattle, yea, everything that waxed and grew on the land.
tgt_text.3568: The eighth was, that locusts came and devoured every blade of grass which was above the earth, yea, even gnawed off the grass and the roots.
tgt_text.3569: The ninth was, that hail came, and such great darkness, both by day and night, and so thick that it might be felt.
tgt_text.3570: The tenth was, that all the boys and all the maidens, who were the first-born in the land, were killed in one night ;
tgt_text.3571: and though that people would not before submit to God, yet they then, against their wills, were obedient to Him;
tgt_text.3572: as much as they before had forbidden Moses and his people to depart from Egypt, so much were they the more desirous that they should depart from them.
tgt_text.3573: But the re­ pentance which then came over them was very soon turned to worse thoughts.
tgt_text.3574: Quickly was the king, with his people, following after them, and would bring them back again to Egypt.
tgt_text.3575: King Pharaoh had six hundred war-chariots, and there were so- many of the other host, which may thence be known, when so many men dreaded them as were with Moses, that was six hundred thousand men.
tgt_text.3576: God, however, lessened the great multitude of Pharaoh, and humbled their excessive pride before Moses and his people, and dried up the Red Sea into twelve ways, so that they crossed that sea with dry feet.
tgt_text.3577: When the Egyptians saw that, their magicians, Geames and Mambres, encouraged them, and they trusted that by their sorceries they could cross over the same road;
tgt_text.3578: but when they were in the sea-road, they all sank and were drowned.
tgt_text.3579: The track is still known on the sea-shore where the wheels of their war-chariots passed.
tgt_text.3580: God does this as a token to all mankind, so that, though the wind or sea-flood cover it with sand, yet it will be again seen as plain as it was before.
tgt_text.3581: At that time was the very intense heat all over the world, so that not only men were sorely afflicted, but also all the cattle were very near perishing.
tgt_text.3582: And the southmost Ethiopians had burning in place of heat;
tgt_text.3583: and the Scythians, the most northern, had unusual heats.
tgt_text.3584: Then many unwise men uttered the opinion and falsehood, that the heat was not for their sins, but said that it was through the transformation of Phaeton, [who was only] a man!
tgt_text.3585: In the year six hundred and five before the building of Rome, fifty men were slain in Egypt in one night, all by their own sons, and all these men came from two brothers.
tgt_text.3586: When this was done, the brothers were yet living.
tgt_text.3587: The elder was named Danaus, who was the author of this evil.
tgt_text.3588: He was driven from his kingdom, and came a fugitive to the land of Argos, and there, Sthenelaus, the king, received him kindly, though he afterwards requited him with evil, when he expelled him from his kingdom.
tgt_text.3589: In those days it was the custom of the king, Busiris, in Egypt, that all strangers who resorted to him he sacrificed and offered to his gods.
tgt_text.3590: I would now, says Orosius, that those would answer me, who say, that this world is now worse, in this Christianity, than it was before in heathenism, when they were enacting such sacrifices and murders, as I have just now mentioned.
tgt_text.3591: Where is there now, in any [part of]
tgt_text.3592: Christendom, among themselves that men need to dread being sacrificed to any gods ?
tgt_text.3593: or where are our gods who desire such atrocities as those were ?
tgt_text.3594: In those days Perseus the king went from Greece into Asia with an army, and made war on that people until they were obedient to him ;
tgt_text.3595: and gave another name to the nation from himself, so that they were afterwards called Persians.
tgt_text.3596: I well know, says Orosius, that I shall here omit many things of this [time], and that those narratives which I shall relate, I shall shorten ;
tgt_text.3597: because the Assyrians, for 1160 years, under the reigns of fifty kings, were never without war, till Sardanapalus was slain, and the power was then trans­ ferred to the Medes.
tgt_text.3598: Who is there that can relate or enume­ rate all the evils that they did ?
tgt_text.3599: I will also pass by in silence the most abominable histories of Tantalus and Pelops;
tgt_text.3600: how many disgraceful wars Tantalus carried on after he was king, on account of the youth Ganymede, whom he forcibly took ;
tgt_text.3601: and how he sacrificed his own son to his gods, and afterwards prepared him for himself for food.
tgt_text.3602: It would weary me also to relate about Pelops, and about Dardanus, and about all the wars of the Trojans;
tgt_text.3603: because their wars are known in histories and in songs.
tgt_text.3604: I shall likewise omit all that has been said about Perseus and Cadmus, and also what has been said of the Thebans and Spartans.
tgt_text.3605: I will also pass in silence the crimes of the Lemnians, and of King Pandion, how cruelly he was driven from the Athenians, his own people;
tgt_text.3606: and of Atreus and Thyestes, how they slew their fathers, and about their execrable lusts, I shall omit it all;
tgt_text.3607: I shall also here omit Oedipus, how he slew both his own father and his step­ father, and his stepson.
tgt_text.3608: In those days there was such enor­ mous evil that men said that the stars of heaven flew from their wickedness.
tgt_text.3609: In the year six hundred and sixty before the foundation of Rome, happened that exceedingly great fight between the Cretans and Athenians, and the Cretans had a bloody victory, and they took all the noblest children of the Athenians, and gave them to the Minotaur to be eaten, which was half man half lion.
tgt_text.3610: In those days it was that the Lapithæ and Thessa­ lians warted with each other.
tgt_text.3611: When the Lapithæ saw the Thessalians fighting against them on horseback, they called them Centaurs, that is half horse half man;
tgt_text.3612: because they had never before seen fighting on horseback.
tgt_text.3613: "Four hundred and eighty years before the building of Rome, Vesoges, king of Egypt, carried on a war in the south part of Asia, till most of it was subjected to him;
tgt_text.3614: and he, Vesoges, king of Egypt, afterwards marched with an army into the north parts, into Scythia, and sent his ambassadors before him to that nation, and commanded them to say un­ equivocally, that they should either redeem that land from him, or he would ruin and desolate them with war.
tgt_text.3615: They thereupon discreetly answered him, and said, that it was wicked and unjust, that so highly exalted a king should make war on so poor a nation as they were.
tgt_text.3616: They, how­ ever, bade that answer to be given him:
tgt_text.3617: that it was more agreeable to them to fight against him than to pay him tri­ bute.
tgt_text.3618: That they made good, and soon put the king with his people to flight;
tgt_text.3619: and pursued him and laid all Egypt waste, except the fen-lands alone.
tgt_text.3620: And as they returned home­ wards, on the west of the river Euphrates, they compelled all Asia to pay tribute to them, and they were there plunder­ ing and ravaging that country for fifteen years, till their wives sent messengers after them, and said to them that they must do one or the other, either return home, or they would choose other husbands.
tgt_text.3621: They then left that country and went home­ wards.
tgt_text.3622: At that same time two princes were expelled from Scythia, their names were Plenus and Scolopythus, and proceeded to and ruled the country between Cappadocia and Pontus, near to the Lesser Asia, and there carried on war till they took their habitation there, and there in a short time were slain by the country people by treachery.
tgt_text.3623: Then were their wives so sorrowful in their minds, and so afflicted, both the wives of the two princes, as well as of the other men who were slain with them, that they took arms to avenge their husbands, and soon afterwards killed all the males nearest to them.
tgt_text.3624: They did so, because they would that the other wives should be as sorry as they, that they might then have support in them, that they might better avenge their husbands.
tgt_text.3625: All these wives then combined together, and carried on the war against the people and slew the males of the country, until they had much of the country in their power.
tgt_text.3626: Then during the war, they made peace with the males.
tgt_text.3627: Afterwards it was their custom every year or twelve month to come together, and there then to beget children.
tgt_text.3628: Then, when the women had brought forth their children, they fed the maiden-children, and slew the male children;
tgt_text.3629: and of the maiden-children they burned off the right breast, that it might not grow, that they might have the stronger shooting power;
tgt_text.3630: therefore they were called in Greek, Amazonas, that is English burned!.
tgt_text.3631: Two of these were their queens;
tgt_text.3632: their names were Marpesia and Lampedo.
tgt_text.3633: They divided their army into two;
tgt_text.3634: one [part] to be at home to defend the land, the other to go out to war.
tgt_text.3635: They afterwards overran the greatest part of Europe and Asia, and built the city of Ephesus, and many others in the Lesser Asia, and afterwards sent home the greater part of their army, with their booty, and left the other part there, to keep possession of the country.
tgt_text.3636: There was the queen Marpesia slain, and many of the army that remained behind with her.
tgt_text.3637: Then was queen her daughter, Sinope, that same Queen Sinope, who in addition to her bravery and manifold virtues, ended her life in maidenhood.
tgt_text.3638: In those days there was so great dread from those women, that neither Europe, nor Asia, nor all the nations near could devise or resolve how they might withstand them, till they chose the giant Hercules, to overreach them with every kind of Grecian cunning.
tgt_text.3639: And yet he durst not venture to in­ vade them with an army before he had commenced with ( those Grecian ships, which are called dulmunsl, of which it is said that one ship may contain a thousand men, and then stole upon them in the night unawares, and slew and de­ stroyed vast numbers of them;
tgt_text.3640: and yet he could not take the country from them.
tgt_text.3641: In those days there were two queens, who were sisters, Antiope and Orithyia, and Orithyia was taken prisoner.
tgt_text.3642: After her Penthesilea succeeded to the king­ dom, who gained great glory in the Trojan war.
tgt_text.3643: It is shameful, says Orosius, to speak about such [a state of things] as was, when such miserable women [and so foreign] had subdued the most powerful part and the bravest men of all this earth:
tgt_text.3644: that was, Asia and Europe they well nigh totally prostrated, and destroyed old cities and old towns;
tgt_text.3645: and after that they sought royal realms, and built new cities, and turned the whole world according to their will, for very near one hundred years, and so accustomed men were to every calamity, that they almost accounted it no evil that they so tormented them.
tgt_text.3646: And now the Goths came from the bravest men of Germany, of whom Pyrrhus, the fierce king of Greece, and Alexander, and the powerful Julius, all stood in dread, lest they should seek them in warfare.
tgt_text.3647: How immoderately ye Romans murmur, and complain that ye are now worse in this Christianity than those Gentiles were;
tgt_text.3648: because the Goths have plundered you a little, and taken your city, and slain a few of you;
tgt_text.3649: and by their crafts and bravery might have had dominion over you in your own de­ spite;
tgt_text.3650: who now ardently pray you for a tranquil peace, and some portion of land, that they be of aid to you;
tgt_text.3651: which land previously lay sufficiently unoccupied and sufficiently waste, and ye had no enjoyment of it.
tgt_text.3652: How blindly many people speak about Christianity:
tgt_text.3653: that it is worse now than it was before, and will not or cannot call to mind where it happened before Christianity, that any nation voluntarily sued another for peace, without having need of it, or where any nation could obtain peace from another, either with gold or with silver, or with any money, without being subjected to it.
tgt_text.3654: But since Christ was born, who is the peace and love of all the earth, not only might men redeem themselves from thraldom with money, but nations also were at peace with each other, without slavery.
tgt_text.3655: Now, think what peace men had before Christianity, when their women did so much evil on this earth.
tgt_text.3656: Four hundred and thirty years before the building of Rome, it happened that Alexander, son of Priam, king of the city of Troy, took Helen, the wife of Menelaus, king of Lacedæmon, a Greek city.
tgt_text.3657: For her was that long war and those great battles between the Greeks and Trojans, such that the Greeks had a thousand ships of those great dulmuns, and had sworn among them that they would never return to their country ere they had avenged their wrongs ;
tgt_text.3658: and they were ten years investing the city, and fighting.
tgt_text.3659: Who is there that can number the human beings that perished on each side ?
tgt_text.3661: Homer the poet has most manifestly said:
tgt_text.3662: there­ fore, says Orosius, there is no need for me to say it, because it is long, and also known to many;
tgt_text.3663: though whoever desires to know it, let him read in his books what mishaps and what sacrifices, either by slaughter, or by hunger, or by shipwrecks, and by various vicissitudes, as it is said in histories.
tgt_text.3664: These nations continued at war between them for full ten years.
tgt_text.3665: [Let any one] think then of those times, and now of these, which he likes best.
tgt_text.3666: Immediately after that war another ensued.
tgt_text.3667: Eneas with his army went from the Trojan war to Italy.
tgt_text.3668: It may also be seen in books, how many wars and how many battles he was there engaged in,Sixty-four years before Rome was built, King Sardanapalus reigned in Assyria, where King Ninus had first ruled, and Sardanapulus was the last king that reigned in that land.
tgt_text.3669: He was a very wonderful man, very effeminate, and very libi­ dinous, so that he more loved the manners of women than of men.
tgt_text.3670: When his viceroy Arbaces, whom he had set over the land of the Medes, found this, he began to plot with the people, over whom he was, how he might deceive him and entice from him all those who he feared would be a support to him.
tgt_text.3671: When the king found that he had been deceived, he burned himself, and the Medes then had sway over the Assyrians.
tgt_text.3672: It is not easy to say how many wars there were afterwards between the Medes, and Chaldeans, and Scy­ thians ;
tgt_text.3673: but any one may easily know that, when such im­ mense kingdoms were excited, how many various slaughters happened in that warfare.
tgt_text.3674: After this, King Phraortes reigned in Media;
tgt_text.3675: after Phra­ ortes, Deioces reigned, who greatly increased the empire of the Medes;
tgt_text.3676: after Deioces, Astyages succeeded to the kingdom, who had no son, but he adopted his nephew, called Cyrus, a Persian by nation, who, when he grew up, both he and the Persians taking it ill that they were under the dominion of his uncle and the Medes, raised up a war.
tgt_text.3677: King Astyages then chiefly bethought him of Harpagus, his general, that he with his power might withstand his nephew in war;
tgt_text.3678: for the king did not remember the wrongs which one had formerly done to the other;
tgt_text.3679: and how the king had com­ manded his son to be slain, and afterwards to be prepared as food for his father.
tgt_text.3680: Though their enmity was then appeased, he, the general, having gone with an army against the Persians, soon taking to flight, completely be­ trayed the greater portion of the people, and treacherously delivered them into the power of the Persian king, and in that battle the power and valour of the Medes fell.
tgt_text.3681: When the king discovered the guile that the general had used against him, he, nevertheless, collected what force he could, and led his army against his nephew.
tgt_text.3682: And Cyrus, king of Persia, had a third part of his army behind him, in order that, if any one fled who was in the battle, towards the people that were behind, they should slay him as readily as they would their enemies.
tgt_text.3683: When, never­ theless, it happened that they inclined somewhat to flee, their wives, running towards them, were highly incensed, and asked, if they durst not fight, whither they would flee;
tgt_text.3684: that they had no other place of refuge, unless they would pass into the wombs of their wives.
tgt_text.3685: They then quickly, after their wives had so reproachfully addressed them, turned again against the king, and put to flight all his army, and took himself prisoner.
tgt_text.3686: Cyrus then gave up to the king, his uncle, all the possessions he had previously had, except that he was not [longer] king;
tgt_text.3687: and he renounced all that, be­ cause his general, Harpagus, had deceived him with his own people;
tgt_text.3688: but Cyrus, his nephew, gave him to rule over the land of Hyrcania.
tgt_text.3689: Then was ended the power of the Medes, and Cyrus, with the Persians, succeeded to the sovereignty;
tgt_text.3690: but the cities, which, in many countries, previously had paid tribute to the Medes, cost Cyrus many wars.
tgt_text.3691: In those days a certain prince aspired to reign in the country of Agrigentum, who was named Phalaris;
tgt_text.3692: he was of the land of Sicily, and destroyed the people with unheard-of torments in order to make them submit to him.
tgt_text.3693: There was at that time a brass-founder there who could make various likenesses, and this founder offered to the prince, thinking to please him, that he would assist him in the torments he was inflicting on the people.
tgt_text.3694: And he did so, and wrought in brass the likeness of a bull, in order that when it was hot, and when the miserable men were thrown into it, [he might hear] how great the cry would be, when they were suffering torment in it, and also that the prince might have both his di­ version and his will, when he heard the torments of the men.
tgt_text.3695: When it was heated, and all done as the founder had previously directed the prince, the prince looked at it, and said, That no one was better fitted first to make trial of the work than the workman who made it.
tgt_text.3696: He ordered him then to be seized, and shoved into it.
tgt_text.3697: Why do men now complain of these Christian times, and say that now times are worse than those were;
tgt_text.3698: when, although any one were with those kings doing evil at their desire, they might not yet find any mercy from them ?
tgt_text.3699: And now, kings and emperors, though any one sin against their will, yet, for love of God, grant forgiveness ac­ cording to the degree of guilt.
tgt_text.3700: Thirty years before the building of Rome, it was that the Peloponnesians and Athenians, nations of Greece, carried on war with each other with all their powers, and so many were slain on each side, that few of them remained.
tgt_text.3701: At the same time the women, who were formerly in Scythia, again, a second time, made war on Asia, and greatly laid it waste and ravaged it.
tgt_text.3702: Twenty years before the building of Rome, the Lacedæ­ monians and Messenians, Greek people, were at war with each other for twenty years;
tgt_text.3703: because the Messenians would not permit the Spartan virgins to make offerings with theirs and sacrifice to their gods.
tgt_text.3704: When at last they had drawn all the Grecian people into those wars, the Lacedæmonians be­ sieged the town of Messena for ten years, and swore oaths, that they never would return home, till they had avenged it.
tgt_text.3705: Then they consulted together, and said, that they should very soon be helpless on the part of their families, as they thought of being there so long, and had bound themselves by their pledges, and that they were rather doing better for their enemies than worse.
tgt_text.3706: They determined, therefore, that those who were not at those oaths, should return home and beget children on all their wives, and the others should be­ siege the town, till they had conquered it;
tgt_text.3707: although they were but a little while obedient to them.
tgt_text.3708: But they chose them an Athenian poet for king, and again marched with an army against the Messenians.
tgt_text.3709: When they approached them, they doubted whether they could go against them.
tgt_text.3710: Their king then began to sing, and make verses, and with his poetry so greatly confirmed their courage, that they said they should be able to oppose the Messenians.
tgt_text.3711: Yet few were left on either side, and the Grecian nation suffered for many years among themselves, either from the Lacedæmonians, or the Messenians, or the Bœotians, or the Athenians, and drew many other nations into that same war.
tgt_text.3712: Now it has been shortly said, what happened before the building of Rome, that was from the beginning of the world four thousand four hundred and eighty-two years;
tgt_text.3713: and after it had been built seven hundred and ten years, was the na­ tivity of our Lord.
tgt_text.3714: Here ends the first book, and begins the second.
tgt_text.3715: I SUPPOSE, said Orosius, that there is no wise man but full well knows that God created the first man just and good, and all mankind with him;
tgt_text.3716: and because he forsook the good which was given to him, and chose worse, God slowly avenged it, first on himself, and afterwards on his children, through­ out all this world with manifold miseries and wars, yea, also of this earth, by which all living creatures live, he diminished the fruitfulness.
tgt_text.3717: Now we know that our Lord created us, we know also that he is our ruler, and with all righteous­ ness loves us more than any man.
tgt_text.3718: Now we know that all powers are from him, we know also that all kingdoms are fromhim, because all powers are derived from a kingdom.
tgt_text.3719: Now he is the ruler of the smaller kingdoms, how much more may we think that he is over the greater, which ruled over such immense powers ?
tgt_text.3720: One was the Babylonian, where Ninus reigned;
tgt_text.3721: the second was the Greek, where Alexander ruled ;
tgt_text.3722: the third was the African, where the Ptolemies ruled;
tgt_text.3723: the fourth is the Roman, who are still ruling.
tgt_text.3724: These four princi­ pal empires are at the four ends of this earth by the ineffable dispensation of God.
tgt_text.3725: The Babylonian was the first and east­ ward ;
tgt_text.3726: the second was the Grecian and to the northward;
tgt_text.3727: the third was the African and to the southward;
tgt_text.3728: the fourth is the Roman and to the westward.
tgt_text.3729: The Babylonian the first, and the Roman the last, were as father and son, when they could well command their will;
tgt_text.3730: the Grecian and the African were as though they obeyed them and were subordinate to them.
tgt_text.3731: That I will also more distinctly explain, that it may be the better understood.
tgt_text.3732: The first king was called Ninus, as we before said;
tgt_text.3733: and when he was slain, Semiramis, his queen, succeeded to the kingdom, and built the city of Babylon, that it might be the capital of all Assyria;
tgt_text.3734: and it so continued many years after, till Arbatus, a prefect of the Medes, slew Sardanapalus, king of Babylon.
tgt_text.3735: Then was the power of the Babylonians and Assyrians ended, and devolved on the Medes.
tgt_text.3736: In that same year that this happened Procas, father of Numitor, began to reign in the land of Italy, where Rome was afterwards built.
tgt_text.3737: This Procas was the father of Numitor and Amulius, and was uncle to Silvia.
tgt_text.3738: Silvia was the mother of Remus and Romulus, who built Rome.
tgt_text.3739: That I will declare, that those kingdoms were not rendered so mighty by the powers of any man nor through any fate, but by God's dispensation.
tgt_text.3740: All historians say, that the Assyrian empire began with Ninus, and the Roman empire with Procas.
tgt_text.3741: From the first year of Ninus's empire till Babylon was built, were sixty- four years ;
tgt_text.3742: also from the same year that Procas reigned in Italy were likewise sixty-four years before Rome was founded.
tgt_text.3743: That same year, in which the Roman empire began to flourish and increase, in the days of Procas the king, in that same year Babylon and all the Assyrian empire and their power fell.
tgt_text.3744: After their king Sardanapalus was slain, the Chaldeans had inhabited those lands in freedom which were nearest to the city, though the Medes had sway over them, till Cyrus, king of Persia, began to reign, and laid waste all Babylonia and all Assyria, and reduced all the Medes under the Persian power.
tgt_text.3745: It then so happened, that at the same time in which Babylonia received servitude from Cyrus, the Romans were delivered from servitude to their most unrighteous, and most proud kings, who were called Tarquins ;
tgt_text.3746: and when the east empire in Assyria fell, then also the west empire of the Romans arose.
tgt_text.3747: I shall yet, says Orosius, more fully speak against those who say that powers are from the influences of fate, not from the dispensation of God.
tgt_text.3748: How similarly it befel with regard to these two chief em­ pires, the Assyrian and the Roman!
tgt_text.3749: as we before said, that Ninus reigned in the east empire two and fifty years;
tgt_text.3750: and after him his queen Semiramis two and forty years;
tgt_text.3751: and in the middle of her reign she built the city of Babylon.
tgt_text.3752: From the year in which it was built, its empire continued nearly eleven hundred and sixty-four years, before it was deprived of its power and overthrown by Arbatus, their own prefect, and king of the Medes;
tgt_text.3753: though afterwards, around the city, for a little while, there was freedom without dominion, as we before said, under the Chaldean nation.
tgt_text.3754: And so in like manner was Rome about a thousand one hundred and nearly fouryears, when Alaric, her count, and king of the Goths, would deprive her of her power, and yet she continued after that unbroken in her dominion.
tgt_text.3755: Although both of these cities, through God's secrets, were thus distinguished;
tgt_text.3756: first Babylon by her own prefect, when he deceived her king, so also Rome, when her own count and king of the Goths would deprive her of power ;
tgt_text.3757: yet God, on account of their Chris­ tianity, would not permit it, not for their Cæsars nor on their own account:
tgt_text.3758: but they are now yet ruling with their Chris­ tianity and their power, and with their Caesars.
tgt_text.3759: This I say now because I am desirous that those may un­ derstand who inveigh against these times of our Christianity, what mercy there was after Christianity was, and how mani­ fold was the world's calamity before that was;
tgt_text.3760: and also that they may know how fitly our God in those early times established those dominions and those realms, the same who yet establishes them and turns every power and every realm to his will;
tgt_text.3761: how like a beginning those two cities had, and how alike were their days, both in good and in evil:
tgt_text.3762: but the ends of their power, however, were very unlike;
tgt_text.3763: for the Babylonians, with their manifold unrighteousnesses, and sin­ ful lusts, together with their king, were living without any repentance, so that they would not amend before God had humbled them with the greatest ignominy, when he deprived them both of their king and their power.
tgt_text.3764: But the Romans, with their Christian king, served God, so that he granted them both their king and their power.
tgt_text.3765: Therefore may those moderate their speech who are adversaries of Christianity, if they will recollect the uncleanness of their forefathers, and their calamitous wars, and their manifold dissensions, and their cruelty, which they had to God and also between them­ selves, so that they would perform no mercy, before the atone­ ment of Christianity came, which they now vehemently re­ proach.
tgt_text.3766: About four hundred and forty years after the destruction of Troy, the Greek city, Rome was built by two brothers, Remus and Romulus, and Romulus soon afterwards defiled­ their undertaking witH his brother's slaughter, and also after­ wards with the marriage of himself and his associates.
tgt_text.3767: What examples he there set, when they asked the Sabine towns­ men to give them their daughters for wives, and they refused their prayer;
tgt_text.3768: yet they got them against their will by treachery, whilst they intreated their assistance that they might the more easily sacrifice to their gods;
tgt_text.3769: when they had complied with this, they took them for wives, and would not restore them to their fathers !
tgt_text.3770: On account of that there was a very great war for many a year, until they were almost all slain and destroyed on either side, so that they could not by any means be reconciled, before the wives of the Romans with their children ran amongst the combatants, and fell at their fathers' feet.
tgt_text.3771: and intreated, that for love of their children they would put an end to the war.
tgt_text.3772: So worthily and so mildly was the city of Rome first hallowed with the blood of a brother and of their fathers-in-law, and.
tgt_text.3773: of Romulus's grandfather, Numitor, whom he also slew whilst he was king, and himself succeeded to the kingdom!
tgt_text.3774: Thus did Romulus at first bless the empire o Rome:
tgt_text.3775: the wall with his brother's blood, and the temples with the blood of their fathers-in-law, and the kingdom with his grandfather's;
tgt_text.3776: and afterwards treacherously put to death his own father-in- law, when he enticed him to him and promised to divide his kingdom with him, and under that [pretext] slew him.
tgt_text.3777: After this, Romulus made war against the Cæninenses, because he had as yet little land-dominion, but only the city.
tgt_text.3778: The Ro­ mans were despised by other nations, because in their boy­ hood they had been slaves to others.
tgt_text.3779: Now when they had besieged the town of Cænina, and were suffering greatly from hunger, they said that they had rather end their lives in those miseries, than abandon the war, or accept peace.
tgt_text.3780: They then continued the war there, till they took the town, and after that they warred incessantly with the people of the country on every side, till they had acquired many cities thereabout.
tgt_text.3781: But the kings who reigned after Romulus, were more de­ praved and wicked than he was, and more hateful and noxious to the people ;
tgt_text.3782: till Tarquin, of whom we have before spoken, who was the most detestable of them all, the most depraved, the most libidinous, the proudest.
tgt_text.3783: He debauched all the Ro­ man women that he could, and allowed his son to lie with Collatinus's wife, named Lucretia, the sister of Brutus, while they were engaged in war, although they were the mostillustrious of the Romans [next] to the king1.
tgt_text.3784: For this Lucretia then killed herself.
tgt_text.3785: When Collatinus, her bus­ band, and Brutus, her brother, heard this, they left the army which they were appointed to command, and when they came home they drove both the king and his son, and all there who were of royal race, altogether from the king­ dom.
tgt_text.3786: After this the Romans appointed under-leaders, whom they called Consuls, who should hold the government, one year one man.
tgt_text.3787: After that the city of Rome had been built two hundred and four years, Brutus was the first consul.
tgt_text.3788: Romulus, their first king, and Brutus, their first consul, were equally cruel.
tgt_text.3789: Romulus slew his brother, and his grandfather, and his father-in-law ;
tgt_text.3790: Brutus slew his five sons and his wife's two brothers, because they said it would be better that the Ro­ mans received their royal race again, as they had before.
tgt_text.3791: For this he ordered them to be bound and scourged with rods, before all the people, and then to have their heads cut off with axes.
tgt_text.3792: Tarquin then, who had before been king of the Romans, induced the king of the Etruscans, named Porsena, to assist him, that he might the more easily make war against Brutus and against all the Romans.
tgt_text.3793: Brutus then offered single combat against the king for their enmity ;
tgt_text.3794: but Tarquin sent against him another officer, Aruns the son of the proud [tyrant], and each of these there slew the other.
tgt_text.3795: After­ wards the kings, Porsena and Tarquin, besieged Rome, and they would also have taken it, if it had not been for Mucius, a man of the city;
tgt_text.3796: he terrified them with his words when they had taken him prisoner.
tgt_text.3797: They then tortured him by burning his hand, one finger after another, and commanded him to say how many men there were of those who had most strongly declared against king Tarquin.
tgt_text.3798: When he would not say that, they asked him how many of such men as he was there were ?
tgt_text.3799: Then said he to them, that there were many of those men, and who had also sworn either to lose their own lives, or to kill king Porsena.
tgt_text.3800: When Porsena heard that, he aban­ doned the siege, and the war altogether, which he had been carrying on for three years.
tgt_text.3801: After that was the Sabine war, which the Romans greatly dreaded, and decreed that they would have one leader, who should be above their consul, whom they called a Dictator, and with that dictator they had a great victory.
tgt_text.3802: After this the Romans among themselves, the rich men and the poorer, raised a great war, and which would have come to a length­ ened vengeance, if they had not quickly been reconciled.
tgt_text.3803: In those days were the greatest misfortunes on the'Romans, both by famine and pestilence, under the two consuls, called Titus and Publius;
tgt_text.3804: and they rested the while from their battles, though they could not from the hunger and the plague;
tgt_text.3805: but these manifold miseries continued to afflict the distressed city.
tgt_text.3806: Before the pestilence was ended, the Veientes and Etrusci raised up war against the Romans, and against the two con­ suls, Marcus and Gneus ;
tgt_text.3807: and the Romans marched against them, and swore oaths among themselves that none of them would again seek their country, unless they had victory.
tgt_text.3808: There were the Romans so terribly slaughtered, though they had the victory, that the one of their consuls who was left refused the triumph, which was brought to meet him, when he returned homewards, and said that they would have done better to have met him with lamentation than with a triumph.
tgt_text.3809: What they called a triumph, that was when they had over­ come any people in war, it was then their custom that after the war all their senators should meet their consuls six miles from the city with a chariot, ornamented with gold and precious stones, and should bring four-footed [cattle], two of them white, when they proceeded homewards:
tgt_text.3810: then should their senators ride in chariots behind the consuls, and drive before them the men that had been captured, that their glory might be the grander.
tgt_text.3811: But when they had reduced any nation under their power without fighting, when they were on their return home, then they were met by a chariot ornamented with silver, and one of every kind of four-footed cattle, in honour to their consuls.
tgt_text.3813: Romulus, first of men, esta­ blished the senate, that was a hundred men, although after a time there were three hundred of them.
tgt_text.3814: These always dwelt within the city of Rome, that they might be their counsellors, and appoint the consuls, and that all the Romans might obey them, and that they might have the care of all the treasure under one roof, which they got either by taxes or from plun­ der, that they might afterwards employ it in common for the benefit of all who were not in a state of slavery.
tgt_text.3815: The consuls, who in those days undertook the Sabine war, were of the race, all of which were called the Fabian, because it was the most eminent of all the Romans, and the most strenuous.
tgt_text.3816: Now yet to this day it is sung in ballads what a loss they were to the Romans.
tgt_text.3817: Many rivers, too, are named after their name, on account of that contest, and also the gates, out of which they went from Rome to that war, have ever since borne the names which they yet have.
tgt_text.3818: After this the Romans chose three hundred and six champions, who should go to combat so many, Sabines, trusting that they with their might would gain the victory;
tgt_text.3819: but the Sabines, with their stratagems, slew them all save one, who announced the sad tidings at home.
tgt_text.3820: Not alone among the Romans, but, as it is sung in poems, throughout all the world, there was card, and war, and terror.
tgt_text.3821: Cyrus, the king of the Persians, as we before said, while the Sabines and Romans were warring in the west, was at the same time warring both.
tgt_text.3822: in Scythia and in India, until he had laid waste almost all the eastern parts, and afterwards led an army to Babylon, which was then more opulent than any other city;
tgt_text.3823: lout the river Gyndes long prevented his crossing, because here were no ships there.
tgt_text.3824: That is of all fresh waters the greatest except the Euphrates.
tgt_text.3825: Then one of his officers declared that he would cross the river by swim­ ming with two " tyncens," but the stream carried him away.
tgt_text.3826: Cyrus then threatened that he would so avenge his officer on it (as he was so exasperated in his mind and angry with the river), that women might wade over it, [the water only reach­ ing] to their knees, where it before was nine miles broad, when it was flood.
tgt_text.3827: That he made good by deeds, and drew it off in four hundred and sixty rivers, and then with his army crossed over, and afterwards the river Euphrates, which is the greatest of all fresh waters, and runs through the middle of the city of Babylon:
tgt_text.3828: this he also by digging drew off into many rivers, and afterwards with all his folk proceeded in the bed of the river on to the city and took it.
tgt_text.3829: So incredible is it for any man to say how any man could build such a city as that was, or again capture it!
tgt_text.3830: Nimrod the giant first began to build Babylon, and Ninus the king after him, and Semiramis, his queen, finished it after him in the middle of her kingdom.
tgt_text.3831: The city was built on the campaign land and on very level [ground], and it was very fair to look on, and was very exactly quadrangular, and the magnitude and strength of the wall is incredible to say, that is, that it is fifty ells broad, and two hundred ells high, and its circuit is seventy miles and one seventh of a mile, and it is wrought of bricks and bitumen, and round the wall is an immense ditch, in which runs a most unfordable stream;
tgt_text.3832: and without the ditch a wall is constructed two ells high;
tgt_text.3833: and above the great wall, over all the circumference, it is beset with stone towers.
tgt_text.3834: This same city of Babylon, which was the greatest and first of all cities, is now the least and most desolate.
tgt_text.3835: Now is the city that whilom was the strong­ est and most wondrous, and greatest of all works, like as if it were set as an example to all the earth, and also as if it were speaking to all mankind, and saying:
tgt_text.3836: “ Now I am thus fallen and passed away, something ye may learn and know from me:
tgt_text.3837: that ye have nothing with yourselves that is firm or strong that can continue.
tgt_text.3838: "In those days that Cyrus the king of Persia took Babylon, Crœsus the king of Lydia marched with an army to aid Babylon.
tgt_text.3839: But when he found that he could be of no help to them, and that the city was taken, he turned homewards to his own kingdom, and Cyrus followed him until he took him prisoner, and slew him.
tgt_text.3840: And now our Christian Rome announces that her walls are decaying from age, not because she has been so maltreated by hostile ravages as Babylon was;
tgt_text.3841: for she, for her Christianity, is yet shielded, so that both herself and her power are falling more from age than by the violence of any king.
tgt_text.3842: After that Cyrus led an army into Scythia, and there a young king encountered him, together with his mother, Tomyris.
tgt_text.3843: When Cyrus marched over the frontier, over the river called the Araxis, the young king could there have prevented his crossing, but he would not, because he trusted that with his folk he might circumvent him, after he was within the con­fines, and had fixed his camp.
tgt_text.3844: But when Cyrus was informed that the young king would seek him there, and also that po­ tations of wine were uncommon and unknown to the people, he marched away from his encampment into a secret place, and left behind all that was delicate and sweet;
tgt_text.3845: so that the young king imagined much more that they were fleeing thence, than that they durst plan any deceit.
tgt_text.3846: When they found it so deserted there, they then with great joy drank the wine without moderation, until they had little power over them­ selves.
tgt_text.3847: Cyrus then there entrapped them, and slew the whole of them, and then marched to where the king's mother with two parts of the people was staying, when he had de­ ceived the third part, with the king.
tgt_text.3848: She then, the queen Tomyris, was with great lamentation thinking of the death of the king her son, [and] how she might avenge it, and also made that good by deeds, and divided her people in two, both women and males;
tgt_text.3849: because there the women fight the same as the males.
tgt_text.3850: She [then] with the half part went before the king as if she were fleeing, until she had led him on to a great swamp, while the [other] half was following Cyrus.
tgt_text.3851: There was Cyrus slain and two [hundred] thousand men with him.
tgt_text.3852: The queen then commanded the king's head to be cut off and cast into a leathern vessel that was filled with man's blood, and thus said:
tgt_text.3854: Thou who hast been thirsting after man's blood for thirty years, drink now thyAfter the city of Rome had been built two hundred and six years, Cambyses, the son of Cyrus, succeeded to the king­ dom of Persia, who, when he had conquered Egypt, did what no heathen king before durst do, that was, that he disowned all their idols, and afterwards totally destroyed them.
tgt_text.3855: After him Darius reigned, who reduced all the Assyrians and Chal­ deans again under the Persians, who had previously with­ drawn from them.
tgt_text.3856: After that he made war on Scythia, both on account of the slaying of Cyrus his kinsmen, and also be­ cause they had refused him the wife [he desired].
tgt_text.3857: His army was seven hundred thousand when he marched to Scythia;
tgt_text.3858: however, the Scythians would not engage with him in a general battle, but when they (the Persians) were dispersed over the country, they then slew them in swarms.
tgt_text.3859: The Per­ sians were thereby greatly terror-stricken, and also dreaded lest they should destroy the bridge which was on the boun­ dary, so that they might not know how to escape from thence.
tgt_text.3860: The king then, after his people had been much slaughtered, left there eighty thousand behind him, that they might yet longer carry on the war there, and himself departed thence into the Lesser Asia, and laid it waste, and afterwards into Macedonia and Ionia, Greek nations, and ravaged both of them;
tgt_text.3861: and afterwards went further into Greece, and raised a war against the Athenians, because they had aided the Macedonians.
tgt_text.3862: As soon as the Athenians knew that Darius would make war on them, they chose eleven thousand men, and marched against him, and found the king at the moun­ tain that is called Marathon.
tgt_text.3863: Their leader was named Theseus, who was bolder in his deeds than [in proportion to] the power he had.
tgt_text.3864: He gained great glory in that battle :
tgt_text.3865: there were two hundred thousand Persians slain, and the others put to flight.
tgt_text.3866: When again he (Darius) had gathered an army in Persia, and would avenge it (his defeat), he died.
tgt_text.3867: Afterhim his son Xerxes succeeded to the kingdom:
tgt_text.3868: and for the war that his father had undertaken, he secretly for five years wrought ships and gathered aid.
tgt_text.3869: There was with him an exile from Lacedæmon, a Greek city, who was named Demaratus, who announced that device to his country, and wrote it on a board, and then covered it over with wax.
tgt_text.3870: Xerxes, when he marched against Greece, had of his own people eight hundred thousand, and of other nations he had demanded four hundred thousand;
tgt_text.3871: of ships he had of those great " dulmuns " a thousand and two hundred, and of ships that bore their food there were three thousand ;
tgt_text.3872: and of his whole army there was such an immense number, that it might easily be said, that it was a wonder where they could have land on which they might encamp, or water that they might quench their thirst ;
tgt_text.3873: yet was the immense multitude of people more easy to overcome than it may now be for us to count or to believe.
tgt_text.3874: Leonidas, king of Lacedemonia, a Greek city, had four thousand men when he marched against Xerxes in a narrow land-pass, and there withstood him with battle.
tgt_text.3875: Xerxes so greatly despised the other folk, that he asked why against so little an army there should be more force besides those alone who had before been exasperated against them in the former battle, that was on the hill of Marathon P and placed those men in one body, whose relatives had before been slain in that country, knowing that they would naturally be fuller of revenge than other men.
tgt_text.3876: And they were so, until almost all of them were there slain.
tgt_text.3877: Xerxes then sorely vexed that his people had been so slaughtered, proceeded himself with all the force he could lead thither, and was fighting there for three days, until there was a great slaughter made of the Persians.
tgt_text.3878: He then com­ manded them to make a circuit round the pass, that they (the enemy) might be attacked on more sides than one.
tgt_text.3879: Leonidas then found that they would thus surround him, [and] marched from thence, and led his army into another stronger place, and there continued till night, and com­ manded all the citizens, that he had called to his aid from another land, to depart from him, that they might safely secure themselves;
tgt_text.3880: for he would not allow any more people to perish for his sake, than himself with his own nation.
tgt_text.3881: But he was thus speaking and groaning:
tgt_text.3883: Now we undoubtedly know that we shall lose our own lives on account of the exceedingly great enmity entertained by our persecutors.
tgt_text.3884: Yet let us devise how we one of these nights may most de­ ceive them, and for ourselves, acquire at our end the best and most lasting renown."
tgt_text.3885: How wonderful it is to say, that Leonidas with six hundred men so maltreated six hun­ dred thousand, slaying some, some putting to flight!
tgt_text.3886: Thus was Xerxes, on two occasions, with his enormous multitude, so disgraced in that land;
tgt_text.3887: yet he was still desirous, a third time, with a naval force, of prosecuting the contest, and of alluring the Ionians, a Greek nation, to aid him ;
tgt_text.3888: although they before, against their will, had turned to his side;
tgt_text.3889: and they promised him that they would first settle the conflict by themselves, although they afterwards acted guilefully towards him, when fighting at sea.
tgt_text.3890: Themistocles was the name of the Athenian leader.
tgt_text.3891: They had come to the assistance of Leonidas, although at the first battle they were not able to come to him.
tgt_text.3892: Themistocles reminded the Ionians of the old enmity that Xerxes had exercised towards them, how he had reduced them under his power by devastation and the slaughter of their relatives.
tgt_text.3893: He, moreover, besought them to remember their old compacts and the numberless friend- ships that they had entertained both for the Athenians and Lacedæmonians in former days;
tgt_text.3894: and he besought them that by some artifice they would for some time desert king Xerxes, that they and the Lacedæmonians might put an end to this war against the Persians.
tgt_text.3895: And they granted them their prayer.
tgt_text.3896: When the Persians saw that they (the Ionians) withdrew from them, on whom they had most relied that they would gain the victory for them, they themselves also took to flight, and many of them were there slain, and drowned, and taken prisoners.
tgt_text.3897: The general of Xerxes was named Mardonius:
tgt_text.3898: he earnestly advised him rather to pro­ ceed homewards than to abide longer there, lest some discord should be stirred up in his own kingdom;
tgt_text.3899: and said that it were more fitting that he should commit the war to him with the support that still was left there to carry it on longer.
tgt_text.3900: And said that it would be a less reproach to the king, if the people without him were to speed ill as they had done before.
tgt_text.3901: The king Xerxes heard his general very implicitly, and with a part of his forces departed from thence.
tgt_text.3902: When on his way home, he came to the water, over which he before had ordered the immense bridge of stone to be constructed westward, in token of his victory, which on that march he thought of completing, there was the water at such high flood that he could not come to the bridge.
tgt_text.3903: Then was the king very anxious in mind that he was neither with his army nor could cross over the water, in addition to which he was very fearful that his foes were in pursuit of him.
tgt_text.3904: Then there came a fisherman to him and with difficulty conveyed him over alone.
tgt_text.3905: How God humbled the greatest arrogance, and the greatest undertaking in such shameful arrogance, that he to whom it before had seemed that no sea could re­ sist him, that he could not quell it with ships and with his forces, that be was afterwards begging a little boat of a poor man, that he might save his life!
tgt_text.3906: Mardonius, Xerxes' general, then left the ships in which they had been faring, and proceeded to a city in Bceotia, a Greek country, and took it.
tgt_text.3907: For that he was afterwards quickly requited, being put to flight and sorely beaten withgreat slaughter;
tgt_text.3908: though the victory and plunder of the Per­ sian treasure proved a great scandal to the Athenians;
tgt_text.3909: for after they were wealthier they became also more luxurious.
tgt_text.3910: Afterwards Xerxes became very contemptible to his own nation;
tgt_text.3911: and his own prefect, Artabanus, plotted against him and slew him.
tgt_text.3913: says Orosius, what joyous times there were in those days, as they say who are the adversaries of Christianity;
tgt_text.3914: so that we may long after such as they were, when so great a [number of] people in so little a space, pe­ rished in three national wars, that was ninety hundred thou­ sand men of the Persian power alone, exclusive of their ad­ versaries, both Scythians and Greeks.
tgt_text.3915: Leonidaa, in his last battle with the Persians, announced what a pestilence there was in the land of Greece through the numerous deaths, when he said to his companions at his morning-repast, be­ fore he went to battle :
tgt_text.3917: Let us now eat this morning-meal as those should who are to seek their evening-refection in hell."
tgt_text.3918: Although he thus spoke, he again said other words:
tgt_text.3919: " Although I before said that we shall go to hell, I yet do not lose trust in God, that he may shield us for better times than those in which we now are."
tgt_text.3920: Leonidas said that those times were evil, and desired that better might be at hand for them.
tgt_text.3921: And now some men say that those were better than [those tbat] now are.
tgt_text.3923: Then were both good, the former times, as some men now say, and also the later, as they formerly said, and were not grateful for them.
tgt_text.3924: If they did not speak truth, then were neither good, neither those nor [those that are] now.
tgt_text.3925: Now we will again, says Orosius, return nearer to Rome, where we before left it;
tgt_text.3926: for after all I cannot recount all the manifold evils of all this earth, as I am not acquainted with the greater part, except that which is within two em­ pires, the first and the last;
tgt_text.3927: those are the Assyrian and the Roman.
tgt_text.3928: After Rome had been built two hundred and eighty years, in the same year that the Sabines so deluded the Romans, when three hundred and six of them on either side went to combat, there was a great wonder seen in the heavens, as if all the heaven were burning.
tgt_text.3929: That token was sorely mani­ fested to the Romans by the great deadly pestilence which soon after came upon them, so that the half of them pe­ rished, together with their two consuls that they then bad ;
tgt_text.3930: so that at last those that might be left were enfeebled to that degree that they could not bring the departed to the earth.
tgt_text.3931: Immediately afterwards all their slaves made war against their masters, and they took their chief place that they called the Capitol, and they had great battles about it, until they had slain one consul who had been newly ap­ pointed ;
tgt_text.3932: although the masters finally had an inglorious vic­ tory ;
tgt_text.3933: and immediately after, in the following year, the Ro­ mans made war against the Yolscian nation, and were there sorely beaten, and the portion that was left was driven into a fastness, and had there perished by hunger, if those had not helped them who were at home, by gathering all the males that remained, and taking a poor man for their consul, where he was going in his field, and had his plough in his hand, and then marched to the Volscian land and released them.
tgt_text.3934: After this it was full a year that over all the Roman terri­ tory the earth quaked and burst, and every day there came men innumerable times to the senate, and told them of sunken towns and villages;
tgt_text.3935: and they themselves were every day in dread when they should be sunk in the earth.
tgt_text.3936: After that there came so great a heat throughout Rome that all their earth-fruits, yea, also themselves, nearly perished.
tgt_text.3937: After that there was the greatest famine.
tgt_text.3938: After that the Ro­ mans appointed ten consuls, when before they had had [only] two;
tgt_text.3939: to the end that they might take care of their laws.
tgt_text.3940: One of them was named Claudius, who would arrogate to himself the supremacy over the others, although they would not concede that to him, but strove against him, until the time when some turned to him, some would not, but, thus divided in two, contended with each other, so that they forgot their external wars that they had on hand, until all the consuls combined together and beat the one, Clau­ dius, with clubs, and afterwards defended their own country.
tgt_text.3941: Familiarly and shortly, says Orosius, I have now spoken of their intestine calamities, although they were almost the greatest and most perilous, which Etna also, that sulphureousfire, showed (when from the gate of hell it sprang up in the land of Sicily), what calamities those were compared with those that now are:
tgt_text.3942: and in Sicily killed many with burning and with stench.
tgt_text.3943: But since it became Christian, that hell­ fire was mitigated, as well as all calamities were;
tgt_text.3944: so that it now is without such manifestations of evil as it caused before;
tgt_text.3945: although it every year is broader and broader.
tgt_text.3946: After Rome had been built three hundred and one years, the Sicilians were at variance among themselves, and half of them drew the Lacedæmonians to their aid, and half the Athenians, Greek people, who had previously warred together against the Persians ;
tgt_text.3947: but after they had made war in Sicily, they also made war between themselves, until Darius, the Per­ sian king, gave aid to the Lacedæmonians against the Athe­ nians, on account of their wars with his forefathers.
tgt_text.3948: That was a great wonder that all the Persian and Lacedæmonian power could more easily lay waste the city of Athens than they could force the people to their wills.
tgt_text.3949: And immediately after, in the same year, Darius, the Persian king, died, and his two sons, Artaxerxes and Cyrus, contended for the kingdom, until each of them had brought a vast number of people against the other, and carried on their enmity by battles until Cyrus was slain, who was the younger.
tgt_text.3950: In those days there was a town in Africa that was near the sea, until a sea-flood came and destroyed it, and drowned the inhabitants.
tgt_text.3951: After Rome had been built three hundred and fifty-five years, the Romans besieged the city of the Veil for ten years, and the siege was much more detrimental to them than to those that were in it, both through cold and hunger;
tgt_text.3952: be­ sides which they (the Veii) often made hostile incursions both on themselves and on their lands at home, and they would speedily have perished before their enemies, if they had not taken the city by that craft which was then most scandalous, but which, on the other hand, was most valuable to them ;
tgt_text.3953: which was, that from their camp they delved under the earth until they came up within the city, and stole on them by night in their first sleep and totally destroyed the city.
tgt_text.3954: This useful craft, although it was not honourable, was devised by their dictator, named Camillus.
tgt_text.3955: Immediately after was the war of the Romans and the Gauls, who were from the city of Sena.
tgt_text.3956: That was, at first, because the Gauls had besieged the city of the Etruscans.
tgt_text.3957: Then the Romans sent messengers to the Gauls, and prayed them that they might have peace with them.
tgt_text.3958: When on the same day, after they had said this, the Gauls were fighting against the city, they saw the Roman messengers fighting against them with the inhabitants, at which they were incensed, and, abandoning the city, with all their force sought the Romans, and Fabius the consul met them in battle, and was also speedily driven into the city of Rome, and the Gauls followed him, until they were all within ;
tgt_text.3959: and like as when a meadow is mown they ravaged the city and slaughtered without any heed.
tgt_text.3960: The sign is yet known, in the name of the river, of the defeat of Fabius.
tgt_text.3961: I do not imagine, says Orosius, that any man could recount all the misery that was inflicted on the Romans at that time, [even] though they (the Gauls) had not burnt the city as they then did;
tgt_text.3962: and the few that remained gave a thousand pounds of gold for their lives;
tgt_text.3963: and they did that chiefly because they thought that they afterwards might be their slaves:
tgt_text.3964: and some fled away into the fastness that they called the Capitol, where they also besieged them, until some perished from hunger, some delivered themselves up, and they afterwards sold them to other nations for money.
tgt_text.3965: What think ye now, says Orosius, [ye] who calumniate the days of Christianity, what joyous times the Romans had after the Gauls had gone from the city, when the poor wretches who were left there crept out of the holes into which they had crouched, weeping as though they had come from another world, when they looked on the burnt city and on the ruin;
tgt_text.3966: that was to them dreadful beyond everything, where before had been the greatest joy;
tgt_text.3967: moreover, besides that evil, they had neither food within nor a friend without.
tgt_text.3968: Those were the times which the Romans now long after, and say, that the Goths have caused them worse times thanthey had before, and yet they were only three days plunder­ ing them, and the Gauls before were six months within the city ravaging and burning, and that seemed to them too little an evil, unless they could deprive them of their name, that they might be no more a nation.
tgt_text.3969: Again the Goths plundered and ravaged there for a less period, [and] so that they in honour to Christianity, and through fear of God, neither burnt the city, nor had the desire to deprive them of their name, nor would they do evil to any one of them who fled to the house of God, although they were heathens;
tgt_text.3970: but were much more desirous that they might settle among them in peace.
tgt_text.3971: And with difficulty could any one before flee or hide him­ self from the Gauls.
tgt_text.3972: And when the Goths had plundered there a little while, no one heard of more than a few slain.
tgt_text.3973: There was seen the wrath of God, when their brazen beams and their images, when they could not be burnt by the Gaulish fire, but heavenly fire at the same time burnt them1.
tgt_text.3974: I do not imagine, says Orosius, now I have long narratives to relate, that I can end them in this book, so I shall begin another.
tgt_text.3975: THREE hundred and fifty-seven years after the building of Rome, in those days when the Gauls had laid Rome waste, then was the great and most ignominious peace between Lacedæmon, a Greek country, and the Persians, after the Lacedæmonians had often overcome the Persians.
tgt_text.3976: Then the Persians enjoined them to have a peace of three years with them, those that would;
tgt_text.3977: and those that would not they would seek with war.
tgt_text.3978: Thereupon the Lacedaemonians gladly sub­ mitted to the peace, on account of the little dread that was inspired into them.
tgt_text.3979: By which it may be clearly known how great a will they had for that war, as their poets sing in their songs and in their fables.
tgt_text.3980: Let not such a war appear to thee anything agreeable, says Orosius, nor yet those times, when a man's enemy may so easily govern him with words.
tgt_text.3981: After the Lacedaemonians had conquered the city of Athens, their own nation, they exalted themselves, and began warring on every side of them, against their own people, and against the Persians, and against the Lesser Asia, and against the city of Athens that they had before laid waste;
tgt_text.3982: because the few that had fled from thence, had again inhabited the city, and had drawn the Thebans, a Greek people, to their aid.
tgt_text.3983: The Lacedaemonians were so up-lifted, that both they themselves and all the neighbouring people imagined that they might have power over all of them;
tgt_text.3984: but the Athenians, with the aid of the Thebans, withstood them and overcame them in battle.
tgt_text.3985: After that the Lacedæmonians chose a general named Dercyllidas, and sent him to Persia with a force to fight against that nation.
tgt_text.3986: The Persians with their two generals, one named Pharnabazus, the other Tissaphernes, marched against him.
tgt_text.3987: As soon as the Lacaedemonian general knew that he should have to fight against the two armies, it seemed to him most advisable to make a truce with one, that he might the more easily overcome the other:
tgt_text.3988: and lie did so, and sent his messengers to the one, and commanded them to say that he would rather have peace with him than war.
tgt_text.3989: Thereupon the general credulously received the message with peace, and the Lacedaemonians in the meanwhile put the other general to flight.
tgt_text.3990: Afterwards the Persian king deprived that general of his province, who had previously accepted peace from the La­ cedæmonians, and gave it to an exile from Athens, the Greek city, who was named Conon, and sent him with a fleet from Persia to Lacedæmonia.
tgt_text.3991: And the Lacedæmonians sent to the Egyptians, praying them for aid, and they gave them a hun­ dred large triremes.
tgt_text.3992: The Lacedæmonians had for general a wise man, although he was lame, who was named Agesilaus, and had as a vaunt, that they would rather have a lame king than a lame kingdom.
tgt_text.3993: They afterwards came together at sea, and there fought so fiercely that they nearly all perished, so that neither could gain a victory over the other.
tgt_text.3994: There was the Lacedaemonian power and glory prostrated.
tgt_text.3995: I do not think, says Orosius, that any two leaders fought more equally.
tgt_text.3996: After that Conon led an army in return against Lacedae­ monia, and totally laid waste the country, exclusive of the city, on all sides;
tgt_text.3997: so that to them who before had coveted power over other nations abroad, it now seemed good if they could defend themselves against thraldom at home.
tgt_text.3998: There was a Lacedaemonian general named Pisander, who went in search of Conon with a fleet, when he left Lacedæmonia, and both of these nations fought, one against the other, with great slaughter.
