tgt_text.3999: There were the Lacedæmonians so totally defeated that they afterwards had neither their name nor their power;
tgt_text.4000: but their fall was the raising up of the Athenians, so that they could avenge the old grudge which in former days had been mutual.
tgt_text.4001: And they and the Thebans assembled, and sought the Lacedæmonians with warfare, and put them to flight, and drove them into their city, and then laid siege to it.
tgt_text.4002: The inhabitants thereupon sent for Agesi­ laus, who was with their army in Asia, and requested him to return home speedily and aid them;
tgt_text.4003: and he did so, and came on the Athenians unawares and put them to flight.
tgt_text.4004: The Athenians then greatly dreaded lest the Lacedæmonians should rule over them as they before had done, in conse­ quence of the little victory they had gained over them.
tgt_text.4005: So they sent to Persia after Conon, and besought him to aid them, to which he consented, and sought them with a large fleet, and they laid waste the greater part of Lacedæmonia, and so reduced them, that they regarded themselves both as too base and too powerless.
tgt_text.4006: After that Conon landed at the city of Athens, his old country, and was there received with the great joy of the citizens, and he there made a long re­ membrance of himself, by compelling both the Persians and the Lacedæmonians to repair the city which they before had ruined, and the Lacedaemonians to be thenceforth obedient to the city, although they previously had long been its adver­ saries.
tgt_text.4007: After this war it happened that the Persians offered peace to all the Greek people, not because they would give them any benefits, but because, being at war with the Egyp­ tians, they might the better for themselves terminate the contest.
tgt_text.4008: But the Lacedæmonians meanwhile were more restless than powerful, and made war on the Thebans more vigorously than their force admitted ;
tgt_text.4009: but stole on them in bodies, until they took their town from the Arcadians.
tgt_text.4010: After that the Thebans sought them with an army, and the Lacedæmonians brought another against them.
tgt_text.4011: When they long fought together, the Lacedæmonian general called to the Arcadians, and requested that they would cease from fighting, that they might bury the dead that had fallen of their people.
tgt_text.4012: It is a custom among the Greeks that with those words it is declared whichside has the victory.
tgt_text.4013: Because it has been my wish to relate, and in narratives describe, says Orosius, how the Greek war, which first proceeded from the city of Lacedæmon [extended itself], first to the city of Athens, and afterwards to Thebes, and then to Boeotia, and then to Macedonia (all these were Greek nations), and then to the Lesser Asia, and then to the Greater, and then to Persia, and then to Egypt, I shall the later recount also the Roman history, which I had begun.
tgt_text.4014: After Rome had been built three hundred and seventy-six years, there was an earthquake in Achaia, and two cities, Ebora and Helice, sank into the earth.
tgt_text.4015: I may also in our own times relate a beginning like to that, although it had not such an end:
tgt_text.4016: that Constantinople, the Greek city, was in a similar quaking, and it was prophesied of it by veracious men, that it should sink into the earth;
tgt_text.4017: but it was shielded through the Christian emperor, Arcadius, and through the Christian people who were in those towns.
tgt_text.4018: That manifested that Christ is the help of the humble and the ruin of the proud.
tgt_text.4019: More of this I would have commemorated than I have altogether related of it:
tgt_text.4020: if any one be desirous to know more, then let him seek it himself.
tgt_text.4021: It happened in those days that the Volsci and Falisci, who had previously been warring on the Romans for seventy years, were overcome by them and their lands ravaged;
tgt_text.4022: and soon after that the nation of the Sutrini laid waste the Roman [territory] as far as the gates of the city.
tgt_text.4023: After which the Romans quickly requited them with war and destruction, and put them to flight.
tgt_text.4024: After Rome had been built three hundred and eighty-three years, when Lucius, who by another name was called Genu­ cius, and Quintus, who by another name was called Servilius, when these were consuls at Rome, happened the great pesti­ lence in the country, not as it is wont, from unseasonable bad weather—that is, from wet summers and from dry winters, and from fierce spring heats, and with excessive autumnalrains and after-heats;
tgt_text.4025: but a wind came from the forest of Calabria, and with that wind the plague.
tgt_text.4026: This pestilence was fall two years in the Roman [territory] over all men alike;
tgt_text.4027: though some died, some afflicted with difficulty escaped, until their priests said that their gods commanded amphi­ theatres to be built for them, that the heathen games might therein be enacted, and their idolatries, that were manifestly all uncleannesses.
tgt_text.4028: Here may we now, says Orosius, answer those who are adversaries of Christianity [who assert] how their gods, through their sacrificing and their idolatry, helped them in this pestilence, only that they knew not by what sorcery and by what artifice of devils they did it (it was not the true God), [and] that they afflicted men with that evil, in order that they might trust in their offerings and to their idols, and that they might thence come at their souls, and that they might treat them with the greatest contumely;
tgt_text.4029: for their am­ phitheatres then were innumerable, and too many for me to relate;
tgt_text.4030: [and] because thou, Father Augustine, hast manifestly said it in thy books, I will direct every one thereto who de­ sires to know more of the subject.
tgt_text.4031: After this, in the same year, the earth yawned within the city of Rome;
tgt_text.4032: whereupon their priests said that their gods commanded a living man to be given them, as it seemed to them they had had too few of their dead.
tgt_text.4033: And the earth so continued gaping, until Marcus, who by another name was called Curtius, with horse and weapons cast himself therein, and it afterwards closed together.
tgt_text.4034: After Rome had been built three hundred and eighty-eight years, the Gauls ravaged the Roman territory to within four miles of the city, and might easily have gained the city, if they had not lost their energy, because the Romans were so timid and so pusillanimous, that they did not suppose they could defend the city.
tgt_text.4035: But on the morrow, Titus, their general, who by another name was called Quinctius, sought them with an army, where Manlius fought in single combat, who by another name was called Torquatus, with a Gaulish man, and slew him.
tgt_text.4036: And of the others Titus Quinctius put some to flight and some he slew.
tgt_text.4037: How many were there slainmay be conceived from this [circumstance], that many thou­ sands of them were taken.
tgt_text.4038: After Rome had been built four hundred and two years, messengers came from the city of Carthage to Rome, and proposed that they should have peace between them, because they were warring together in a country, that was, in Bene­ ventum.
tgt_text.4039: When the messengers came to Rome, with them also came the overwhelming calamity and miseries of many nations, which went on increasing long after that, as the stars of heaven at that time testified, so that it was night till mid- day, and at one time it hailed stones over all the Roman [territory].
tgt_text.4040: In those days Alexander was born in Greece, as a great tempest comes over all the earth;
tgt_text.4041: and Ochus, king of Persia, who by another name is called Artaxerxes, after he had laid Egypt waste, proceeded to the land of the Jews and destroyed many of them ;
tgt_text.4042: afterwards in the land of Hyrcania;
tgt_text.4043: he settled many of them by the sea called the Caspian, and they are yet settled there to this day in considerable numbers, in the hope that at some time God will conduct them thence to their own land.
tgt_text.4044: After that Artaxerxes took Sidon, a city of Phœnicia, which was the wealthiest in those days.
tgt_text.4045: After that the Romans began the Samnite war about the land of Campania.
tgt_text.4046: They fought long and often for it with alternate victories.
tgt_text.4047: The Samnites then drew to their aid Pyrrhus, king of Epirus, the greatest enemy of the Romans.
tgt_text.4048: That war was, nevertheless, for some time suspended, because the Carthaginians had begun to war on the Romans since that (the Samnite) war was begun.
tgt_text.4049: If there be any man, says Orosius, who can find in writings that the door of Janus was afterwards closed, except for one year, and that was be­ cause the Romans were all that year afflicted with the pesti­ lence, first in the time of the emperor Octavianus.
tgt_text.4050: That temple the Romans had built for that one sign:
tgt_text.4051: that on whatever side they would be at war, whether south, or north, or east, or west, they then undid the door which was opened on that side, that they might thereby know whither they should [proceed] ;
tgt_text.4052: and when they saw any one of the doors open, they then drew up their robe above the knee, and preparedthem for war;
tgt_text.4053: by which it was known that with some nation they were not at peace.
tgt_text.4054: And when they had peace, then all the doors were closed, and they let their robe down to their feet.
tgt_text.4055: But when the emperor Octavianus succeeded to the empire, then were the doors of Janus closed, and there was peace and quiet over all the earth.
tgt_text.4056: After the Persians had made peace with the Romans, it pleased all nations to be subject to the Romans and to observe their law;
tgt_text.4057: and so greatly did they love that peace, that it was more agreeable to them to have Roman kings than of their own race.
tgt_text.4058: By which it was manifestly indicated that no earthly man could cause such love and such peace over all the earth as that was.
tgt_text.4059: But it was because Christ was born in those days, who is the peace of the inhabitants of heaven and of earth.
tgt_text.4060: That also Octavianus manifestly indicated, when the Romans would sacrifice to him, as was their wont, and said that the peace was through his might;
tgt_text.4061: but he disclaimed both the act and the speech, and also said himself, that the deed was not his, nor could it be of any earthly man, that could bring such peace to all the world, what previously two nations could not have, nor, what was less, two families.
tgt_text.4062: After Rome had been built four hundred and eight years, it befel that the Romans and the Latins made war.
tgt_text.4063: In the first battle the Roman consul, Manlius, who by another name was called Torquatus, was slain;
tgt_text.4064: and their other consul, named Decius, and by another name, Mus, slew his own son, because he transgressed their agreement, which was, that they had declared they would all equally assail the Latins.
tgt_text.4065: But there one of the Latin army rushed forth and demanded a single combat, and the consul's son advanced against him and there slew him.
tgt_text.4066: For that crime the Romans would not bring the triumph to the consul, which was their custom, al­ though he had the victory.
tgt_text.4067: In the year after this, a woman named Minucia, who in their manner is said to have been a nun, had promised their god­ dess Diana that she would pass her life in maidenhood ;
tgt_text.4069: The Romans thereupon, for the sin of having belied her vow, buried her alive in theearth;
tgt_text.4070: and now to this day, in token of that sin, that land is called the " Campus sceleratus," where she was buried.
tgt_text.4071: Soon after that, in the time of the two consuls, Claudius, who by another name was called Marcellus, and Valerius, who by another name was called Flaccus, it betel, though I feel shame, says Orosius, [to relate it], that some Roman women were in such [a state ofl magical delusion and such frantic passion, that they would kill every human being, both female and male, that they could, by poison, and give it them to take either in food or drink.
tgt_text.4072: And this they did for a long time, before the people knew whence the evil came, only that they said it came from above, from the air, until it was made known by a slave.
tgt_text.4073: Thereupon all those women were summoned before the Roman senators (there were three hundred and eighty of them), and were there forced to consume that which they had before given to others, so that they died before all those men.
tgt_text.4074: After Rome had been built four hundred and twenty-two years, Alexander, king of the Epirots, the uncle of Alexander the Great, began to war on the Romans with all his power, and posted himself on the boundary of the Samnites and Romans, and drew to his aid the nearest people of the coun­ try on either side, until the Samnites fought against them and slew the king.
tgt_text.4075: Now I have here made mention of this Alexander, says Orosius, I will also mention the Great Alex­ ander, the other's nephew;
tgt_text.4076: although I shall recount concern­ ing the Roman wars in that year, until I have related them.
tgt_text.4077: I shall, however, retrograde, that I may relate every, even small, portion of Alexander's deeds;
tgt_text.4078: and how his father, Philip, four hundred years after the building of Rome, suc­ ceeded to the realm of Macedonia and the Greeks, and held it for twenty-five years, and in those years he conquered all the states that were in Greece.
tgt_text.4079: One was the Athenian, the second was the Theban, the third was the Thessalian, the fourth the Lacedaemonian, the fifth the Phocian, the sixth the Mœsian, the seventh Macedonia, which he had first.
tgt_text.4080: When a boy, Philip had been given as a hostage to the Thebans, to Epaminondas, that powerful king and most learned philosopher, by his own brother, Alexander, who then had the realm of Lacedæmonia, and was taught by him (Epaminondas) during the three years that he was there.
tgt_text.4081: Then was Alexander, his brother, slain by his own mother, although she had before slain also her other son, for the sake of her adultery, and she was Philip's stepmother.
tgt_text.4082: Philip then succeeded to the kingdom of Macedon, and held it all the while in great peril and with great difficulty ;
tgt_text.4083: for both from with­ out, from other countries, war was made on him, and his own people also plotted against his life, so that at last it was preferable to him to make war abroad than to be at home.
tgt_text.4084: His first war was with the Athenians, and them he overcame;
tgt_text.4085: and after that with the Illyrians, whom we call Bulgarians, and of them he slew many thousands, and took Larissa, their largest city, and afterwards carried on the war principally against the Thessalians, in consequence of his desire to draw them to his aid, on account of their military skill, and because they of all people could fight the best on horses;
tgt_text.4086: and at the first, either through dread of him, or through his flattery, they turned to him.
tgt_text.4087: He then, with their force and with his own, gathered an invincible army of both horse and foot.
tgt_text.4088: After Philip had reduced the Athenians and Thessalians under his subjection, he obtained the daughter of Arucha, king of the Molossians, to wife, whose name was Olympias.
tgt_text.4089: Arucha thought that he should increase his kingdom when he gave his daughter to Philip ;
tgt_text.4090: but he confined him to his dwelling, and took from him what he already had, and after­ wards banished him, until he ended his life.
tgt_text.4091: After that, Philip fought against the city of Methone, in the Theban realm, and there was one of his eyes shot out with an arrow.
tgt_text.4092: He, nevertheless, won the city, and slew all the people that he found in it.
tgt_text.4093: And afterwards, by his artifices, he conquered all the Greek nations, because it was their usage, that they would of every city have the power to themselves, and no one be subject to another, but were thus warring among themselves.
tgt_text.4094: They then besought Philip, first from one city, then from another, that he would aid them against those who were warring against them.
tgt_text.4095: Then, when he had overpowered those with whom he was then at war, with [the aid of] the people who had before sought his help, he reduced them both to his subjection.
tgt_text.4096: Thus he deluded all Greece into his power.
tgt_text.4097: When the Greeks became sell­ sible of that, and also being sorely mortified that a king, so easily, without any war, should reduce them under his power, as though they were his slaves (he also often sold them in thraldom to other nations, whom before no nation could overcome in war) ;
tgt_text.4098: they thereupon all raised war against him, and he humbled himself to that people whom he most sorely dreaded, namely, the Thessalians, and by his flattery induced them to make war with him on the Athenians.
tgt_text.4099: When they came to the boundary with their army, they [the Athenians] had shut up all the passes.
tgt_text.4100: When Philip could not enter, that he might avenge his mishap, he turned against those who alone had been true to him and took their city, and slew all the people and over­ threw their temples, as he did all that he found in any place, yea, even his own, until the priests said to him that all the gods were wroth with him, and warring against him;
tgt_text.4101: and although they all were wroth with him for the five-and-twenty years that he was engaged in war and fighting, he was not over­ come.
tgt_text.4102: He afterwards proceeded to the land of Cappadocia, and there, by his treachery, slew all the kings, and after­ wards all Cappadocia submitted to him;
tgt_text.4103: and he afterwards turned against his three brothers and slew one [of them], and the two fled to the town of Olynthus, which was the strongest and wealthiest of the realm of Macedon;
tgt_text.4104: and Philip followed them and captured the town, and slew his brothers and all that were in it.
tgt_text.4105: The three brothers were not [related] to Philip by the mother, but by the father.
tgt_text.4106: In those days, in the country of Thrace, there were two kings contending for the kingdom ;
tgt_text.4108: They then sent to Philip, and prayed that he would recon­ cile them with regard to the kingdom, and be witness that it was equally divided.
tgt_text.4109: Philip thereupon came to their assem­ bly with a large army, and slew both the kings and all their councillors, and succeeded to both the kingdoms.
tgt_text.4110: After that the Athenians prayed Philip to be their leader against the Phocians, although they had previously closed their passes against him;
tgt_text.4111: and that he would do either the one or the other, either reconcile them, or aid them that they might overcome them [the Phocians].
tgt_text.4112: He thereupon promised them that he would aid them, so that they should conquer them.
tgt_text.4113: At the same time the Phocians also prayed him to aid them against the Athenians.
tgt_text.4114: He then promised that he would settle their difference.
tgt_text.4115: After he had the passes in his power, he also reduced those countries to subjection, and dis­ persed his army among all the towns, and commanded that they should harry the land until they had laid it waste.
tgt_text.4116: That was a calamity to the people, both that they had to bear that greatest of evils, and also that they could not free them­ selves from it;
tgt_text.4117: for he had commanded all the most powerful to be slain, and of the others sent some into exile, [and] placed some in other confines.
tgt_text.4118: Thus did Philip humble those large realms, although each of them before had ima­ gined that it could have power over many others;
tgt_text.4119: so that at last they esteemed themselves as nought.
tgt_text.4120: It seemed to Philip after that, that on land he could not conciliate the people with gifts who had been constantly fighting [in alliance] with him, but he collected ships, and they became pirates, and soon, at one time, they captured a hundred and eighty merchant-ships.
tgt_text.4121: He then chose him a city on the sea called Byzantium, in order (what seemed de­ sirable to him) that they might therein best have peace, and also that they there might be the nearest at hand to make war from thence on any country.
tgt_text.4122: But the inhabitants of the town refused him this, [and] Philip, with his forces, besieged them and made war on them.
tgt_text.4123: This same Byzantium was first built by Pausanius, the Lacedæmonian general, and after that enlarged by Constantine, the Christian emperor, and from his name it was called Constantinople, and is now the highest royal seat and head of all the eastern empire.
tgt_text.4124: After that Philip had long laid siege to the town, it pained him sorely that he had not money to give to his army, as they had been accustomed to receive.
tgt_text.4125: Thereupon he divided his army in two, stationed some about the town, and he with some bodies went and plundered many towns of the Cherso­ nesus, Grecian people, and afterwards marched to Scythia, with his son Alexander (where King Atheas ruled the realm, who had previously been his associate in the Istrian war), and would enter that country;
tgt_text.4126: but the people of the country forbade him that, and marched with an army against him.
tgt_text.4127: When Philip was apprized of this he sent for a larger force to those who were besieging the town (Byzantium), and with all his power marched against them.
tgt_text.4128: Although the Scythians had a greater multitude of men, and were them­ selves more vigorous;
tgt_text.4129: yet Philip deceived them with his arti­ fices, by hiding himself with a third part of his army, with which he himself was, and commanded the two parts, that, when they began to fight, they should flee towards him, that he then, with the third part, might ensnare them, when they were dispersed.
tgt_text.4130: There were twenty thousand Scythians slain and captured, females and males, and there were twenty thousand horses taken;
tgt_text.4131: though they there found no treasure, as they had previously been accustomed to do, when they kept possession of the field of battle.
tgt_text.4132: In that war the poverty of the Scythians first became known.
tgt_text.4133: When Philip was on his return, other Scythians met him with a little army ;
tgt_text.4135: Philip regarded their hostility as contemptible, until a woman shot him through the thigh, so that the horse was killed on which he sat.
tgt_text.4136: When his army saw that he had fallen together with his horse, they all fled, and left all the booty they had before taken.
tgt_text.4137: It was a great wonder that so large an army fled in consequence of the fall of the king, which before that would not flee from those who slew many thousands of them.
tgt_text.4138: Philip, with his cunning, during the time he was wounded, allowed all the Greeks to retain their sovereignty among themselves, as they had done before.
tgt_text.4139: But as soon as he was cured, he committed ravages on the Athenians.
tgt_text.4140: Thereupon they sent to the Lacedaemonians, and besought them that they might be friends, although they had before long been foes, and besought that they might all endeavour in common to drive from them their common enemy.
tgt_text.4141: To this some ac­ ceded, and collected a larger force than Philip had;
tgt_text.4143: To Philip it then seemed that he could no longer withstand them in great battles, but he frequently, with detachments, made hostile inroads on them, and laid ambushes around them, until they were again divided, and then unexpectedly marched with his army on Athens.
tgt_text.4144: On this occasion the Athenians were so cruelly slaughtered and humbled, that they never afterwards assumed to themselves any power or any freedom.
tgt_text.4145: After that Philip led an army against the Lacedaemonians and the Thebans, and sorely afflicted and misused them, untilthey were all undone and ruined.
tgt_text.4146: After Philip had reduced all the Greeks under his power, he gave his daughter to the king Alexander, his own kinsman, to whom he had before given the kingdom of Epirus.
tgt_text.4147: On that day when they were playing on horseback, both Philip and Alexander, to whom he would give his daughter, and also Alexander his own son, as was their usage on such [occasions], and also many others with him;
tgt_text.4148: when Philip, in the course of the play, had occasion to ride out from the company, he was met by one of his old enemies and mortally wounded.
tgt_text.4149: I know not, says Orosius, why by you, Romans, these old wars are so well liked and listened to in poems, and why you so warmly praise times of such miseries;
tgt_text.4150: and now, though a very little of such miseries befal you, you bemoan it as the worst of times, and can as bitterly bewail it as you can joyfully laugh over those others.
tgt_text.4151: If you are such persons as you imagine you are, then you should as willingly bear your own afflic­ tions (although they are less) as you are [willing] to hear [those] of those [times];
tgt_text.4152: then might these times appear better to you than those, as your afflictions are now less than theirs then were;
tgt_text.4153: because Philip was for twenty-five years devastating the Greek nation, either burning their towns or slaying their people, and sending some into exile ;
tgt_text.4154: and your Roman afflictions, which you are all day adducing, were for three days only.
tgt_text.4155: Yet might the evil caused by Philip in.
tgt_text.4156: some degree be thought moderate, before the drunkard Alexander, his son, succeeded to the kingdom;
tgt_text.4157: though I will now for a while be silent as to his deeds, until I relate [those] of the Romans, which were done at the same time.
tgt_text.4158: Four hundred and twenty-six years after the building of Rome, the place [called] Caudinæ Furculæ became very famous, and yet to this day is a reproach to the Romans.
tgt_text.4159: That betel after the war that the Romans and Samnites had, as we have before said, when twenty thousand of the Samnites were slain [by the former] under the consul Fabius.
tgt_text.4160: But in a second war, the Samnites came with a larger force and with more caution than before to meet the Romans, at the place called Caudinæ Furculæ ;
tgt_text.4161: and there the Romans suf­ fered disgrace chiefly because that land was more unknown to them than it was to the Samnites, and in their ignorance they marched into a narrow pass, until the Samnites encom­ passed them without, so that they must then do one or the other, either perish from want of food, or yield themselves to the Samnites.
tgt_text.4162: In their power the Samnites were so confident, that the prince, who was their general, named Pontius, caused the king, his father, who was at home, to be asked, whether he preferred that he should slay them all, or order them to be preserved alive as a mockery.
tgt_text.4163: The prince then treated them with that contumely which in those days was the greatest.
tgt_text.4164: He bereft them of their clothes and their weapons, and received six hundred hostages into his power, on condition that they should afterwards be perpetual slaves to him;
tgt_text.4165: and the prince commanded some of his people to conduct the Roman consuls to their own territories, and to drive them before them like thralls, that their ignominy might be the greater.
tgt_text.4166: We would rather, says Orosius, be silent than speaking on the disgraces of you, Romans, if we might, notwithstanding your own discontent which you have with Christianity.
tgt_text.4168: you know that, even at this day, you would be the slaves of the Samnites, if you had not belied your pledges and your oaths that you gave them;
tgt_text.4169: and you now murmur because many nations, over whom you had power, would not perform what they had promised you.
tgt_text.4170: And will you not call to memory how hateful it was to yourselves to perform your oaths to those who had power over you ?
tgt_text.4171: Immediately after this, in the following year, the Romans broke their oaths that they had given to the Samnites, and with Papirius, their consul, sought them with an army, and gained a deadly victory (for both of those nations were eager for battle;
tgt_text.4172: the Samnites on account of the power that they had on every side, and the Romans because of the disgrace they had undergone from them) ;
tgt_text.4173: till at length the Romans captured the king of the Samnites, and took their fastness and made them tributaries.
tgt_text.4174: The same Papirius was, after that war, invested with such authority, that they chose him to withstand in war the Great Alexander, if he from the East, from Asia, should invade Italy, as he had said.
tgt_text.4175: Four hundred and twenty-six years after the building of Rome, Alexander succeeded to the kingdom of Macedon, after his father, Philip, and manifested his earliest ability by reducing by his policy all the Greeks under his power, all those who had raised up war against him.
tgt_text.4176: That arose first from the Persians, when they gave Demosthenes, the philo­ sopher, treasure, in order that he might instruct all the Greeks to oppose Alexander.
tgt_text.4177: The Athenians declared war against Alexander, but he forthwith beat and put them to flight, so that from that time they stood in boundless awe of him;
tgt_text.4178: and took the fastness of the Thebans, and totally de­ stroyed it, which before had been the capital of all the Greeks;
tgt_text.4179: and afterwards sold all the people into foreign countries ;
tgt_text.4180: and all the other nations that were in Greece he made tributaries, except Macedonia, which again returned to him;
tgt_text.4181: and thence he marched against the Illyrians and Thracians, and subjected them all to him;
tgt_text.4182: and afterwards he gathered an army against Persia, and while he was gather­ ing it, he slew all his relations that he could reach.
tgt_text.4183: In his foot-army there were thirty-two thousand, and of cavalry four thousand five hundred, and of ships a hundred and eighty.
tgt_text.4184: I know not, says Orosius, which was the greater miracle, that he with so small a force could overcome the greatest part of this earth, or that he with so little an army durst undertake so much.
tgt_text.4185: In the first battle that Alexander fought with Darius and the Persians, Darius had six hundred thousand people, yet he was defeated more by Alexander's craft than his fighting.
tgt_text.4186: There was an immense slaughter of the Persians, and of Alexander's [force] there were no more than a hundred and twenty of the cavalry and only nine of the infantry [slain].
tgt_text.4187: Alexander then marched thence to Phrygia, a country of Asia, and took and destroyed their town called Sardis.
tgt_text.4188: It was then told him that Darius had again gathered an army in Persia.
tgt_text.4189: At this Alexander was in dread, on account of the narrow place in which he then was, and [urged] by that fear, speedily marched from thence over Mount Taurus, and proceeded an incredibly long way on that day, until he came to the city of Tarsus in the land of Cilicia.
tgt_text.4190: On that day he met with a river that had exceedingly cold water, which was called Cydnus, and all sweaty began bathing in it, when, through the cold, all his veins shrank, so that no one sup­ posed him alive.
tgt_text.4191: Quickly after that Darius came with an army to Alexander:
tgt_text.4192: he had three hundred thousand foot and a hundred thousand horse.
tgt_text.4193: Alexander greatly dreaded him, on account of that great multitude, and of the little that he himself had ;
tgt_text.4194: although he had before with the same Darius overcome a greater.
tgt_text.4195: The battle was fought with great obstinacy by both nations, and both kings were there wounded.
tgt_text.4196: Of the Persians there were slain ten thousand horse and eighty thousand foot, and eighty thousand captured, and there was an immense treasure found in the camp.
tgt_text.4197: The mother of Darius was there taken, and his wife, who was his sister, and his two daughters.
tgt_text.4198: Darius then offered half his kingdom to Alexander for the women, but Alexander would not grant him that.
tgt_text.4199: Yet a third time Darius gathered an army from the Persians, and also what aid he could draw to him from other countries, and marched against Alexander.
tgt_text.4200: While Darius was collecting an army, Alexander sent his general Parmenio to put the fleet of Darius to flight, and he himself marched into Syria, and they came to meet him, and received him with great humility;
tgt_text.4201: yet he, nevertheless, ravaged their country, and of the people he let some remain, drove some thence, sold some into foreign countries.
tgt_text.4202: And the ancient and rich city of Tyre he besieged and took, and totally destroyed, because they would not voluntarily receive him ;
tgt_text.4203: and afterwards proceeded to Cilicia, and subdued that people, and afterwards to the island of Rhodes, and reduced that people under his subjection, and after that proceeded against the Egyptians, and reduced them to subjection, and there commanded the city to be built that from him was afterwards called Alexandria;
tgt_text.4204: and afterwards he proceeded to the temple which the Egyptians said was [that] of their god Ammon, who was the son of Jove, their other god, for the purpose of exculpating his mother with reference to Nectabanus the sorcerer, with whom it was said she had committed adultery, and that he was the father of Alexander.
tgt_text.4205: Thereupon Alexander com- manded the heathen priest to creep into the image of Ammon, that was within the temple, before he and the people had assembled there, and said how he, according to his will, should answer before the people to what he might ask him.
tgt_text.4206: Plainly enough Alexander has now given us to know what the heathen gods are for [objects of] worship, [and] that it is rather from the body of priests and their own utterance that which they say, than from the power of the gods.
tgt_text.4207: From that place Alexander marched for the third time against Darius, and they met each other at the city of Tarsus.
tgt_text.4208: In that battle the Persians were so totally defeated, that their great and long power they afterwards esteemed as no­ thing against Alexander.
tgt_text.4209: When Darius saw that he should be overcome, he was desirous of perishing in the battle, but his officers drew him away against his will, so that he after­ wards fled with the army;
tgt_text.4210: and Alexander was thirty-three days on the place before hd could plunder the camp and the dead, and afterwards marched into Persia and took the city of Persepolis, their royal residence, which is still the wealthiest of all cities.
tgt_text.4211: Then it was told to Alexander that his own relations had bound Darius with a golden chain.
tgt_text.4212: He then marched towards him with six thousand men, and found him alone lying by the way pierced with spears, half dead.
tgt_text.4213: Alex­ ander then showed to him alone [when] dead a little compas­ sion, by ordering him to be buried in the tomb of his ancestors, which he would not afterwards show to any part of his kin, not to his wife, nor his mother, nor his children, not to that which was least of all, his younger daughter, [whom] he would have only in captivity, who was a little child.
tgt_text.4214: Not easily [even] to the credulous can be related so many evils as in those three years betel, in the three great battles be­ tween the two kings.
tgt_text.4215: It was fifteen hundred thousand men that perished within that [time];
tgt_text.4216: and of the same nations there perished a little before, as has before been said, nineteen hundred thousand men, not to mention the great ravages which took place within those three years among many a people;
tgt_text.4217: that is, in Assyria all the nation was plundered by Alexander, and many cities in Asia, and Tyre, the great city, were destroyed, and all the land of Cilicia laid waste, and the land of Cappadocia, and all Egypt reduced to slavery, and the island of Rhodes totally laid waste, and many lands about the mountains of Taurus.
tgt_text.4218: Not only was then the war of those two in the east part of this earth, but coeval with that Agis, the Spartans' king, and Antipater, another Greek king, were at war with each I other;
tgt_text.4219: and Alexander, the uncle of Alexander the Great, desired the west part as the other did the east part, and led an army into Italy, and was there speedily slain.
tgt_text.4220: And at the same time, Zopyrion, king of Pontus, marched with an army, and he and his people there totally perished.
tgt_text.4221: After the death of Darius, Alexander won all the Mardi and all Hyrcania;
tgt_text.4222: and at another time, when he was there carrying on war, Minothaea, the Scythian queen, with three hundred women, shamelessly sought him, because they wished to con­ ceive children by him and his greatest warriors.
tgt_text.4223: After that Alexander made war on the Parthian nation, and slew and de­ stroyed them nearly all before he could overcome them.
tgt_text.4224: After that he subdued the nations of the Drangae, the Euergetæ, and the Parapameni, and the Adaspii, and many other nations that are seated about the mountains of Caucasus, and there commanded a city to be built, that was afterwards called Alex­ andria.
tgt_text.4225: Neither his treachery nor his ravages were exercised only on foreigners, but he slew and injured alike those who were constantly his associates and fellow-warriors.
tgt_text.4226: First he slew Amyntas, the son of his maternal aunt, and afterwards his brother, and then Parmenio, his general, and then Phi­ lotas, and then Attains;
tgt_text.4227: then Eurylochus, then Pausanias, and many others that were the most powerful of Macedonia;
tgt_text.4228: and Clitus, who was both his servant and previously his father, Philip's.
tgt_text.4229: When they on one occasion were sitting drunk at their feast, they began to discuss who had performed the greater deeds, whether Philip or Alexander;
tgt_text.4230: when Clitus, from old affection, said that Philip had done more than he.
tgt_text.4231: Alexander then, on account of that speech, leapt up and slew him;
tgt_text.4232: besides that, he was the oppressor both of his own people and those of other kings ;
tgt_text.4233: he was ever thirsting after human blood.
tgt_text.4234: Quickly after that he marched with an army against the Chorasmi and Dahæ, and forced them to be tributaries to him.
tgt_text.4235: Callisthenes, the philosopher, his fellow-disciple, he slew (they had been taught together by their master, Aristotle), and many men with him, because they would not worship him as their god.
tgt_text.4236: After that he proceeded to India, for the purpose of ex­ tending his dominion to the eastern ocean.
tgt_text.4237: In that expedi­ tion he took Nyssa, the chief city of India, and all the mountains called Dædali, and all the realm of Cleophis, the queen, and compelled her to prostitution, and for that re­ stored to her her kingdom.
tgt_text.4238: After Alexander had reduced all India under his power, excepting one town that was ex­ ceedingly strong, surrounded by rocks, he was informed that Hercules, the giant, had journeyed thither in days of old, with the design of taking it;
tgt_text.4239: but he did not attempt it, be.
tgt_text.4240: cause there was an earthquake at that time.
tgt_text.4241: He, Alexander, then undertook it, chiefly because he would that his glory should be greater than Hercules's, although he gained it with a great loss of his people.
tgt_text.4242: After that Alexander had a battle with Porus, the most valiant king of India.
tgt_text.4243: In that battle there was infinite bloodshed of those people on both sides.
tgt_text.4244: In that battle Porus and Alexander fought in single combat on horseback, when Porus killed Alexander's horse that was named Bucephalus, and might [have killed] himself, if his attendants had not come to his succour;
tgt_text.4245: and he had wounded Porus with many wounds, and also made him pri­ soner, after his attendants bad come to him ;
tgt_text.4246: and left him his kingdom again, on account of his valour, because he bad so stoutly fought against him.
tgt_text.4247: And Alexander afterwards commanded him to build two cities, one was called after his horse, Bucephala, the other Nicæa.
tgt_text.4248: He afterwards proceeded against the nation of the Adrestæ, and against the Cathæi, and against the Præsidæ, and against the Gangaridæ, and fought against them all and overcame them.
tgt_text.4249: When he came to the east confines of India, there came against him two hundred thousand people on horseback, and Alexander with difficulty overcame them, both on account of the summer heat, and of the frequent battles.
tgt_text.4250: After that, he would have a larger encampment than he was previously wont to have;
tgt_text.4251: because, after that battle, he stayed within it more than he had done previously.
tgt_text.4252: After that he marched out to the ocean, from the mouth of the river which was called Acesine, on to an island where the nation of the Sibi and the Gessonæ dwell (and Hercules had before brought them thither and established them), and them he reduced to subjection.
tgt_text.4253: After that he proceeded to the island the people of which are called Mandræ and Subagri, and.
tgt_text.4254: they brought against him eight hundred thousand footl and sixty thousand horse, and they were long contending before either of them could attain the victory over the other, until Alexander at length gained a dishonourable victory.
tgt_text.4255: After that he proceeded to a fortress, when he came to which he could from without see no man in the fortress.
tgt_text.4256: Thereupon Alexander wondered why it was so deserted, and quickly climbed over the wall himself, and he was there dragged in by the inhabitants, and they then assailed him so violently that it is incredible to relate, both with arrows and casting of stones, as well as with all their warlike devices;
tgt_text.4257: and yet all the inhabitants could not compel him, a single man, to surrender to them.
tgt_text.4258: But when the people pressed on him most violently, he slept to the angle of a wall and there defended himself.
tgt_text.4259: And thus were all the people hindered by him alone, so that none guarded the wall, until Alexander's followers broke down the wall opposite to him and came in.
tgt_text.4260: There was Alexander pierced with an arrow underneath one of his breasts.
tgt_text.4261: We know not now which is most to be wondered at, how he alone defended himself against all the inhabitants, or, on the other hand, when aid came to him, how he pressed through that people, so that he slew the same who had before shot him;
tgt_text.4262: or again, the conduct of his followers, when they knew without a doubt that their lord was in the power of their enemies, either alive or dead, that they, nevertheless, would not cease from breaking down the wall, [and]'that they did not avenge their lord, although they found him faint, resting on his knee.
tgt_text.4263: After he had reduced the city to subjection he pro­ ceeded to another city, in which the king Ambira dwelt, where many of Alexander's army perished by poisoned arrows.
tgt_text.4264: But in that same night a plant was shown to Alexander in a dream;
tgt_text.4265: this he took in the morning, and gave it to the wounded to drink, and they were thereby healed, and afterwards took the city;
tgt_text.4266: and he afterwards re­ turned homewards to Babylon, where ambassadors were awaiting him from all the world, that was, from Spain, and from Africa, and from Gaul, and from all Italy.
tgt_text.4267: So terrible was Alexander when he was in India, in the east of this earth, that those dreaded him who were in the west.
tgt_text.4268: There came to him also ambassadors from many nations to whomno one of Alexander's associates imagined that his name was known, and desired peace of him.
tgt_text.4269: Even after Alex­ ander came home to Babylon, there was in him the greatest thirst after human blood.
tgt_text.4270: But when his associates found that he yet would not desist from war, for he said he would march to Africa, his cup-bearers devised among themselves how they might deprive him of life, and gave him poison to drink.
tgt_text.4273: says Orosius, in how great a delusion men now are in this Christendom;
tgt_text.4274: although [only] some little thing befal them that is un­ pleasant, how bitterly they bewail it.
tgt_text.4275: It is one of these, they either do not know, or they will not know, in what miseries those lived who were before them.
tgt_text.4276: Let them now think how it was with those who were in the power of Alex­ ander, when they who were in the west of this earth so greatly feared him, that they were in such great degradation and such great ignorance, that not only on the dread of the sea, and in the deserts of wild beasts and the various ser­ pent kinds, and in tongues of people, they sought him for peace in the east of this earth.
tgt_text.4277: But we know well that they now, more from fear, neither dare either seek peace so far away, nor, indeed, defend themselves in their cots, when any one seeks them at home;
tgt_text.4278: but [yet] that they criminate these times.
tgt_text.4279: After Rome had been built four hundred and fifty years, under the two consuls, one of whom was called Fabius, and, by another name, Maximus, and under him who was named Quintus, and, by another name, Decius, in their consulship four of the strongest nations in Italy, the Umbrians, the Etruscans, the Samnites, and the Gauls, agreed among them­ selves to make war on the Romans;
tgt_text.4280: and they greatly dreaded how they might finally withstand them, and diligently planned how they might divide them, and sent a powerful army to harry on the Etruscans, and on the Umbrians, and to ruin that people.
tgt_text.4281: When they were apprized of that, they returned homewards, that they might defend their country ;
tgt_text.4282: and the Romans in the meanwhile with their large force, which they had at home, marched against the Samnites and against the Gauls.
tgt_text.4283: There in that war, Quintus, the consul, was slain, and Fabius, the other consul, after the other's fall, gained a victory.
tgt_text.4284: Of the Samnites and Gauls forty thou­ sand were there slain, and seven thousand of the Romans, in that part where Decius was slain.
tgt_text.4285: Now Livy has said, that of the Samnites and Gauls a hundred and fifty thousand foot were slain, and seven thousand horse.
tgt_text.4286: I have also heard say for a truth, says Orosius, that with the Romans in those days it was nothing but war, either against other nations or among themselves, together with manifold plagues and pes­ tilences as then were.
tgt_text.4287: When the consul Fabius returned homewards from that war, they brought a triumph to meet him, as was their custom when they had victory.
tgt_text.4288: But joy was very quickly turned in their minds to grief, when they saw the dead bodies so thickly borne to earth, that had been previously at home;
tgt_text.4289: because the great pestilence was there at that time.
tgt_text.4290: And about a year afterwards the Samnites fought against the Romans and put them to flight, and drove them into Rome, and speedily after that the Samnites changed to another fashion, and covered with silver both their garb and all their weapons, as a token that they would either all live or all fall.
tgt_text.4291: In those days the Romans chose Papirius for their consul, and soon after led an army against the Sam­ nites, although their priests told them from their gods that they (the gods) forbade the war.
tgt_text.4292: But Papirius scoffed much at the priests for their declaration, and, nevertheless, pro­ ceeded on his march, and had as honourable a victory as he before had dishonourably contemned the priests of the gods.
tgt_text.4293: Of the Samnites there were twelve thousand slain and four thousand taken.
tgt_text.4294: And soon after that glorious victory they were again saddened by pestilence, and it was so violent and so lasting, that they at last wittingly sought by devilish arts how they might stay it;
tgt_text.4295: and fetched the image of Æscula­ pius with the immense adder that is called the Epidaurian ;
tgt_text.4296: and they did like as if a similar evil had never before befallen them, and was afterwards never to befal them again.
tgt_text.4297: In the second year after this, Fabius, their consul, who by another parne was called Gurges, fought against the Samnites, and ignominiously fled homewards.
tgt_text.4298: Thereupon the senate woulddepose him, because he had brought the people to flight;
tgt_text.4299: then his father prayed (he was also named Fabius) the senate to forgive his son his crime, and that, with his son, he might a second time march against the Samnites with their whole force:
tgt_text.4301: The father then com­ manded the consul that he with his army should go against (the enemy), and he would stay behind with some of the force.
tgt_text.4302: When he saw that Pontius, the king of the Samnites, had ensnared the consul, his son, and surrounded him with his people, he came to his succour, and greatly encouraged him;
tgt_text.4303: and they took Pontius, the king of the Samnites.
tgt_text.4304: Of the Samnites twenty thousand were there slain, and four thousand taken, together with the king.
tgt_text.4305: There was the war of the Romans and the Samnites ended, because they (the Romans) had taken their king, which they had been carrying on for fifty-nine years.
tgt_text.4306: In the second year after this, Curius, the consul, with the Romans, fought against the Sabines, and slew an infinite number of them, and had the victory;
tgt_text.4307: which may be known by that, that they, the consuls, could not reckon them (the slain).
tgt_text.4308: After Rome had been built four hundred and sixty-three years, when Dolabella and Domitius were consuls in Rome, the Lucani, and Brutii, and Samnites, and the Seno-Galli raised war against the Romans.
tgt_text.4309: Thereupon the Romans sent ambassadors to Gaul [praying] for peace;
tgt_text.4311: They then afterwards sent Cæcilius, their prætor, with an army to where the Gauls and the Brutii were together, and he and the people with him were there slain, that was eighteen thousand.
tgt_text.4312: As often as the Gauls warred with the Romans, the Romans were nearly crushed.
tgt_text.4313: Therefore, ye Romans, says Orosius, when ye are always murmuring about that war which the Goths made on you, why will you not think of the many earlier ones that the Gauls frequently, to your disgrace, have carried on against you?
tgt_text.4314: I shall also record in some measure what the successors of Alexander did in those times, when this took place at Rome, how they ruined themselves with divers wars.
tgt_text.4315: It is, says he, when I think of it, most like as if I were sitting on a high mountain, and then see many fires burning in the smooth field;
tgt_text.4316: so over all the realm of Macedonia, that is, over all the Greater Asia, and the greatest part of Europe, and all Libya, it was nothing but hate and wars.
tgt_text.4317: They who were foremost under Alexander, ravaged with wars there where they reigned after him;
tgt_text.4318: and there where they were not, they caused the greatest terror, like as the bitterest smoke ascends and is then widely dispersed.
tgt_text.4319: Alexander, for twelve years, oppressed and terrified this world under him;
tgt_text.4320: and his successors, for fourteen years after, rent and tore it, most like to when the lion brings his hungry whelps something to eat then they show in that food which of them can tear it the most.
tgt_text.4321: So then did Ptolemæus, one of Alexander's officers, when he united together all Egypt and Arabia, and Laomedon, his other officer, who seized on all Assyria, and Thelenus Cilicia, and Philotas Illyria, and Atropatus the Greater Media, and Stromen the Lesser Media, and Per­ diccas the Lesser Asia, and Susana the Greater Phrygia, and Antigonus Lycia and Pamphylia, and Nearchus Caria, and Leonnatus the Lesser Phrygia, and Lysimachus Thrace, and Eumenes Cappadocia and Paphlagonia;
tgt_text.4322: and Seleucus had all the noblest men of Alexander's army, and at length with them he acquired all the east lands, and Cassander the common soldiers, together with the Chaldeans.
tgt_text.4323: And in Bactria and in India were those prefects whom Alexander had appointed;
tgt_text.4324: and Taxiles had the land between the two rivers, the Indus and the Hydaspes, and Pitbon had the colonies, nations in India, and Oxyartes had the Parapar­ meni at the end of Mount Caucasus, and Sibyrtius had the Arachosii and Gedrosia, and Stasanor had the nations of the Drangæ and the Arei, and Amyntas had the Bactrian people, and Scythæus had the Sogdiani, and Nicanor had the Par­ thians, and Philippus the Hyrcanians, and Phratapbernes had Armenia, and Tlepolemus had the Medes, and Peucestes had the Babylonians, and Arcbon had the Pelasgi, and Archelaus Mesopotamia.
tgt_text.4325: All their wars arose first from Alexander's epistle, because he therein commanded, that all the exiles should be permitted [to return to their] country, who were in those lands which he himself had previously ravaged.
tgt_text.4326: Then the Greeks would not obey that command, because they dreaded, when they were all gathered [to­ gether], that they would avenge on them the injuries that they had previously suffered with them;
tgt_text.4328: to obey Lacedaemonia, where their chief city was.
tgt_text.4329: And soon afterwards, the Athenians led thirty thousand men and two hundred ships against the king Antigonus, who was to have all the Grecian realm, because he was the messenger of that errand from Alexander;
tgt_text.4330: and they ap­ pointed for their leader Demosthenes, the philosopher, and drew to their support the inhabitants of Corinth, and Sicyon, and Argos, and besieged the king Antipater in a fortress, because he was a supporter of Antigonus.
tgt_text.4331: There was Leo­ sthenes, another of their leaders, shot with an arrow.
tgt_text.4332: When they were [returning] homewards from that city, they met Leonnatus, who was coming to the aid of Antipater, and was there slain.
tgt_text.4333: After that, Perdiccas, who had the Lesser Asia, began to war against Ariarathus, king of Cappadocia, and drove him into a fortress, and the inhabitants themselves burnt it on four sides, so that all that were within it perished.
tgt_text.4334: After that, Antigonus and Perdiccas threatened that they would fight with each other, and were long planning about where they should meet, and laid waste many islands in the contest, which of them might draw to him the greater aid.
tgt_text.4335: In that interval, Perdiccas proceeded with an army into Egypt, where Ptolemy was king, because it had been told him that he (Ptolemy) would aid King Antigonus.
tgt_text.4336: There­ upon Ptolemy gathered a great army against him.
tgt_text.4337: While they were proceeding to- meet each other, the two kings, Neoptolemus and Eumenes, fought, and Eumenes put Neo­ ptolemus to flight, so that he came to King Antigonus, and prevailed on him to come unawares upon Eumenes with an army.
tgt_text.4338: Thereupon Antigonus sent himself (Neoptolemus) and his other officer, Polyperchon, with a large force, that they might take him by surprise.
tgt_text.4339: When Eumenes was in­ formed of that, he beset them where they had thought to beset him, and slew them both, and put the others to flight.
tgt_text.4340: After that Perdiccas and Ptolemy fought, and Perdiccas was there slain.
tgt_text.4341: After that, it became known to the Macedonians that Eumenes, and Pithon, and Illyrius, and Alceta, the brother of Perdiccas, would make war on them, and settled that Antigonus should go against them with an army.
tgt_text.4342: In the battle Antigonus put Eumenes to flight, and drove him into a fortress, and there besieged him.
tgt_text.4343: Thereupon Eumenes sent to King Antipater, and implored his aid.
tgt_text.4344: When Anti­ gonus was apprized of that, he abandoned the siege.
tgt_text.4345: But Eumenes, expecting from Antigonus a homeward march of great perfidies, would draw to him the aid of those who had been previously Alexander's soldiers, who were called Agyr­ aspidæ, because all their weapons were silvered over.
tgt_text.4346: While in doubt whether they, though with no zeal, should fulfil his wishes, Antigonus came upon them with an army, and took from them their wives, and their children, and their land, and all the treasure, which they had acquired under Alex­ ander;
tgt_text.4347: and they themselves with difficulty fled to Eumenes.
tgt_text.4348: After that they sent to Antigonus, on account of this great contumely, and prayed him that he would restore that of which he had previously bereft them.
tgt_text.4349: He thereupon an­ nounced to them that he would grant it them, if they would bring to him King Eumenes bound, who was at that time their lord;
tgt_text.4351: But he afterwards both received them with contumely, and also set them on the most squalid land, which was at the extreme end of his people, and, at the same time, would restore them nothing that they had prayed for.
tgt_text.4352: After that, Eurydice, the queen of Arridæus, king of Macedon, did much evil to the people, through Cassander, her lord's minister, with whom she had secretly criminal intercourse, and during which she persuaded the king that he so raised him up, that he was above all who were in the kingdom [next] to the king;
tgt_text.4353: and by her counsel she was the cause that all the Macedonians were hostile to the king, until they resolved on sending for Olympias, the mother of Alexander, that she might support them, that they might compel both the king and the queen to their will.
tgt_text.4354: Then she, Olympias, came to them with a force of Epirots, of her own realm, and requested aid from Æacidas, king of the Molossians, and they slew both the king and the queen, and Cassander fled;
tgt_text.4355: and Olympias succeeded to the kingdom, and did much that was hostile to the people while she had the government.
tgt_text.4356: When Cassander was apprized that she was detested by the people, he gathered an army.
tgt_text.4357: When she was informed that so many of the people had turned to him, she did not trust that the other part would be obedient to her, but took her daughter-in-law, Roxane, Alexander's relict, and Alexander's son, Hercules, and fled to the fortress which was called Pydna;
tgt_text.4358: and Cassander followed her, and took the fortress, and slew Olympias ;
tgt_text.4359: and the inhabitants carried off the daughter-in-law with her son, when they were aware that the fortress would be taken, and sent them to another stronger fortress ;
tgt_text.4360: and Cassander ordered them to be besieged there, and wielded all the power of the Macedonian realm.
tgt_text.4361: Now, it was imagined that the war among Alex­ ander's successors was ended, when those had fallen who had most contended in it, namely, Perdiccas, and Eumenes, and Alceta, and Polyperchon, and Olympias, and Antipater, and many others.
tgt_text.4362: But Antigonus, who immoderately desired power over others, proceeded to the fortress where Alex­ ander's relict was with his son, and got them, because he would that the people should the more readily submit to him, when he had their old lord's son in his power.
tgt_text.4363: When Cassander was informed of that, he made a league with Ptolemy, and Lysimachus, and with Seleucus, the east king, and they all made war on Antigonus, and on Demetrius, his son, some on land, some on water.
tgt_text.4364: In that war the greatest part of the flower of Macedonia fell, although some were with Antigonus, some with Cassander.
tgt_text.4365: There was Anti­ gonus with his son put to flight.
tgt_text.4366: After that Demetrius, the son of Antigonus, fought in ships against Ptolemy, and drove him to his own country.
tgt_text.4367: After that Antigonus commanded that the people should call both him and his son king ;
tgt_text.4368: be­ cause Alexander's successors had not previously been so called, but generals.
tgt_text.4369: In the midst of these wars, Antigonus dreaded Hercules, the son of Alexander, lest the people should choose him for sovereign, because he was of the right royal race:
tgt_text.4370: he therefore commanded both him and his mother to be slain.
tgt_text.4371: When the three were informed that he intended to deceive them all, they again assembled and warred against him.
tgt_text.4372: But Cassander himself durst not join in the expedition, on account of his nearest enemies, who were about him ;
tgt_text.4373: but sent his force to his ally, Lysimachus.
tgt_text.4374: His councillors had also bethought themselves of Seleucus, because he had conquered many states by wars in the east countries, namely, first the Babylonians and the Bactrians, and after that he marched to India, where no man, before or since, durst march with an army, save Alexander.
tgt_text.4375: And he, Seleucus, reduced all the generals to his obedience, and they all sought Antigonus and his son, Demetrius, with an army.
tgt_text.4376: In that war Antigonus was slain, and his son driven from the kingdom.
tgt_text.4377: I do not imagine, says Orosius, that there was any one who could tell what [number] perished in that war.
tgt_text.4378: At that time Cassander died, and his son, Philip, suc­ ceeded to the kingdom.
tgt_text.4379: Then again, a second time, people imagined that the war of Alexander's successors was ended.
tgt_text.4380: But soon after, they warred among themselves;
tgt_text.4381: and Seleucus, and Demetrius, the son of Antigonus, made a league toge­ ther, and warred against the three, against Philip, the son of Cassander, and against Ptolemy, and against Lysimachus;
tgt_text.4382: and they entered upon that war just as if they had not pre­ viously begun it.
tgt_text.4383: In that war Antipater slew his mother, the relict of Cassander, although she miserably begged her life of him.
tgt_text.4384: Thereupon Alexander, her son, prayed Deme­ trius to aid him, that he might avenge his mother's death on his brother ;
tgt_text.4385: and they soon after slew him.
tgt_text.4386: After that Demetrius and Lysimachus made war;
tgt_text.4387: but Lysimachus could not withstand Demetrius, because Dorus, king of Thrace, also made war on him.
tgt_text.4388: Then was Demetrius at that time greatly elated, and led an army against Ptolemy.
tgt_text.4389: When he received intelligence of that, he got Seleucus to aid him, and also Pyrrhus, king of the Epirots.
tgt_text.4390: And Pyrrhus chiefly supported him, because he was craftily aiming at the domi­ nion over Macedonia;
tgt_text.4391: and they then drove Demetrius from it, and Pyrrhus took possession [of the kingdom].
tgt_text.4392: After that Lysimachus slew both his own son, Agathocles, and Antipater, his son-in-law.
tgt_text.4393: In those days the city of Lysi­ machia sank into the earth with all its inhabitants.
tgt_text.4394: And after Lysimachus had so acted towards his son and his son- in-law, his own people shunned him, and many turned from him, and prevailed on Seleucus to deceive Lysimachus.
tgt_text.4395: Not even yet could the grudge between the two be allayed, although at that time no more of them were living who had been followers of Alexander;
tgt_text.4396: but old as they then were, theyfought.
tgt_text.4397: Seleucus was seventy-seven years [old], and Lysi­ machus was seventy-three.
tgt_text.4398: There was Lysimachus slain, and three days after came Ptolemy, whose sister Lysimachus had married, and marched secretly after Seleucus, as he was pro­ ceeding homewards, until his army was dispersed, and slew him.
tgt_text.4399: Then that peace and mercy which they had learned from Alexander, were ended.
tgt_text.4400: That was, that those two, who lived the longest, had slain thirty kings, their own old com­ panions, and afterwards had for themselves all the dominions, which they [the thirty] had previously had during those wars.
tgt_text.4401: Lysimachus lost his fifteen sons, some he himself slew, some were slain in the wars before his eyes.
tgt_text.4402: Such brotherhood, says Orosius, they held among themselves, who were nurtured and instructed in one family, that it is now to us rather ridiculous that we complain, and that we now call it war, when strangers and foreigners come upon us, and plunder us of some little, and again quickly leave us, and will not think how it then was, when no man could buy his life of another, nor even would those be friends, who were brothers by father and by mother.
tgt_text.4404: Rome had been built four hundred and sixty-four years, the Tarentine people were playing in their city of Tarentum, at their theatre, which had been therein built, when they saw Roman ships running on the sea.
tgt_text.4405: There­ upon the Tarentines went quickly to their own ships and sailed after them, and got them all into their power, save five, and those who were there taken they treated with the greatest barbarity:
tgt_text.4406: some they slew, some they scourged, some they sold for money.
tgt_text.4407: When the Romans were informed of that, they sent envoys to them, and demanded reparation for what had been done to [excite] their indignation.
tgt_text.4408: They then treated the envoys with the greatest ignominy, as they had before done the others, and afterwards let them go home.
tgt_text.4409: After that, the Romans marched against the Tarentines, and so completely took [all] their force with them, that [even] their proletarii might not remain behind.
tgt_text.4410: These were those whom they had appointed that they might beget children by their wives, while they went forth to war, and said that it seemed to them wiser not to dispense with those who there went forth, let whoever might have children.
tgt_text.4411: The Romans then came upon the Tarentines, and there laid waste all that they found, and took many towns.
tgt_text.4412: There­ upon the Tarentines sent everywhere for aid, where they could expect any:
tgt_text.4413: and Pyrrhus, king of Epirus, came to them with the greatest aid, both of foot and horse.
tgt_text.4414: He was, in those days, famed above all other kings, as well for his great army as for his counsels, and for his military skill.
tgt_text.4415: Pyrrhus aided the Tarentines, because the city of Tarentum had been built by the Lacedæmonians, who were then under his government;
tgt_text.4416: and he had the Thessalians to aid him, and the Macedonians;
tgt_text.4417: and he had twenty elephants with him for that war, which [animals] the Romans had not before seen :
tgt_text.4418: he was the first man who introduced them into Italy:
tgt_text.4419: he was also in those days the most expert in battle and warfare, except only that his gods and his idols that he worshiped deceived him.
tgt_text.4420: When he inquired of his gods, which of them should have victory over the other, he over the Romans, or the Romans over him, they answered him ambiguously:
tgt_text.4421: " Thou wilt have it or not have it."
tgt_text.4422: The first battle that he had with the Romans was in Campania, near the river called the Liris.
tgt_text.4423: There, after a great slaughter was made on both sides, Pyrrhus commanded the elephants to be led into the battle.
tgt_text.4424: When the Romans saw that such a wile was prac.
tgt_text.4425: tised on them, such as they before had not seen nor heard spoken of, they fled, all save one man, who was called Minutius.
tgt_text.4426: He ventured [to go] under an elephant, so that he stabbed it in the navel.
tgt_text.4427: When it was angry and wounded it slew many of the people, so that both those perished who were upon it, and he also wounded and irritated the other elephants, so that most of those also perished who were on them;
tgt_text.4428: and although the Romans were put to flight, they were, nevertheless, emboldened by knowing how they should [act] with elephants.
tgt_text.4429: In that battle fourteen thousand foot of the Romans were slain, and eight hundred and eighty taken prisoners;
tgt_text.4430: and of the horse there were slain one thou­ sand three hundred;
tgt_text.4431: and there were seven hundred ensigns taken.
tgt_text.4432: It was not said how many of Pyrrhus's people were slain, because it was not the custom in those times to count any slaughter on that side which was the prevailing one, unless a very small number were slain, as it was with Alex­ ander, in the first battle he fought against Darius, where of his people there were no more than nine slain.
tgt_text.4433: But Pyrrhus testified afterwards how he liked the victory he had over the Romans, when at the door of his god he said, and thereon so wrote it:
tgt_text.4434: " Have thanks, thou Jove, that I have been able to overcome those who before had not been overcome;
tgt_text.4435: and I am also overcome by them."
tgt_text.4436: His officers thereupon asked him why he said such debasing words of himself, that he was overcome, when he answered:
tgt_text.4437: " If I again gain such a vic­ tory over the Romans, I may afterwards return to Greece without any soldier "
tgt_text.4438: For the Romans also it appeared as an evil token, before the battle, when they were in camp, that there would be a great fall of the people, when thunder slew twenty-four of their fodderers, and the others came away half-dead.
tgt_text.4439: After that Pyrrhus and the Romans fought in the country of Apulia, where Pyrrhus was wounded in one of his arms, and the Romans had the victory, and had learned more devices, how they might circumvent the elephants, by taking stakes, into one end of which they drove many sharp iron nails, and wound flax about them and set it on fire, and then drove it into the hinder part of the elephant, so that they ran raging mad, both in consequence of the burning of the flax and the pricking of the nails;
tgt_text.4440: so that with every one those first perished that were upon them;
tgt_text.4441: and afterwards they as impetuously slew the other people as they should have protected them.
tgt_text.4442: In that battle eight thousand of the Romans were slain and eleven ensigns taken.
tgt_text.4443: And of Pyrrhus's army twenty thousand were slain, and [fifty-three] of his ensigns taken.
tgt_text.4444: It then became known to Pyrrhus, that Agathocles, king of the citizens of Syracuse, was dead in the land of Sicily.
tgt_text.4445: Thereupon he proceeded thither, and subjected that realm to him.
tgt_text.4446: As soon as that war with the Romans was ended, there was such a complicated pestilence with mortality, that even nothing bearing, neither women nor cattle could bring forth anything living;
tgt_text.4447: so that at last they were in despair whether any man should be born to them.
tgt_text.4448: Pyrrhus then turnedfrom Sicily again to the Romans, and Curius, the consul, came against turn, and their third battle was in Lucania, on the mountain of Arusius.
tgt_text.4449: Although the Romans had for some while thought more of flight than of fighting, before they saw that the enemy brought the elephants into the battle;
tgt_text.4450: yet after they saw how they could irritate them, so that they impetuously slew those whom they should aid, Pyrrhus's army was chiefly on that account put to flight.
tgt_text.4451: In that battle Pyrrhus had eighty thousand foot and five thousand horse, and there were thirty-six thousand slain and four hundred captured.
tgt_text.4452: After that Pyrrhus departed from Italy, about five years from the time he first came thither;
tgt_text.4453: and soon after he came home, he would take the city of Argos, and was there mortally struck with a stone.
tgt_text.4454: After the Tarentines had been informed that Pyrrhus was dead, they sent to Africa, to the Carthaginians, for succour, and again warred against the Romans;
tgt_text.4455: and quickly after they came together the Romans had the victory.
tgt_text.4456: There the Carthaginians found that they could be overcome, although no people had before been able to conquer them in war.
tgt_text.4457: While Pyrrhus was warring against the Romans, they had eight legions.
tgt_text.4458: They then appointed the eighth to aid the people of Rhegium.
tgt_text.4459: When this eighth part of the legions felt not confident that the Romans could withstand Pyrrhus, they began to plunder and oppress those whom they should protect.
tgt_text.4460: When the Romans were informed of that, they sent thither their consul Genucius with a force, in order that he might take vengeance on them, for slaying and op­ pressing those whom all the Romans should protect;
tgt_text.4462: Some he slew, bound and sent some home, and there they were afterwards scourged, and their heads afterwards cut off with axes.
tgt_text.4463: After the city of Rome had been built four hundred and seventy-seven years, there happened in Rome evil prodigies.
tgt_text.4464: The first was, that thunder struck the house of their highest god, Jove;
tgt_text.4465: and also much of the city-wall fell to the earth;
tgt_text.4466: and also three wolves, in one night, brought a dead man's body into the city, and there afterwards tore it piecemeal,until the men awoke and ran out, and they afterwards fled away.
tgt_text.4467: In those days it betel, that on a hill near the city of Rome, the earth opened and there was burning fire up from the earth, so that on each side of the fire, the earth, for the breadth of five acres, was burnt to ashes.
tgt_text.4468: Soon after this, in the following year, Sempronius the consul marched with an army against the Picentes, a people of Italy.
tgt_text.4469: Then, when they had put themselves in array, and would engage, there was an earthquake, so that both people imagined indubitably that they would sink into the earth, and they, nevertheless, continued thus dreading until the terror had passed over, and afterwards there fiercely fought.
tgt_text.4470: There was a vast bloodshed of those people on both sides, though the Romans bad the victory, when few were left there.
tgt_text.4471: There was seen that the earthquake betokened the great blood-drenchings which they let flow on her.
tgt_text.4472: After Rome had been built four hundred and eighty years, among many other wonders that happened in those days, blood was seen to boil from the earth, and milk to rain from the heavens.
tgt_text.4473: In those days the Carthaginians sent succour to the Tarentines, that they might the more easily fight against the Romans.
tgt_text.4474: Thereupon the Romans sent messengers to them, and asked them why they so did ?
tgt_text.4475: They then swore to the messengers with a most shameful oath, that they bad never afforded them aid;
tgt_text.4476: although those oaths were nearer to falsehood than to truth.
tgt_text.4477: In those days, the nations of the Vulsinienses and Etruscans almost all nearly perished through their own folly, because they had freed some of their slaves, and were also too mild to them all, and too indulgent.
tgt_text.4478: Then their churls took it ill that the lords had freed the slaves, and would not [free] them.
tgt_text.4479: They thereupon rose against the lords, and the slaves with them, until they were stronger than they.
tgt_text.4480: And they afterwards entirely drove them from the country, and took for wives those who had previously been their mistresses.
tgt_text.4481: Afterwards the lords applied to the Romans, and they aided them, so that they again came to their own.
tgt_text.4482: After Rome had been built four hundred and eighty years, a great mortality came on the Romans, so that at last they did not ask how many had died, but how many of them then remained.
tgt_text.4483: And also the devils, whom they constantly wor­ shiped, led them astray, in addition to the other manifold scandals that they taught them, so that they could not under­ stand that it was the vengeance of God;
tgt_text.4484: but commanded the priests to tell the people that their gods were wroth with them, in order that they might more frequently offer and sacrifice to them than they had ere done.
tgt_text.4485: At the same time it happened that a vestal of their gods, who was named Capparonia, committed incontinence.
tgt_text.4486: For that crime the Romans hanged her, and also him who bad perpetrated the crime with her, and all those who were privy to the crime, and concealed it among themselves.
tgt_text.4487: How can we now imagine, that the Romans themselves wrote and composed such [narratives] for their own glory and praise, and yet, in the midst of the praise, have related such disgraces of them­ selves ?
tgt_text.4488: How many may we imagine greater disgraces they have passed in silence, both for love of themselves and countrymen, as well as for fear of their senate ?
tgt_text.4490: We will now, says Orosius, begin concerning the Carthaginian war (that was of the people of the city of Carthage, that was built by the woman .Elisa eighty-two years before Rome), as of the calamities of the citizens and their disasters little has been said and written, as Trogus and Justinus, the historians, have related;
tgt_text.4491: because their affairs at no time succeeded well, neither within among themselves, nor without from other nations.
tgt_text.4492: And yet, in addition to these evils, they decreed, when a great pestilence came upon them, that they should sacrifice men to their gods.
tgt_text.4493: In like manner, the devils, in whom they believed, instructed them, that for those who were unhealed there they should slay the hale;
tgt_text.4494: and men were so foolish, that they imagined they might thereby still the evil, and the devils so crafty that they thereby aug­ mented it.
tgt_text.4495: And because they were so very foolish, the vengeance of God came upon them, in wars, besides otherevils.
tgt_text.4496: That was oftenest in the islands of Sicily and Sardinia, in which they most frequently warred.
tgt_text.4497: After they had so often been unsuccessful, they began to blame their generals and their soldiers for their disasters, and commanded them to go into exile and banishment.
tgt_text.4498: Shortly after, they prayed to be re-admitted to their country, that they might try whether they could overcome their bad fortune.
tgt_text.4499: When this was refused them, they attempted with an army.
tgt_text.4500: In the ravage, the general-in-chief, Mazeus, met his own son clad in purple, though one of the priesthood.
