tgt_text.4501: On account of that garment he was incensed, and he commanded him to be seized and crucified;
tgt_text.4502: and thought that in contempt of him he wore such a garment;
tgt_text.4503: because it is not a custom with them that any other should be clad in purple but kings.
tgt_text.4504: Shortly after this they got the city of Carthage, and slew all the chiefs that were in it, and reduced the others to sub­ jection.
tgt_text.4505: Then at last, he was himself circumvented and slain.
tgt_text.4506: This happened in the days of Cyrus, king of the Persians.
tgt_text.4507: After that Himilco, king of Carthage, proceeded with an army to Sicily, and there came upon them such a sudden evil, that men were dead as soon as it came upon them, so that at last they could not bury them;
tgt_text.4508: and from fear against his will departed, and proceeded home with those that there were.
tgt_text.4509: As soon as the first ship reached the land and an­ nounced the fearful intelligence, then were all the Cartha­ ginian citizens affected with violent groaning and weeping, and every one asking and inquiring after his friends, and would positively believe nothing true, but that they must all have perished.
tgt_text.4510: While the citizens were engaged on so mournful a subject, the king himself came with his ship, and landed in a very squalid garment, and both he himself pro­ ceeded homewards, and the people who had come to meet him, all followed him homewards weeping;
tgt_text.4511: and he, the king, stretched out his hands upwards towards heaven, and with overflowing heart, bewailed both his own hard fortune and that of all the people;
tgt_text.4512: and he, moreover, did to himself that which was worst, when he came to his house, when he there shut the people out, and locked himself therein alone, and slew himself.
tgt_text.4513: After that, there was a wealthy man in Carthage, who was named Hanno, and was immoderately craving after the kingship.
tgt_text.4514: But it seemed to him that with the will of the senators he could not attain it, and he took the resolution that he would bid them all to a feast, in order that he might then kill them by poison.
tgt_text.4515: But it was divulged through those who he had thought would have aided him in the deed.
tgt_text.4516: When he found that it was known, he gathered all the slaves and the evil men that he could, and thought that he could come on the citizens unawares;
tgt_text.4517: but it had been previously made known to them.
tgt_text.4518: When he did not succeed at the city, he betook himself with twenty-four thousand to another city, and thought he could capture it.
tgt_text.4519: But the citizens had the Mauritanians to aid them, and came against him outside the fortress, and took Hanno, and put the others to flight, and there he was afterwards tortured.
tgt_text.4520: First they scourged him, then put his eyes out, and afterwards struck off his hands, then his head, and slew all his kin, lest they at a future day might avenge it, or any other might again dare the like.
tgt_text.4521: This happened in the days of Philip the king.
tgt_text.4522: After that, the Carthaginians heard that the Great Alexander had taken the city of Tyre, which, in days of old, was the country of their forefathers, and dreaded lest they should also come to them.
tgt_text.4523: Thereupon they sent Amilcar thither, their most expert man, that he might observe Alexander's move­ ments, so that he might announce it to them at home written on a board;
tgt_text.4524: and after it was written, he worked it over with wax.
tgt_text.4525: After Alexander was dead and he was come home, the senators of the city accused him of having acted treache­ rously towards them with Alexander, and for that accusation slew him.
tgt_text.4526: After that the Carthaginians made war on Sicily, where they seldom succeeded well, and besieged their chief city called Syracuse.
tgt_text.4527: Then it did not seem advisable to Agathocles, their king, that he should fight with them outside his fortress, nor also that, on account of want of food, they should all remain within it;
tgt_text.4528: but let a part of their force be within, both that they might hold their fastness, and also that during that while they might have food;
tgt_text.4529: and the king with the other part proceeded in ships to the Carthaginian territory, and immediately after he had reached land com-manded them to be burnt, because he would not that his enemies should have afterwards any power over them ;
tgt_text.4530: and he there speedily constructed a fortress, and was driving out the people thence and oppressing them, until Hanno, the people's other king, sought him at the fortress with twenty thousand men.
tgt_text.4531: But Agathocles put him to flight, and slew two thousand of his people, and followed after him to within five miles of the Carthaginian city, and there constructed another fortress, and there about was harrying and burning, so that the Carthaginians might see the fire from their city, and the calamity, while they were [out] in the expedition.
tgt_text.4532: About the time that this was, the brother of Agathocles, who was named Andro, whom he had left behind him at home in the city, overcame by artifice the army that had besieged him, in one night unexpectedly, and slew them almost all, and the others fled to their ships.
tgt_text.4533: And immediately after they came home, and the intelligence became known to the Cartha­ ginians, they were so despised, that not only many cities became tributaries to Agathocles, but also surrendered to him in bodies.
tgt_text.4534: So also Ophellas, the king, with Cyrene, his people, likewise sought him.
tgt_text.4535: But Agathocles acted treacherously towards him, by deceiving him into a compact with him, and slew him ;
tgt_text.4536: as it happened afterwards also to himself.
tgt_text.4537: If he had not done that one act of treachery, he might from that day, without difficulty have acquired the rule over all the Carthaginians.
tgt_text.4538: During the time that he was following that evil counsel, Bomilcar, the Punic king, was peaceably marching towards him with all his people.
tgt_text.4539: But there was dissension between Agathocles and his people, so that he himself was slain.
tgt_text.4540: After his death the Cartha­ ginians proceeded again to Sicily with ships.
tgt_text.4541: When they (the Sicilians) were apprized of that, they sent for Pyrrhus, king of Epirus, and he for some time aided them.
tgt_text.4542: After Rome had been built four hundred and eighty-three years, the Mamertini, a Sicilian people, sent to the Ro­ mans for aid, that they might withstand the Punic people.
tgt_text.4543: Whereupon they sent to them the consul, Appius Claudius, with aid.
tgt_text.4544: Then after they had proceeded together with their people, the Carthaginians fled, as they themselves said afterwards;
tgt_text.4545: and they wondered that they fled before they had engaged together.
tgt_text.4546: Through that flight, Hanno, the Punic king, with all his subjects, became tributaries to the Romans, and paid them every year two hundred talents of silver, in each single talent were eighty pounds.
tgt_text.4547: After that the Romans besieged the elder Annibal, the Punic king, in Agrigentum, a city of Sicily, until he nearly perished with hunger.
tgt_text.4548: Then the other Punic king, who was named Hanno, came to his aid with a fleet, and was there put to flight, and the Romans afterwards took the fortress, and the king, Annibal, fled away by night with a few men, and gathered eighty ships, and pillaged on the Roman coasts.
tgt_text.4549: In re­ taliation, the Romans first resolved to construct ships, which Duilius, their consul, promoted, so that the undertaking was speedily accomplished;
tgt_text.4550: so that after sixty days from the time that the timber was cut, a hundred and thirty were ready, both with mast and sail;
tgt_text.4551: and the other consul, who was named Cornelius Asina, proceeded to the island of Lipara with sixteen ships, to a private conference with Annibal, when he slew him.
tgt_text.4552: When Duilius, the other consul, heard that, he proceeded to the island with thirty ships, and slew three hundred of Annibal's people, and took thirty of his ships, and sank thirteen in the sea, and put himself to flight.
tgt_text.4553: After that the Pœni, that is, the Cartha­ ginians, placed Hanno over their ships, as Annibal had previously been, that he might defend the islands of Sardinia and Corsica against the Romans;
tgt_text.4554: and he soon after fought against them with a fleet and was slain.
tgt_text.4555: In the year after this, the consul Calatinus proceeded with an army to Camerina, a city of Sicily;
tgt_text.4556: but the Carthaginians had beset the way, where he was to pass over the mountain.
tgt_text.4557: Calatinus thereupon took with him three hundred men and ascended the mountain at a secret place, and the men feared that they were all fighting against them, and left the way without defence, so that the army afterwards passed there- through;
tgt_text.4558: and there were all the three hundred men slain, save the consul alone;
tgt_text.4560: After that the Carthaginians again appointed the old Annibal to make war on the Romans with ships;
tgt_text.4561: but again, when he was about to harry there, he was quickly put to flight, and in the flight his own companions stoned him to death.
tgt_text.4562: After that the consul Atilius laid waste the Sicilian islands of Lipara and Melita.
tgt_text.4563: After that the Romans proceeded to Africa with four hundred and thirty ships.
tgt_text.4564: Thereupon they sent their two kings, Hanno and Amilcar, against them with ships;
tgt_text.4565: and there were both put to flight, and the Romans took from them eighty-four ships, and they afterwards took their city of Clupea, and harried as far as their chief city, Carthage.
tgt_text.4566: After that the consul Regulus undertook the Carthaginian war.
tgt_text.4567: When he first came thither with an army, he en­ camped near a river that was named Bagrada, when there came from the water a serpent that was enormously large, and slew all the men that came near the water.
tgt_text.4569: Thereupon Regulus gathered all the archers that were in the expedition, that they might overcome it with arrows;
tgt_text.4570: but when they struck or shot at it, it (the missile) glided on its scales as if they were smooth iron.
tgt_text.4571: He then commanded that with the balistas, with which they break walls when they fight against a fortress, they should cast at it obliquely.
tgt_text.4572: Thereupon with one cast one of its ribs was broken, so that afterwards it had no power to protect itself, but shortly after was slain;
tgt_text.4573: because it is the nature of serpents, that their power and their locomotive faculty is in their ribs, as of other creeping worms it is in their feet.
tgt_text.4574: When it was killed, he ordered it to be flayed and the hide brought to Rome, and there to be stretched out as a wonder;
tgt_text.4575: because it was a hundred and twenty feet long.
tgt_text.4576: After that, Regulus fought against three Punic kings, in one battle, against the two Asdrubals, and the third called Amilcar, who was in Sicily, [but] fetched to aid them.
tgt_text.4577: In that battle seventeen thousand Carthaginians were slain, and fifteen thousand captured, and nine elephants taken, and eighty-two towns surrendered to him.
tgt_text.4578: Then, after the Carthaginians had been put to flight, they desired peace from Regulus;
tgt_text.4579: but after they had ascertained that he would have an immoderate tribute for the peace, they said that they would rather that death should destroy them in such [a state of] hate, than that they under such hard conditions should obtain peace.
tgt_text.4580: Thereupon they sent for succour to Gaul, to Spain, and to Lacedæmonia, to the king, Xantippus.
tgt_text.4581: After they were all assembled, they com­ mitted all their military force to Xantippus, and he subse­ quently led those nations to where they had agreed together, and placed two nations secretly on each side of him, and the third behind him, and commanded the two nations, when he himself with the foremost part should flee towards the hind­ most, that they then should march on the army of Regulus, on each side obliquely.
tgt_text.4582: There were slain thirty thousand Romans, and Regulus with five hundred men was taken.
tgt_text.4583: This victory happened to the Carthaginians in the tenth year of their war with the Romans.
tgt_text.4584: Shortly after, Xantippus returned to his own kingdom, and the Romans were fear­ stricken, because by his instruction, in their engagement, they had been overreached.
tgt_text.4585: After that, the consul AEmilius Paulus proceeded to Africa with three hundred ships, to the island of Clupea, and there the Carthaginians came against him with as many ships, and were there put to flight, and five thousand of their people were slain, and thirty of their ships taken, and a hundred and four sunk;
tgt_text.4586: and of the Romans one thousand one hundred were slain, and nine of their ships sunk:
tgt_text.4587: and they constructed a fortress on the island;
tgt_text.4588: and there the Carthaginians again sought them with their two kings, who were called the two Hannos, and there nine thousand of them were slain, and the others put to flight.
tgt_text.4589: With the booty the Romans overloaded their ships when they were [proceeding] homeward, so that two hundred and thirty were lost, and seventy were left, and with difficulty saved, by casting out almost all that was in them.
tgt_text.4590: After that, Amilcar, the Punic king, proceeded to Numidia and to Mauritania, and ravaged them, and made them tributary, because they had before submitted to Regulus.
tgt_text.4591: Six years after, Servilius Cæpio and Sempronius Blæsus, the consuls, proceeded with three hundred and sixty ships to Africa, and took many towns from the Carthaginians, and afterwards with much spoil proceeded homewards, and again so over­ loaded their ships, that a hundred and fifty of them were lost.
tgt_text.4592: After that, the consul Cotta proceeded to Sicily, and ravaged it all;
tgt_text.4593: there were so many slaughters on both sides, that at last they could not be buried.
tgt_text.4594: In the days of the consul Lucius Cælius, and of Metellus Caius, and of Furius Pacilus, Asdrubal, the new king of Carthage, came to the island of Lilybæum with thirty thousand horse, and with a hundred and thirty elephants, and immediately after fought with the king Metellus.
tgt_text.4595: But after Metellus had overcome the elephants, he also quickly put the other people to flight.
tgt_text.4596: After the flight, Asdrubal was slain by his own people.
tgt_text.4597: Then were the Carthaginians so overcome and so perplexed among themselves, that they could not assume to themselves any power, but they determined that they would desire peace of the Romans.
tgt_text.4598: Thereupon they sent the consul Begulus, whom they had had five years with them in bonds ;
tgt_text.4599: and he swore to them, in the name of his gods, that he would both announce the errand, as they commanded him, and also again declare the answer.
tgt_text.4600: And that he so performed, and an­ nounced, that each people should restore to the other all the men that they had captured, and afterwards preserve peace between them.
tgt_text.4601: And after he had announced that, he im.
tgt_text.4602: plored them not to accept aught of the errands, and said, that it would be a great disgrace to them to exchange on such equal terms;
tgt_text.4603: and also that it was not fitting that they should think so meanly of themselves that they were their equals.
tgt_text.4604: Then, after those words, they enjoined him to stay at home with them, and assume the government;
tgt_text.4605: but he answered them and said, that it could not be that he should be a king of nations, who had before been a slave to people.
tgt_text.4606: When his companions had related how he had announced their errands, they cut the two nerves on the two sides of his eyes, so that after that he could not sleep, until thus enduring pain, he yielded up his life.
tgt_text.4607: After that Atilius Regulus and Manlius Vulso, the consuls, proceeded against the Carthaginians, on the isle of Lilybæum, with two hundred ships, and there besieged a fortress.
tgt_text.4608: Then the young king, Annibal, the son of Amilcar, betook him­ self there where unprepared they were sitting about the fortress, and there all were slain save a few.
tgt_text.4609: After that the consul Claudius again proceeded to Carthage, and Annibal met them out at sea and slew them all, except thirty transports that escaped to the island of Lilybaeum.
tgt_text.4610: There were slain nine thousand, and twenty thousand captured.
tgt_text.4611: After that the consul Caius Junius proceeded to Africa, and perished at sea with his whole expedition.
tgt_text.4612: In the year after, Annibal sent a fleet to Rome, and there they committed great ravages.
tgt_text.4613: After that, Lutatius, the consul, proceeded against Africawith three hundred ships to Sicily, and the Carthaginians there fought against him.
tgt_text.4614: There was Lutatius wounded through one knee.
tgt_text.4615: On the morrow came Hanno with Annibal's army, and there fought against Lutatius, although he was wounded, and he put Hanno to flight, and proceeded after him, until he came to the city of Erycina.
tgt_text.4616: Quickly after, the Carthaginians came to him again with an army, and were put to flight, and two thousand slain.
tgt_text.4617: The Carthaginians then a second time sued for peace to the Romans, and they granted it to them on condition that they should not take possession of Sicily nor Sardinia;
tgt_text.4618: and should, moreover, pay them three thousand talents every year.
tgt_text.4619: After Rome had been built five hundred and seven years, there was an immense conflagration among the Romans, and no man knew whence it came.
tgt_text.4620: When the fire ceased, the river Tiber was so swollen as it had never been before nor since;
tgt_text.4621: so that it carried away almost all the sustenance of the people that was within the city, yea, even in their dwell­ ings.
tgt_text.4622: In those days, when Titus Sempronius and Caius Gracchus were consuls at Rome, they fought against the people of the Falisci, and slew twelve thousand of them.
tgt_text.4623: In that year, the Gauls, who are now called Longobards, were hostile to the Romans, and shortly after, led their people together.
tgt_text.4624: In their first battle three thousand of the Romans were slain ;
tgt_text.4625: and in the following year four thousand Gauls were slain, and two thousand captured.
tgt_text.4626: When the Romans were [returning] homeward, they would not make a triumph before their consuls, as was their wont when they had victory, because in the first battle they had fled;
tgt_text.4627: and they for many years after endured that in divers victories.
tgt_text.4628: When Titus Manlius, and Caius Torquatus, and Atilius Bulbus were consuls at Rome, the Sardinians, as the Carthaginians had taught them, began to war against the Romans, and were soon overpowered.
tgt_text.4629: After that the Romans made war on the Carthaginians, because they had broken the peace.
tgt_text.4630: They thereupon sent two of their messengers to Rome for peace, but could not obtain it.
tgt_text.4631: Then, at the third time, they sent ten of their eldest senators, and they could not obtain it.
tgt_text.4632: At the fourth time, they sent Hanno, their unworthiest minister, -and he obtained it.
tgt_text.4633: Verily, says Orosius, we are now come to the good times that the .
tgt_text.4634: Romans twit us with, and to the­ abundance that they are always boasting of before us, [saying] that ours are not like to them.
tgt_text.4635: But let then any one ask them, after how many years the peace was, from the time they first had war with many people ?
tgt_text.4636: It is then after four hundred and fifty years.
tgt_text.4637: Then let him again ask, how long the peace lasted P
tgt_text.4639: Immediately after, in the following year, the Gauls made war.
tgt_text.4640: against the Romans, and, on the other side, the Cartha­ ginians.
tgt_text.4641: How think ye now, Romans, how the peace was established, whether it were not likest to any one taking a drop of oil and dropping it on a great fire, and thinking thereby to quench it, when the probability is much greater that, when he thinks that he quenches it, he makes it burn so much more fiercely ?
tgt_text.4642: So then it was with the Romans, that the one year they had peace, during that peace, they fell into the greatest strife.
tgt_text.4643: In their first war, Amilcar, king of Carthage, when he was about to proceed against the Romans with an army, was surrounded by the Spaniards and slain.
tgt_text.4644: In that year the Illyrians slew the Roman envoys.
tgt_text.4645: After that Fulvius Postumius, the consul, on that account, led an army against them, and many were slain on both sides, yet he had the victory.
tgt_text.4646: Soon after, in the following year, the Roman priests taught, as new doctrines, such as they had very often prac­ tised in former times:
tgt_text.4647: when a war was raging on three sides of them, with the Gauls on the south of the mountains, the Gauls on the north of the mountains, and the Cartha­ ginians, that they should sacrifice for themselves to their gods with human beings, and that should be a Gaulish man and a Gaulish woman.
tgt_text.4648: And the Romans then, by the instruction of their priests, thus buried them alive.
tgt_text.4649: But God avenged it on them, as he had always done before.
tgt_text.4650: So often as they sacrificed with human beings, they paid with their living ones, for having slain the guiltless.
tgt_text.4651: That was first seen in the battle that they had with the Gauls, al­ though their own force was eight hundred thousand, besides other nations that they had drawn to them, when they quicklyfled, because their consul was slain, and of their other people three thousand:
tgt_text.4652: that seemed to them as an immense slaughter, what they had often before regarded as naught.
tgt_text.4653: In their second battle, nine thousand Gauls were slain.
tgt_text.4654: In the third year after this, Manlius Torquatus and Fulvius Flaccus were consuls at Rome.
tgt_text.4655: They fought against the Gauls, and slew a hundred thousand of them and took six thousand.
tgt_text.4656: In the year after, there were many wonders seen.
tgt_text.4657: One was, that in the wood of Picenum a spring welled with blood;
tgt_text.4658: and in the land of Thrace it was seen as if the heavens were burning;
tgt_text.4659: and in the city of Ariminum there was night until mid-day;
tgt_text.4660: and there was so great an earthquake that in Caria and the isle of Rhodes there were great ruins, and the Colossus fell.
tgt_text.4661: In this year, the consul Flaminius despised the sayings that the augurs had said to him, and falsely warned him not to engage in war against the Gauls;
tgt_text.4662: but he carried it through and with honour ended it.
tgt_text.4663: There were seven thousand of the Gauls slain, and fifteen thousand captured.
tgt_text.4664: After that, the consul Claudius fought against the Gauls and slew thirty thousand of them;
tgt_text.4665: and he himself fought with the king in single combat, and slew him, and took the city of Milan.
tgt_text.4666: After that, the Istrians warred against the Romans;
tgt_text.4667: they thereupon sent their consuls, Cornelius and Minucius, against [them].
tgt_text.4668: There was a great slaughter made on both sides, though the Istrians became subjected to the Romans.
tgt_text.4669: After Rome had been built five hundred and thirty-three years, Annibal, the Punic king, besieged Saguntum, a city of Spain, because they had ever held peace with the Romans;
tgt_text.4670: and was sitting there eight months, until he had killed them all by hunger and destroyed the city;
tgt_text.4671: although the Romans sent their messengers to him, and prayed him to abandon the war, but he so injuriously slighted them, that he declined even the sight of them in that war, and also in many others.
tgt_text.4672: After that, Annibal manifested the enmity and hate, that he had sworn before his father, when he was a boy of nine years, that he would never be a friend of the Romans.
tgt_text.4673: When Publius Cornelius, and Publius Scipio, and Sempronius Longus were consuls, Annibal burst with warfare over the mountains called the Pyrenees, that are between Gaul and Spain, and afterwards he traversed many nations, until he came to the mountains of the Alps, and burst across them also, although oftentimes opposed with battle;
tgt_text.4674: and then wrought a way over the mountain [and] so proceeded.
tgt_text.4675: When he came to the rock itself, he commanded it to be heated with fire, and afterwards hewed with mattocks, and with the greatest toil crossed the mountains.
tgt_text.4676: Of his army there were a [hundred] thousand foot and twenty thousand horse.
tgt_text.4677: When he had marched on the plain until he came to the river Ticinus, the consul Scipio came against him, and was there dangerously wounded, and would also have been slain, if his son had not helped him, by placing himself before him, until he betook himself to flight.
tgt_text.4678: There was a great slaughter made of the Romans.
tgt_text.4679: Their second battle was at the river Trebia, and the Romans were again beaten and put to flight.
tgt_text.4680: When Sempronius, their other consul, who was gone with an army to Sicily, heard that, he departed thence, and both consuls proceeded with an army against Annibal, and their meeting was again at the river Trebia, and the Romans [were] also put to flight, and more completely beaten, and Annibal wounded.
tgt_text.4681: After that, Annibal proceeded over the Apennine mountains, although about that time there were such great snow-storms, that of the horses many perished, and all the elephants but one;
tgt_text.4682: yea, the men themselves with difficulty could sustain the cold.
tgt_text.4683: But he ventured across the mountain, chiefly because he knew that the consul Flaminius imagined that he might without apprehension abide in the winter­ station in which he then was with the army he had gathered, and imagined undoubtingly that there was no one who durst or could undertake the passage at that season, on account of the intense cold.
tgt_text.4684: When Annibal came to that land, he en­ camped in a secret place near the other army, and sent some of his people over the country to burn and -pillage;
tgt_text.4685: so that the consul imagined that all the army was dispersed over the land, and proceeded thitherward, and thought he should circumvent them in the plundering, and led the army in dis­ order, as he knew that the other was, until Annibal came upon his flank with the force that he had together, and slewthe consul, and of the other people twenty-five thousand, and six [thousand] were captured;
tgt_text.4686: and of Annibal's people two thousand were slain.
tgt_text.4687: After that, the consul Scipio, the brother of the other Scipio, fought many battles in Spain, and took Mago, a general of the Carthaginians, prisoner.
tgt_text.4688: And many wonders happened at this time.
tgt_text.4689: The first was, that the sun was as if it were all diminished.
tgt_text.4690: The second was, that it was seen as if the sun and moon were fighting.
tgt_text.4691: These wonders happened in the land of Arpi.
tgt_text.4692: And in Sardinia two shields were seen to sweat blood.
tgt_text.4693: And the And people of the Falisci saw the heavens, as it were, cloven.
tgt_text.4694: it seemed to the people of Antium, that, having thrown their bundles of corn into their baskets, all the ears were bloody.
tgt_text.4695: After Rome had been built five hundred and forty years, when Lucius Æmilius, and Paulus Publius, and Terentius Varro were consuls, they marched with an army against Annibal;
tgt_text.4696: but he deceived them by the same stratagem that he had used at their former meeting, and also with a new one which they knew not before;
tgt_text.4697: which was, that he left some of his army in a strong place, and with some marched against the consuls, and as soon as they came together, he fled towards those who were behind, and the consuls pursued him and slew his people, and thought that they on that day should have the greatest victory.
tgt_text.4698: But as soon as Annibal came to his force, he put all the consuls to flight, and made so great a slaughter of the Romans as never had been of them, neither before nor since, in one battle ;
tgt_text.4700: and he slew two of their consuls and captured the third;
tgt_text.4701: and on that day he might have come to the dominion of all the Romans, if he had marched on to the city.
tgt_text.4702: After that Annibal sent home to Carthage three measures of golden rings, in token of his victory.
tgt_text.4703: By the rings might be known how many noble Romans had fallen;
tgt_text.4704: because it was their custom in those days, that no one might wear a golden ring, unless he were of noble lineage.
tgt_text.4706: After that battle the Romans were so very desponding, that Cæcilius Metellus, who was then their consul, yea, all their senate, had resolved to abandon the city of Rome, and, in fact, all Italy;
tgt_text.4707: and they had so done, if Scipio had not restrained them, who was the eldest of the soldiers, when he drew his sword, and swore that he would rather kill himself than abandon his paternal country;
tgt_text.4708: and said also that he would pursue every one of those as his foe, who should give his vote for leaving Rome;
tgt_text.4709: and he, at the same time, compelled them to swear oaths that they would altogether either fall in their country or live in their country.
tgt_text.4710: After that, they appointed a dictator, who should be master over the consuls ;
tgt_text.4712: he was only seventeen years, and Scipio they ap­ pointed consul, and all the men that they had in servitude they freed, on condition that they swore oaths, that they would aid them in the wars ;
tgt_text.4713: and some, whose masters would not, until they were indemnified to enable them, the consuls paid for with their public money, and then freed them;
tgt_text.4714: and all those who had previously been condemned or perpetrated crime, they forgave all, on condition of their rendering full service in the wars.
tgt_text.4715: Of these men there were six thousand, when they were gathered together.
tgt_text.4716: And all Italy deserted from the Romans and turned to Annibal, because they were without hope that the Romans would ever recover their power.
tgt_text.4717: A Annibal then marched on Beneventum, and they came to meet him and turned to him.
tgt_text.4718: After that, the Romans had collected four legions of their people, and sent Lucius Postumius, the consul, against those Gauls that are now called Langobardi, and he was there slain, and many people with him.
tgt_text.4719: After that the Romans appointed Claudius Mar­ cellus for consul, who had previously been the companion of Scipio:
tgt_text.4720: he marched secretly with an overwhelming force against that part of Annibal's army, in which he himself was, and slew many of his people, and put him himself to flight.
tgt_text.4721: Thus did Marcellus make manifest to the Romans, that Annibal could be put to flight, although they had before doubted whether any one with any human force could defeat him.
tgt_text.4722: During these wars, the two Scipios, who were then consuls and also brothers, were in Spain with an army, and fought against Asdrubal, Annibal's uncle, and slew him;
tgt_text.4723: and of his thirty thousand men slew some and captured some:
tgt_text.4724: he was also the Carthaginians' other king.
tgt_text.4725: After that, Centenius Penula, the consul, requested the senate to give him a force,that he might give battle to Annibal, and he was there slain, and eight thousand of his people.
tgt_text.4726: After that, Sempronius Gracchus, the consul, again marched with an army against An­ nibal, and was put to flight, and of his army a great slaughter was made.
tgt_text.4727: How can the Romans now, says Orosius, say with truth, that they had better times then than they now have, when they had, at the same time, undertaken so many wars ?
tgt_text.4728: One was in Spain, a second in Macedonia, a third in Cappa­ docia, a fourth at home against Annibal;
tgt_text.4729: and they were, moreover, oftenest defeated and disgraced.
tgt_text.4730: But it was very manifest that they were better soldiers then than they now are;
tgt_text.4731: that they, nevertheless, would not flinch from the war;
tgt_text.4732: (but they often rested on a little and hopeless foundation), so that at last they had dominion over all those, whom before they had had for their neighbours.
tgt_text.4733: After Rome had been built five hundred and forty-three years, the consul, Claudius Marcellus, proceeded with a fleet to Sicily, and acquired Syracuse, their wealthiest city, al­ though in the former expedition he could not obtain it, when he had besieged it, by reason of the craft of Archi­ medes, a Sicilian officer.
tgt_text.4734: In the tenth year from the time that Annibal made war in Italy, he proceeded from the land of Campania, as far as three miles of Rome, and encamped by the river that is called the Anien, to the great terror of all the Romans ;
tgt_text.4735: as in the conduct of the men it might be understood how frightened and panic-stricken they were;
tgt_text.4736: when the women ran with stones to the walls, and said that they would defend the city, if the men durst not.
tgt_text.4737: On the following morning, Annibal proceeded to the city, and arrayed his army before the gate that is called the Colline.
tgt_text.4738: But the consuls would not think themselves so dastardly as the women had before charged them [with being], that they durst not defend themselves within the city:
tgt_text.4739: but they arrayed themselves against Annibal without the gate.
tgt_text.4740: But when they would join battle, there came such an overwhelm­ ing rain, that none of them could govern any weapon, and they therefore separated.
tgt_text.4741: When the rain had ceased, they came together again, and again there was another such rain, and they again separated.
tgt_text.4742: Then Annibal was sensible, and to himself said, though he was desirous of and hoping for the dominion over the Romans, that God did not permit it.
tgt_text.4743: Tell me now, Romans, says Orosius, when it happened or where, before Christianity, that either ye or others could by prayer obtain rain from any gods as men afterwards could, after Christianity was, and may now yet many blessings of our Saviour Christ, when they have need.
tgt_text.4744: For it was very manifest, that the same Christ, who afterwards converted them to Christianity, sent them the rain as a protection, al­ though they were not worthy of it, in order that they them­ selves, and many others also, through them, might come to Christianity and to true belief.
tgt_text.4745: In the days that this happened there were two consuls slain in Spain, they were brothers, and were both named Scipio.
tgt_text.4746: They were drawn into an ambuscade by Asdrubal, the Punic king.
tgt_text.4747: At that time, the consul, Quintus Fulvius, terrified all the chief men that were in Campania, so that they killed themselves with poison.
tgt_text.4748: And all the chief men that were-in the city of Capua he slew, because he thought that they would be a support to Annibal, although the senate had strongly forbidden him that deed.
tgt_text.4749: When the Romans were informed that the consuls were slain in Spain, the senate could not among themselves find any consul that durst proceed with an army to Spain, except the son of one of the consuls, who was named Scipio, who was a youth.
tgt_text.4750: He earnestly entreated that they would grant him support, that he might lead an army to Spain, and he was chiefly desirous to accomplish this expedition, because he hoped he could avenge his father and his uncle;
tgt_text.4751: although he strictly con­ cealed this from the senate.
tgt_text.4752: But the Romans were so eager for the expedition, although they were greatly broken in their treasure, which they had in common, in consequence of the wars, which they had on four sides, that they gave him all that they had, in aid of the expedition, excepting that every woman retained one ounce of gold and one pound of silver, and every man one ring and one bulla.
tgt_text.4753: When Scipio had marched to the new city of Carthage, which is now called Cordova, he besieged Mago, the brother of Annibal, and because he came unawares on the inhabitants, he in a little time reduced them under his power by hunger, so that the king himself surrendered, and of all the others some he slew, some bound, and sent the king bound to Rome, and with him many of the chief senators.
tgt_text.4754: Within the city a great treasure was found:
tgt_text.4755: some of it Scipio sent to Rome, some he ordered to be divided among his people.
tgt_text.4756: At that time the consul Lævinus proceeded with a fleet from Mace­ donia to Sicily, and there took the city of Agrigentum, and captured Hanno, their leader.
tgt_text.4757: Afterwards forty towns sur­ rendered to him, and twenty-six he gained by warfare.
tgt_text.4758: At that time Annibal slew the consul Cneus Fulvius in Italy, and eight thousand with him.
tgt_text.4759: After that Annibal fought against Marcellus, the consul, for three days:
tgt_text.4760: on the first day, the people fell alike on either side;
tgt_text.4761: on the second day, Annibal had the victory;
tgt_text.4762: on the third day, the consul had.
tgt_text.4763: After that, the consul, Fabius Maximus, proceeded with a fleet to the city of Tarentum, unknown to Annibal, and captured the city by night, so that they knew it not who were therein;
tgt_text.4764: and slew Carthalo, Annibal's general, and thirty thousand with him.
tgt_text.4765: In the year after this, Annibal stole on the consul, Claudius Marcellus, where he sat with his army, and slew him and his people with him.
tgt_text.4766: In those days Scipio put to flight Asdrubal in Spain, the other brother of Annibal, and of that people there surrendered to him eighty towns.
tgt_text.4767: So hateful were the Punic people to Scipio, that, when he had defeated them, although he sold some for money, he would not possess the value that had been given him for them, but gave it to other persons.
tgt_text.4768: In the same year, Annibal again circumvented two consuls, Marcellus and Crispinus, and slew them.
tgt_text.4769: When Claudius Nero and Marcus Livius Salinator were consuls, Asdrubal, Annibal's brother, marched with an army from Spain to Italy, to the aid of Annibal.
tgt_text.4770: Then the consuls were apprized of that before Annibal, and came against him when he had crossed the mountains, and there they had a long battle ere either of the armies fled.
tgt_text.4771: It was chiefly in conse­ quence of his having elephants with him that Asdrubal was so slow to flee;
tgt_text.4772: and the Romans had the victory.
tgt_text.4773: There was Asdrubal slain, and fifty-three thousand of his army, and five thousand captured.
tgt_text.4774: The consuls then commanded Asdrubal's head to be cut off and cast before Annibal's camp.
tgt_text.4775: When it was known to Annibal that his brother was slain, and so many of the people with him, then he first felt fear of the Romans, and marched into the land of the Bruttii.
tgt_text.4776: There­ upon Annibal and the Romans had a year of stillness between them, because of both armies vast numbers died of fever.
tgt_text.4777: During that stillness, Scipio conquered all Spain, and after­ wards came to Rome, and counselled the Romans to proceed with ships to Annibal's land.
tgt_text.4778: Thereupon the Romans sent him, that he might be the commander of the expedition;
tgt_text.4779: and as soon as he came to Carthage, Hanno, the king, came against him unawares, and was there slain.
tgt_text.4780: At that time Annibal fought against the consul Sempronius in Italy, and drove him into Rome.
tgt_text.4781: After that the Carthaginians pro. ceeded against Scipio with all their force, and pitched a camp in two places, near the city that is called Utica;
tgt_text.4782: in the one were the Carthaginians, in the other the Numidians, who were in aid of them, and had thought they should there have winter-quarters.
tgt_text.4783: But when Scipio learned that the foremost watches were stationed far from the fortress, and also that there were no others nearer, he secretly led his army be­ tween the watches, and sent a few men to one of their fast­ nesses, that they might set one end of it on fire, that then most of all those that were within would run towards the fire, for the purpose of quenching it.
tgt_text.4784: He then, Scipio, in the mean while, slew almost all of them.
tgt_text.4785: When the others, who were in the other fastness, discovered that, they went thitherward in flocks, to aid the others;
tgt_text.4786: and Scipio was all that night slaying them as they came, until day;
tgt_text.4787: and afterwards he slew those fleeing through the whole day;
tgt_text.4788: and their two kings, Asdrubal and Syphax, fled to the city of Carthage, and gathered the force that they had there, and came against Scipio, and were again driven into Carthage.
tgt_text.4789: Some fled to the isle of Cirta, and Scipio sent a fleet after them, so that some were slain, some taken;
tgt_text.4790: and Syphax was taken, one of their kings, and was afterwards sent in chains to Rome.
tgt_text.4791: In these wars, the Carthaginians were so reduced, that they afterwards esteemed themselves as naught against the Romans, and sent to Italy for Annibal, and prayed that he would come to their aid, and he granted their prayer weeping, because he must abandon Italy, in the thirteenth year after he had first come thither;
tgt_text.4792: and he slew all his men that were of those countries, who would not [cross] the sea with him.
tgt_text.4793: When he sailed homewards, he commanded a man to ascend the mastand look whether he knew the land towards which they were going.
tgt_text.4794: Then he said to him that he saw a ruined sepulchre, such as it was their custom to make above the earth of stones for rich men.
tgt_text.4795: Thereupon was to Annibal, according to their heathen custom, that answer extremely distasteful, and he ex­ pressed his dissatisfaction at the answer, and he commanded all the army with the ships to turn from the place to which he had resolved [to go], and arrived at the town of Leptis, and speedily proceeded to Carthage, and prayed that he might speak with Scipio, and desired that he might settle a peace between the [two] nations:
tgt_text.4796: but their private confer­ ence, which they had with each other, they brought to a hostile termination, and prepared themselves for battle;
tgt_text.4797: and soon after they had come together, Annibal's army was put to flight and twenty thousand slain, and five hundred and eighty elephants;
tgt_text.4798: and Annibal with three others fled to the fortress of Adrumetum.
tgt_text.4799: Thereupon the inhabitants of Car­ thage sent for Annibal, and said that it would be best for them to desire peace of the Romans.
tgt_text.4800: When Caius Cornelius and Publius Lentulus were consuls, peace was granted to the Carthaginians by Scipio, with the consent of the senate, on condition that the islands of Sicily and Sardinia should belong to the Romans, and that they should pay them every year as many talents of silver as they then conceded to them;
tgt_text.4801: and Scipio ordered five hundred of their ships to be drawn up and burnt, and then proceeded homeward to Rome.
tgt_text.4802: Then they brought the triumph to meet him, when therewith went Terentius, the great Carthaginian poet, and bare a hat on his head;
tgt_text.4803: because the Romans had newly decreed, that those who might bear a hat, when they had overcome such people, might have toth life and freedom.
tgt_text.4804: After Rome had been built five hundred and fifty years, the second war of the Carthaginians and Romans was ended, that they had been carrying on for fourteen years;
tgt_text.4805: but the Romans, immediately after, began another against the Ma­ cedonians.
tgt_text.4806: Then the consuls drew lots, which of them should first undertake that war.
tgt_text.4807: The lot then fell on Quinc­ tius Flamininus, who in that war fought many battles, and oftenest had the victory, until Philip, their king, sued for peace, and the Romans granted it to him ;
tgt_text.4808: and he after went to Lacedæmonia, and Quinctius Flamininus compelled both kings to give their sons as hostages.
tgt_text.4809: Philip, the Macedonian, king, gave his son Demetrius, and the Lacedæmonian king gave his son Armenes.
tgt_text.4810: And of all the Roman men that Annibal had sold into Greece, the consul commanded their heads to be shaved, in token that he released them from slavery.
tgt_text.4811: At that time the nations of the Insubres and Ce­ nomani assembled together, at the instigation of Amilcar, the brother of Annibal, whom he had before left behind him in Italy, and they afterwards proceeded against the lands of Placentia and Cremona, and totally laid them waste.
tgt_text.4812: Thereupon the Romans sent thither the consul Claudius Fulvius, and he with difficulty overcame them.
tgt_text.4813: After that the consul Flamininus fought against Philip, the king of Macedon, against the Thracians, and against the Illyrians, and against many other nations, in one battle, and put them all to flight.
tgt_text.4814: There were of the Macedonians eight thousand slain, and six thousand taken.
tgt_text.4815: After that the consul Sem­ pronius was slain in Spain with all his army.
tgt_text.4816: At that time the consul Marcellus was routed in the land of Etruria, when Furius, the other consul, came to his aid and had vic­ tory, and they afterwards laid waste all that land.
tgt_text.4817: When Lucius Valenus and Marcus Flaccus were consuls, Antiochus, the Syrian king, began to war against the Romans, and came from Asia into Europe with an army.
tgt_text.4818: At that time, the Romans commanded that Annibal, the Carthaginian king, should be seized and afterwards brought to Rome.
tgt_text.4819: When he heard that, he fled to Antiochus, the Syrian king, where he was in a state of doubt, whether he durst war against the Romans as he had begun.
tgt_text.4820: But Annibal induced him that he carried on the war longer.
tgt_text.4821: Thereupon the Romans sent Scipio Africanus, as their ambassador, to Antiochus, when he commanded Annibal to speak with the ambassadors, and answer them.
tgt_text.4822: When they obtained no peace, the consul Scipio came after that with Glabrio, another consul, and of the people of Antiochus slew forty thousand.
tgt_text.4823: In the fol­ lowing year, Scipio fought against Annibal out at sea, and had the victory.
tgt_text.4824: When Antiochus heard that, he prayed Scipio for peace, and sent his son home to him, who was in his power, as he knew not how he came to him, unless, as some men said, that he had been captured while plundering, or on his watch.
tgt_text.4825: In the further Spain, jEmilius, the consul, perished with all his army by the Lusitanian nation.
tgt_text.4826: In those days, the consul, Lucius Bæbius, perished with all his army, by the Etruscan nations, so that none was left to an­ nounce it at Rome.
tgt_text.4827: After that, the consul Fulvius pro­ ceeded with an army to Greece, to the mountains that are called Olympus, where many of that people had fled to a fastness.
tgt_text.4828: Then, in the fight, when they would capture the fastness, many of the Romans were shot with arrows and struck with stones.
tgt_text.4829: When the consul was sensible that they could not take the fastness, he commanded some of the army to depart from the fastness, and the others he ordered to flee towards the others, when the fight was hottest, that they might thereby entice out those that were there within.
tgt_text.4830: In the flight, when the inhabitants fled back towards the fast­ ness, forty thousand of them were slain, and those that were left surrendered to him.
tgt_text.4831: In those days, the consul Marcius went with an army to the land of Liguria, and was put to flight, and four thousand of his army were slain.
tgt_text.4832: When Marcus Claudius and Marcellus Quintus were consuls, Philip, king of Macedon, slew the Roman ambassadors, and sent his son, Demetrius, to the senate, that he might allay their anger:
tgt_text.4833: and, although he did so, when he came home Philip commanded his other son to kill him with poison, be­ cause he accused him of speaking disparagingly of him before the senate.
tgt_text.4834: At the same time, Annibal voluntarily killed himself by poison.
tgt_text.4835: At that same time, appeared the island of Vulcan, in Sicily, which had not been seen before then.
tgt_text.4836: At that time the consul, Quintus Fulvius, fought against the further Spaniards, and had victory.
tgt_text.4837: When Lepidus Mucius was consul, that most fierce nation called the Bas­ ternæ (but now called Hungarii) resolved to make war on the Romans.
tgt_text.4838: They wished to come to the aid of Perseus, the Macedonian king.
tgt_text.4839: At that time the river Danube was so greatly frozen over, that they trusted that they could pass over the ice, but almost all of them there perished.
tgt_text.4840: When P. Licinius Crassus and Caius Cassius were consuls, the Macedonian war took place, which may well be numbered among the greatest wars, because in those days all the Italianswere in aid of the Romans, and also Ptolemy, king of Egypt, and Ariarathes, king of Cappadocia, and Eumenes, king of Asia, and Massanissa, king of Numidia.
tgt_text.4841: And of Perseus, king of Macedon, there were in aid all the Thracians and Illyrians.
tgt_text.4842: And soon after they came together, the Romans were put to flight, and soon after, in a second battle, they were also put to flight;
tgt_text.4843: and after those battles, Perseus greatly harassed the Romans all that year, and afterwards marched into Illyria, and took their town of Sulcanum, which was subject to the Romans, and of the people some he slew, some led into Macedonia.
tgt_text.4844: After that, Lucius jEmilius, the consul, fought against Perseus and overcame him, and slew twenty thousand of his army, and he himself on that occasion fled, and soon afterwards was captured and brought to Rome, and there slain.
tgt_text.4845: And there were many wars in those days in many lands, which it is now too tedious to relate.
tgt_text.4846: After Rome had been built six hundred years, when Lu­ cius Licinius and Lucullus Aulus were consuls, the Romans were in the greatest fear of the Celtiberians, a Spanish peo­ ple, and had no man who durst proceed thither with an army, except the consul Scipio, who after that expedition was called Africanus, because he a second time went whither no other durst [go] ;
tgt_text.4847: although the Romans, a little while before, had decreed that he should go to Asia;
tgt_text.4848: but he fought many battles in Spain with divers victories.
tgt_text.4849: In those days, Servius Galba, a companion of Scipio, fought against the Lusitanians, a people of Spain, and was defeated.
tgt_text.4850: In those days, the Ro­ roan gods commanded the senate to build them a theatre for plays;
tgt_text.4851: but Scipio oftentimes enjoined them not to un­ dertake it, and also himself said, when he came from Spain, that it would be the greatest imprudence and the greatest error.
tgt_text.4852: The Romans then, through his chiding and his advice, contemned the gods;
tgt_text.4853: and all the money that they had thereto collected, with which they had intended to pay for the pillars and for the work, they paid for other things.
tgt_text.4854: Now may those Christians feel shame, who love and cultivate such idolatry;
tgt_text.4855: when he, who was not a Christian, so greatlydespised it, who should have furthered it according to their own custom.
tgt_text.4856: After that, Servius Galba went again to Lusi­ tania, and made peace with them, and during that peace cir­ cumvented them.
tgt_text.4857: That deed was almost of the greatest harm to the Romans, so that no people would trust them who was subject to them.
tgt_text.4858: After Rome had been built six hundred and two years, when Censorinus Marcus and Lucius Manilius were consuls, there happened the third war of the Romans and Cartha­ ginians :
tgt_text.4859: and the senate agreed among themselves, that, if they overcame them a third time, they would destroy all Carthage.
tgt_text.4860: And they again sent Scipio thither, and in their first battle he put them to flight and drove them into Car­ thage.
tgt_text.4861: After that, they sued the Romans for peace ;
tgt_text.4862: but Scipio would not grant it them on any other condition, except they would all give up their weapons, and abandon the city, and that no one should settle nearer than ten miles to it.
tgt_text.4863: After that was done, they said that they would rather perish together with the city, than that it should be destroyed with­ out them;
tgt_text.4864: and they again made themselves weapons, those that had iron;
tgt_text.4865: and those that had not, made them, some of silver, some of wood, and appointed the two Asdrubals for their kings.
tgt_text.4866: Now I will, says Orosius, relate how in circuit it was thirty miles about, and was all without surrounded with sea, except three miles;
tgt_text.4867: and the wall was twenty feet thick and forty ells high ;
tgt_text.4868: and within there was another less fastness, on the sea-shore, that was two miles high.
tgt_text.4869: The Carthaginians then, at that time, defended the city, although Scipio had before broken down much of the wall, and after­ wards returned homewards.
tgt_text.4870: When Cneus Cornelius and Lifcius Lentulus were consuls, Scipio proceeded a third time to Africa, because he intended to destroy Carthage;
tgt_text.4871: and when he came there he was six days fighting against the city, until the citizens prayed that they might be their thralls, as they could not defend them­ selves.
tgt_text.4872: Thereupon Scipio commanded all the women, of whom there were twenty-six thousand, and then the men, the number of whom was thirty thousand [to go out] ;
tgt_text.4873: andthe king Asdrubal, killed himself, and his wife with her two sons burned themselves, because of the king's death;
tgt_text.4874: and Scipio commanded all the city to be destroyed, and every hewn stone to be beaten to pieces, that they might not after­ wards [serve] for any wall.
tgt_text.4875: And the city within was burning for sixteen days, about seven hundred years from the time when it was first built.
tgt_text.4876: Then was the third war of the Car­ thaginians and Romans ended, in the fourth year from the time when it was first begun ;
tgt_text.4877: although the Romans had pre­ viously a long consultation, as to whether it were more advi­ sable totally to destroy the city, that they might ever after have peace on that side, or they should leave it standing, that war might afterwards be raised up from thence;
tgt_text.4878: because they dreaded, if they had not sometimes war, that they would too quickly become slothful and spiritless.
tgt_text.4879: So that it is now manifest to you, Romans, that since Christianity was, says Orosius, that ye have lost the whetstone of your forefathers, of your wars and your energy;
tgt_text.4880: because ye are now fat with­ out and lean within;
tgt_text.4881: but your forefathers were lean without and fat within, of strong and firm mind.
tgt_text.4882: I also know not, says he, how useful I may be while I am speaking these words, or whether I may lose my labour.
tgt_text.4883: It is also de­ sirable for a man to rub hardly the softest metal, if he intends the most excellent whetstone to work upon it.
tgt_text.4884: So then it is to me now very difficult to whet their mood, now when it will be neither sharp nor hard.
tgt_text.4885: I KNOW, says Orosius, what the Roman vaunt chiefly is ;
tgt_text.4886: [it is] because they have overcome many nations and have often­ times driven many kings before their triumphs.
tgt_text.4887: Those are the blessed times that they are always boasting of, as if they now said, that those times were given to them alone, and not to all people ;
tgt_text.4888: but, if they could well understand it, they were common to all nations.
tgt_text.4889: But if they say that those times were good, because they made one city prosperous, then more justly may they say, that they were the most unhappy, be­ cause through the pride of that one city, all the others werereduced to indigence.
tgt_text.4890: But if they do not believe this, let them ask the Italians, their own countrymen, how they liked those times, when they were slain, and oppressed, and sold into other lands for a hundred and twenty years ?
tgt_text.4891: But if they do not believe them, let them ask the Spaniards, who were suffering the same for two hundred years, and many other nations.
tgt_text.4892: And also the many kings, how they liked it, when in yokes and in chains they were driven in pride before their triumphs towards Rome, and afterwards lay in prisons until they perished by death?
tgt_text.4893: And many kings they afflicted, that they might give them all that they had for their miserable life.
tgt_text.4894: But therefore it is unknown to us and incredible, because we are born in that peace that they could hardly buy with their lives.
tgt_text.4895: It was after Christ was born that we were redeemed from every thraldom and from every fear, if we will fulfil his precepts.
tgt_text.4896: After Rome had been built six hundred and six years, that was in the same year in which Carthage was destroyed:
tgt_text.4897: after its fall, Cneus Cornelius and Lucius Lentulus destroyed Corinth, the chief city of all the Greeks.
tgt_text.4898: In its burning, all the statues that were in it, were melted together, of gold, of silver, brazen, or of copper, and sunk into pits.
tgt_text.4899: Yet to this day we call Corinthian vessels all that were made thereof;
tgt_text.4900: for they are fairer and dearer than any others.
tgt_text.4901: In those days there was a shepherd in Spain, who was named Viriathus, and was a great thief, and in his stealing he became a robber, and in his robberies drew to him a large force of men, and plundered many towns.
tgt_text.4902: After that his gang increased so much that he ravaged many lands, and the Romans were in great dread of him, and sent the consul Ve­ tilius against him with an army, and he was there put to flight, and the greatest part of his people slain.
tgt_text.4903: At the second time, Caius Plautius the consul proceeded thither, and was also put to flight.
tgt_text.4904: At the third time, the consul Claudius proceeded thither, and thought that he would re­ pair the Roman disgrace;
tgt_text.4905: but he in that expedition rather increased it, and escaped himself with difficulty.
tgt_text.4906: After that Viriathus, with three hundred men, met with a thousand Romans in a wood, where of Viriathus' people seventy were slain, and of the Romans three hundred, and the others were put to flight.
tgt_text.4907: In the flight there was a soldier of Viriathus following at too great a distance from the others, until his horse was slain under him, when all the others [Romans] would slay or bind him, a single man.
tgt_text.4908: Thereupon he slew a man's horse with his sword, so that its head flew off, where­ upon the others were in such great fear of him that they durst not encounter him.
tgt_text.4909: After that, the consul, Appius Claudius, fought against the Gauls, and was put to flight, and soon after again led an army against them, and had the victory, and slew six thousand of them.
tgt_text.4910: When on his return home, he begged that the triumph might be brought to meet him;
tgt_text.4911: but the Romans positively refused it, and excused it under the [plea] that he previously, on the other occasion, had not the victory.
tgt_text.4912: After that there was so great a pesti­ lence at Rome that no stranger durst come thither, and many lands within the city were without any inheritor.
tgt_text.4913: They knew, however, that the same evil would pass away without sacrifice, as the many others had done, that they imagined they had repressed by their idolatries.
tgt_text.4914: Without doubt, if they could then have sacrificed, they would have said that their gods had helped them.
tgt_text.4915: But it was God's grace that they all lay [sick] who should have done it, until it passed over of itself.
tgt_text.4916: After that, Fabius, the consul, marched with an army against Viriathus, and was put to flight.
tgt_text.4917: The con­ sul did a most disgraceful deed for all the Romans, when he enticed to him from Scythia six hundred men of his associates, and when they came to him, commanded the hands of them all to be cut off.
tgt_text.4918: After that the consul Pompeius proceeded against the Numantines, a nation of Spain, and was put to flight.
tgt_text.4919: About fourteen years from the time when Viriathus began to [ make war] against the Romans, he was slain by his own men;
tgt_text.4920: and as often as the Romans had sought him with battle, he always put them to flight.
tgt_text.4921: There, however, the Romans showed a little regard to faith, and that those were hateful to them and unworthy who betrayed their lord, although they at that time expected rewards.
tgt_text.4922: I shall also from necessity pass in silence the many wars which took place in the east lands.
tgt_text.4923: I shall grow weary of these Romanwars.
tgt_text.4924: At that time, Mithridates, king of the Parthians,­ conquered Babylonia and all the lands that were between the two rivers, the Indus and the Hydaspes, which had previously been under the Roman power:
tgt_text.4925: and afterwards he extended his dominion east as far as the confines of India;
tgt_text.4926: and De­ metrius, the king of Asia, sought him twice with an army.
tgt_text.4927: At one time he was put to flight, at the other captured.
tgt_text.4928: He was under the Roman power, because they had established him there.
tgt_text.4929: After that, Mancinus, the consul, proceeded against the Numantines, a people of Spain, and was there warring until he made peace with that people, and afterwards stole himself away.
tgt_text.4930: When he came home, the Romans ordered him to be bound and brought before the gate of the fortress of Numantia.
tgt_text.4931: Then, neither those who had led him thither durst lead him back, nor would those receive him to whom he was brought;
tgt_text.4932: but very cruelly, thus bound, he con­ tinued, in one place, before the gate, until he gave up his life.
tgt_text.4933: In those days, the consul Brutus slew of the Spanish nation sixty thousand, who had been aiding the Lusitanians;
tgt_text.4934: and immediately after, he again proceeded against the Lusi­ tanians and slew fifty thousand of them, and captured six thousand.
tgt_text.4935: In those days, the consul Lepidus proceeded to the hither Spain, and was put to flight, and of his army six thousand were slain, and those who came away, fled with the greatest disgrace.
tgt_text.4936: Can the Romans reproach any man for saying how many of their people perished in a few years in Spain, when they boast of happy times, while those were to themselves the most unhappy ?
tgt_text.4937: When Servius Fulvius and Quintus Flaccus were consuls, a child was born at Rome that had four feet, and four hands, and four eyes, and four ears.
tgt_text.4938: In that year fire sprang up from Etna, in Sicily, and burned more of that land than it had ever done before.
tgt_text.4939: After Rome had been built six hundred and twenty years, when Mancinus made the evil peace in Numantia, as the Romans themselves said, that, during their dominion, no more disgraceful deed had taken place, except at the battle of Calldinæ Furculæ ;
tgt_text.4940: the Romans sent Scipio against the Numantines with an army.
tgt_text.4941: They are in the north-west end of Spain, and had previously defended themselves with four thousand [men], for fourteen years, against forty thousand Romans, and oftenest had victory.
tgt_text.4942: Scipio then besieged them a half year in their fastness, and reduced them to such straits, that they preferred devoting themselves, to longer enduring those miseries.
tgt_text.4943: When Scipio was aware that they were of such a mind, he commanded some of his army to fight against the fastness, that they thereby might entice the people out.
tgt_text.4944: The inhabitants [were] much rejoiced and much elated at being enabled to fight, and amid their joy over­ drenched themselves with ale, and ran out at two gates.
tgt_text.4945: In that city ale-works were first begun, because they had no wine.
tgt_text.4946: By that device the flower of Numantia fell, and the part that was left burned the entire city, because they would not allow their enemies to succeed to their ancient treasures;
tgt_text.4947: and after that they destroyed themselves in the fire.
tgt_text.4948: When Scipio was returning homeward from that land, there came to him an old man, who was a Numantine.
tgt_text.4949: Then Scipio asked him, what the cause was that the Nu­ mantines had so rapidly become so enervated, so bold as they had long been.
tgt_text.4950: He thereupon said to him, that they were bold as long as they preserved unanimity and simplicity among themselves;
tgt_text.4951: but as soon as they raised up discord among themselves, they all perished.
tgt_text.4952: To Scipio that answer appeared of serious import, and to all the Roman senators;
tgt_text.4953: by that answer, and by those words, they were greatly terri­ fied when he came home;
tgt_text.4954: because they then had discord among themselves.
tgt_text.4955: At that time one of their consuls was named Gracchus, and he began to war against all the others, until they slew him.
tgt_text.4956: And also at that time in Sicily the slaves made war on their lords, and were with difficulty overcome, and seven thousand slain before they could be reduced.
tgt_text.4957: And at the single town of Minturnæ four hundred and fifty were cru­ cified.
tgt_text.4958: After Rome had been built six hundred and twenty-one years, the consul, Licinius Crassus, who was also the chief priest of the Romans, proceeded with an army against Aris­ tonicus, the king, who would appropriate to himself the Lesser Asia, although Attains, his own brother, had pre­ viously given it to the Romans by his will.
tgt_text.4959: To the aid of Crassus there came many kings from many lands:
tgt_text.4960: one was from Nicomedia, two from Bithynia, three from Pontus, four from Armenia, five from Argeata, six from Cappadocia, seven from Pylemene, eight from Paphlagonia;
tgt_text.4961: and yet, soon after they came together, the consul was put to flight, although he had a great force.
tgt_text.4962: When Perperna, the other consul, heard that, he hastily gathered an army, and came on the king, unawares, when his army was all dispersed, and drove him into a fortress, and besieged him until all the inhabitants delivered him to the consul, and he afterwards ordered him to be brought to Rome and cast into prison, and he there lay until he gave up his life.
tgt_text.4963: At that time it appeared to Antiochus, king of Assyria, that he had not realm enough, and was desirous of acquiring Parthia, and proceeded thither with many thousands, and there the Parthians easily over­ came him, and slew the king, and appropriated to themselves the kingdom;
tgt_text.4964: because Antiochus recked not what number of men he had, and took no heed of what sort they were, there were therefore more dissolute than decent among them.
tgt_text.4965: At that time, Scipio, the best and the most excellent of Roman senators and officers, bewailed his hardships to the Roman senators, when they were at their meeting, [demanding] why they treated him so unworthily in his age;
tgt_text.4966: and asked them, why they would not remember all the miseries and the toils that he had undergone for their sake, and also from necessity, for many years and at countless times, and how he had saved them from Annibal's thraldom, and of many another nation ;
tgt_text.4967: and how he had reduced to their servitude all Spain and all Africa.
tgt_text.4968: And then, on that same night, after the day on which he had spoken, the Romans thanked him for all his toil with a worse reward than he had earned from them, when they smothered and suffocated him in his bed,so that he lost his life.
tgt_text.4970: who can now trust you, when you so rewarded your most faithful senator?
tgt_text.4971: When AEmilius and Orestes were consuls, the fire of Etna flowed up so broad and so much, that few of the inhabitants of the island of Lipari could remain in their dwellings, who' were there that night, on account of the heat and of the stench.
tgt_text.4972: Yea, all the cliffs, that were near the sea, were burnt to ashes, and all the ships were consumed, although they were sailing on the sea.
tgt_text.4973: Yea, all the fishes, that were in the sea, perished from the heat.
tgt_text.4974: When Marcus Flaccus was consul, locusts came into Africa, and every morning cropped off whatever was waxing and growing on the land.
tgt_text.4975: After they were drowned, the sea cast them up, and afterwards almost everything perished that was on the land, both men and cattle, and also the wild animals, by reason of the stench.
tgt_text.4976: After the city of Rome had been built six hundred and twenty-four years, when Lucius Metellus and Quintus Flamininus were consuls, the senate decreed, that Carthage should be rebuilt.
tgt_text.4977: But on the same night of the day on which they had marked the city out with stakes, so as they wished to construct it, the wolves pulled up the stakes;
tgt_text.4978: then, because of that, they abandoned the work, and had a long consultation, whether it betokened peace or war;
tgt_text.4980: At that time, Metellus the consul proceeded to the Balearic islands, and overcame the pirates who plundered in those islands, although many of the inhabitants perished.
tgt_text.4981: After the city of Rome had been built six hundred and twenty-seven'years, the consul Fabius met Bituitus, king of Gaul, and, with a small force, overcame him.
tgt_text.4982: After the city of Rome had been built six hundred and thirty-five years, when Scipio Nasica and Lucius Calpurnius were consuls, the Romans warred against Jugurtha, king of Numidia.
tgt_text.4983: The same Jugurtha was the son of Micipsa, king of Numidia, and he adopted him in his youth, and ordered him to be fed and taught with his two sons:
tgt_text.4984: and when the king died, he commanded his two sons to give a third part of his realm to Jugurtha.
tgt_text.4985: But when the third part was in his power, he deceived both the sons, one he slew, the other he drove away, and he afterwards applied to the Romans for protection;
tgt_text.4986: and they sent the consul Calpurnius with him with an army.
tgt_text.4987: But Jugurtha with his money bribed the consul, so that he performed but little of warfare.
tgt_text.4988: After that, Jugurtha came to Rome, and secretly bribed the senators, one by one, so that they were all vacillating about him.
tgt_text.4989: When he returned homewards from the city, he re­ proached the Romans, and insulted them wtth his words, and said, that no city could be bought more easily with money, if any one were inclined to buy it.
tgt_text.4990: In the following year, the Romans sent Aulus Postumius, the consul, with sixty thousand [men] against Jugurtha.
tgt_text.4991: Their meeting was at the city of Calama, and there the Romans were overcome, and a little while after, they made peace between them;
tgt_text.4992: and afterwards, almost all Africa turned to Jugurtha.
tgt_text.4993: After that, the Ro­ mans again sent Metellus with an army against Jugurtha, and he had victory on two occasions, and, on the third occa­ sion, he drove Jugurtha into Numidia, his own land, and compelled him to give the Romans three hundred hostages ;
tgt_text.4994: and he yet afterwards made depredations on the Romans.
tgt_text.4995: They then after that sent the consul Marius against Ju­ gurtha, [one] ever as crafty and cunning as he was;
tgt_text.4996: and [he] proceeded to a city exactly as if he intended to besiege it.
tgt_text.4997: But as soon as Jugurtha had led his force to that city against Marius, he, Marius, then abandoned that fortress, and marched to another, where he had learned that Jugurtha's treasure was, and compelled the inhabitants to surrender to him;
tgt_text.4998: and they gave up to him all the treasure that was therein.
tgt_text.4999: Jugurtha then did not trust his own people afterthat, but associated himself with Bocchus, king of Mauri­ tania, and he came to him with a large aid of men, and fre­ quently stole on the Romans, until a general battle was re­ solved on between them.
tgt_text.5000: For that battle Bocchus had brought to the aid of Jugurtha sixty thousand horse besides foot.
tgt_text.5001: With the Romans there was not, neither before nor since, so hard a fight as there was, because they were sur­ rounded on every side, and also the most of them perished, because their meeting was on a sandy down, so that for dust they could not see how they should defend themselves;
tgt_text.5002: be­ sides which they were annoyed both by thirst and heat, and all that day they were enduring that until night.
tgt_text.5003: In the morning they were doing the same, and were again sur­ rounded on every side, as they had been before:
tgt_text.5004: and when they were most doubting whether they could escape, they resolved that some should protect their rear, and some, if they might, fight [their way] out through all the cohorts.
tgt_text.5005: When they had so done, there came a rain, and so violently, that the Mauritanians were wearied by it, because their shields were covered with the hides of elephants, so that few of them could raise them, in consequence of the wet, and were, therefore, put to flight;
tgt_text.5006: because an elephant's hide will drink water as a sponge does.
tgt_text.5007: Of the Mauritanians there were slain forty thousand one hundred men.
tgt_text.5008: After that, Bocchus made peace with the Romans, and delivered Jugurtha to them bound, and he was afterwards cast into prison and his two sons, until they there all perished.
tgt_text.5009: After Rome had been built six hundred and forty-two years, when Manlius and Quintus were consuls, the Romans fought against the Cimbri, and against the Teutones, and against the Ambrones (these nations were in Gaul), and all were there slain, except ten men, that was forty thousand1;
tgt_text.5010: and of the Romans were there slain eighty thousand, and their consul and his two sons.
tgt_text.5011: After that, these same nations besieged the consul Marius in a fortress, and it was a long time before he would go out to battle, until it was told him that they would go into Italy, the land of the Romans.
tgt_text.5012: Butafter he went towards them out of the fortress, he met them on a down, when the consul's men complained to him of their thirst, which was oppressive to them;
tgt_text.5013: whereupon he an­ swered them and said:
tgt_text.5014: “ We can easily see, on the other side of our enemies, where the drink is to be had that is nearest to us;
tgt_text.5015: but because they are nearer to us, we cannot come to it without fighting."
tgt_text.5016: The Romans there had victory, and of the Galli there were slain two hundred thousand and their leader, and eighty thousand taken.
tgt_text.5017: After the city of Rome had been built six hundred and forty-five years, in the fifth year that Marius was consul, and also when there was peace with the Romans from other nations, then the Romans began to raise the greatest strife among themselves;
tgt_text.5018: though I shall [but] shortly now say, says Orosius, who its authors were.
tgt_text.5019: That was, in the first place, the consul Marius, and Lucius, and Apuleius, and Saturninus, because these drove the consul Metellus into exile, who was consul before Marius.
tgt_text.5020: The other consuls then, Pompey and Cato taking this extremely ill, although they could stand the exile, with regard to his banishment, in no stead, nevertheless, succeeded in slaying Lucius and Satur­ ninus, and afterward requested that Metellus might [return] to Rome;
tgt_text.5021: but Marius and Furius still forbade it;
tgt_text.5022: and the enmity between them was afterwards increased;
tgt_text.5023: although they durst not openly manifest it for fear of the senate.
tgt_text.5024: After the city of Rome had been built six hundred and sixty-one years, in the sixth year that Julius Cæsar was consul, and Lucius Martius, there was over all Italy unna­ tural and open hostility between Julius and Pompey;
tgt_text.5025: al­ though they had previously completely concealed it between themselves.
tgt_text.5026: And also in that year many wonders happened in many lands.
tgt_text.5027: One was, that people saw as if a fiery ring came from the north, with a great sound.
tgt_text.5028: The second was in the city of Aretium, at a feast, when the loaves werescored for eating, there ran blood out.
tgt_text.5029: The third was, that it hailed day and night over all the Roman [territory], and in the Samnites' land the earth burst asunder, and thence fire burnt up to the heavens, and there was seen as it were a golden ring in the heavens, broader than the sun, and ex­ tending itself from the heavens down to the earth, and after­ wards returned towards the heavens.
tgt_text.5030: At that time, the nation of the Picentes, and the Vestini, and the Marsi, and the Peligni, and the Marrucini, and the Samnites, and the Lucani, all agreed together that they would revolt from the Romans, and slew Caius Servilius, the Roman prætor, who had been sent to them with messages.
tgt_text.5031: In those days, the cattle became mad, and the dogs that were with the Sam­ nites.
tgt_text.5032: After that, the consul Pompey fought against those nations and was put to flight;
tgt_text.5033: and Julius Cæsar fought against the nation of the Marsi, and was put to flight;
tgt_text.5034: and shortly after Julius fought against the Samnites and against the Lucani and put them to flight.
tgt_text.5035: After that they named him Cœsar.
tgt_text.5036: He then demanded that the triumph should be brought to meet him, when they sent him a black mantle, as an insult, instead of a triumph;
tgt_text.5037: and afterwards they sent him a toga, which they had promised, so that he did not come to Rome altogether without honour.
