tgt_text.5038: After that, Sylla, the consul, the companion of Pompey, fought against the people of Æsernia, and put them to flight.
tgt_text.5039: After that, Pompey fought against the nation of the Picentes, and put them to flight.
tgt_text.5040: The Romans then brought the triumph to meet Pompey, with great honour, for that little victory that he had had, and would not do any honour to Julius, although he had done a greater deed, except a toga, and therewith greatly confirmed their [mutual] hostility.
tgt_text.5041: After that, Julius and Pompey took the town of Asculum from the Marsi, and there slew eighteen thousand.
tgt_text.5042: After that, the consul Sylla fought against the Samnites, and slew eighteen thousand of them.
tgt_text.5043: After the city of Rome had been built six hundred and sixty-two years, the Romans sent the consul Sylla against Mithridates, king of the Parthians.
tgt_text.5044: Then Marius the consul, the uncle of Julius, took it ill that they would not commit that war to him, and demanded that a seventh con­ sulate should be given to him, and also that war;
tgt_text.5045: because it was a custom with them, that after a twelvemonth they raised the seat of every consul higher by a cushion than it was before.
tgt_text.5046: When Sylla was informed with what design Marius had come to Rome, he instantly marched towards Rome with all his army, and drove Manus into the city of Rome with all his people ;
tgt_text.5047: and the citizens afterwards seized and bound him, and afterwards resolved on delivering him to Sylla.
tgt_text.5048: But he fled in that same night from the bonds with which they had bound him in the day;
tgt_text.5049: and afterwards fled south over the sea to Africa, where his greatest support was;
tgt_text.5050: and quickly again turned towards Rome.
tgt_text.5051: Two of the consuls were his supporters, Cinna and Sertorius, who were ever authors of every evil.
tgt_text.5052: And immediately after the senate heard that Marius was approaching Rome, they all fled out to the land of Greece, after Sylla and after Pompey, whither they had then proceeded with an army.
tgt_text.5053: Thereupon Sylla with great diligence proceeded from Greece towards Rome, and fought obstinate battles against Marius, and put him to flight, and slew within the city of Rome all who had been in aid of Marius.
tgt_text.5054: Immediately after, all the consuls died save two.
tgt_text.5055: Marius and Sylla died voluntarily, and Cinna was slain at Smyrna, a city of Asia;
tgt_text.5056: and Sertorius was slain in Spain.
tgt_text.5057: Pompey then undertook the Parthian war, because Mithri­ dates, their king, had taken to himself the Lesser Asia, and all the land of the Greeks;
tgt_text.5058: but Pompey made him flee from all that land, and drove him into Armenia, and pursued him, until other men slew him ;
tgt_text.5059: and he compelled Archelaus, the general, to be his underling.
tgt_text.5060: It is now incredible to say, says Orosius, how many perished in that war, which they endured for forty years, before it could be ended, as well through the devastation of nations, the slaughters of kings, and hunger.
tgt_text.5061: When Pompey was [on his way] homewards, those nations would not deliver up the fortress at Jerusalem.
tgt_text.5062: They were supported by twenty-two kings.
tgt_text.5063: Then Pompey commanded the fortress to be taken, and fought against it by day, andby night, one after another, unwearied pressed it, and thereby so harassed the people, that they surrendered to « him three months after they had first invested it.
tgt_text.5064: There were thirteen thousand Jews slain, and the walls were cast down to the ground ;
tgt_text.5065: and Aristobulus was led bound to Rome, who was both their king and their priest.
tgt_text.5066: After Rome had been built six hundred and sixty-seven years, the Romans gave Caius Julius seven legions, that he might war five years in Gaul.
tgt_text.5067: After he had overcome them, he proceeded to the island of Britain, and fought against the Britons, and was put to flight in the land that is called Kentland.
tgt_text.5068: Soon after, he again fought against the Britons in Kentland, and they were put to flight.
tgt_text.5069: Their third battle was near the river that is called Thames, near the ford that is called Wallingford.
tgt_text.5070: After that battle, the king surrendered to him, and the inhabitants that were in " Cyrnceaster,” and afterwards all who were in the island.
tgt_text.5071: After that, Julius went to Rome, and demanded the triumph to be brought to meet him;
tgt_text.5072: whereupon they commanded him that he should come to Rome with few men, and leave the whole of his force behind him.
tgt_text.5073: But as he was proceeding homewards, there came to meet him the three senators who were his supporters, and said to him, that they, on his ac­ count, had been driven away;
tgt_text.5074: and also, that all the legions, that were in the power of the Romans, had been given to aid Pompey, that he might have the securer contest with him.
tgt_text.5075: Julius thereupon returned to his own army, and, weeping, complained of the dishonour that had been so undeservedly done him, and chiefly [on account] of those men who had perished for his sake:
tgt_text.5076: and he afterwards enticed to him the seven legions that were in the land of Sulmo.
tgt_text.5077: When Pompey, and Cato, and all the senators heard that, they went to the Greeks, and gathered a large force in the mountain of Thrace.
tgt_text.5078: Then Julius marched to Rome, and broke open their treasury, and divided all that was therein.
tgt_text.5079: It is incredible to say, says Orosius, how much there was of it all.
tgt_text.5080: After that he proceeded to the land of Marseilles, and there left three legions behind him, that he might reduce that people to subjection, and he himself, with the other part, proceeded to Spain, where Pompey's legions were with his three generals, and he subjected them all to him.
tgt_text.5081: After that he proceeded to Greece, where Pompey awaited him on a mountain, with thirty kings besides his own force.
tgt_text.5082: Pompey then marched to where Marcellus, Julius' general, was, and slew him with all his army.
tgt_text.5083: After that, Julius besieged Torquatus, Pompey's general, in a fortress, and Pompey pro­ ceeded after him:
tgt_text.5084: there was Julius put to flight, and many of his people slain, because they fought on both sides of him, on one side Pompey, on the other the general.
tgt_text.5085: Julius then marched into Thessaly, and there gathered his force.
tgt_text.5086: When Pompey heard that, he marched after him with an immense force:
tgt_text.5087: he had eighty cohorts, which we now call truman, which in those days were of a thousand five hundred men:
tgt_text.5088: all this he had besides his own force, and besides [that of]
tgt_text.5089: Cato, his associate, and besides that of the senate.
tgt_text.5091: Each of them had his force in three bodies, and they themselves were in the middlemost, and the others on the two sides of them.
tgt_text.5092: When Julius had put one of the bodies to flight, Pompey called to him about the old Roman compact, although he himself did not think of observing it:
tgt_text.5093: " Comrade, comrade, remember that thou do not too long infringe our old fellowship and covenant."
tgt_text.5094: Thereupon he answered him, and said:
tgt_text.5095: “ At one time thou wast my comrade, and because thou art not [so] now, that is most desirable to me that is most hateful to thee."
tgt_text.5096: This was the compact that the Romans had established, that none of them should strike another in the face, wherever they met in battles.
tgt_text.5097: After those words, Pompey was put to flight with all his army;
tgt_text.5098: and he himself afterwards fled into Asia with his wife and his children, and afterwards he went to Egypt, and asked aid of Ptolemy the king.
tgt_text.5099: And soon after he came to him, he commanded his head to be cut off, and afterwards sent to Julius, and his ring with it.
tgt_text.5100: But when it was brought to him, he bewailed the deed with much weep­ ing ;
tgt_text.5101: because he was of all men the most compassionate in those days.
tgt_text.5102: After that, Ptolemy led an army against Julius, and all his people were put to flight, and -he himself cap-hired;
tgt_text.5103: and Julius commanded all the men to be slain who were of the counsel for slaying Pompey;
tgt_text.5104: and he, neverthe­ less, dismissed Ptolemy again to his kingdom.
tgt_text.5105: After that Julius fought thrice against Ptolemy, and at every time had victory.
tgt_text.5106: After that war, all the Egyptians were subdued by Julius;
tgt_text.5107: and he afterwards returned to Rome, and re-established the senate, and appointed himself to be higher than consul, what they called a dictator.
tgt_text.5108: After that he proceeded to Africa after the consul Cato.
tgt_text.5109: When he [Cato] heard that, he ad­ vised his son to go to meet him, and sue to him for peace:
tgt_text.5110: " Because," said he, " I know that so good a man as he is lives not in this life, although to me he is the most hostile, and therefore I cannot prevail on myself ever to see him.
tgt_text.5111: "After that speech, he went to the city walls, and flew out over them, so that he was all burst to pieces.
tgt_text.5112: But when Julius came to the city, he greatly grieved that he had not come to him alive, and that he had died by such a death.
tgt_text.5113: After that, Julius fought against the nephews of Pompey, and against many of his kin, and he slew them all, and afterwards pro­ ceeded to Rome, and was there in such veneration, that they granted him the triumph four times after he came home.
tgt_text.5114: Afterwards he proceeded to Spain and fought against Pom­ pey's he two sons, and there his army was so slaughtered, that he for some time thought he should be captured, and, by reason of that dread, he the more pressed into the [hostile] army, because it was to him more desirable to be slain than bound.
tgt_text.5115: After that he came to Rome, and all the laws there that were too severe and too hard, he made lighter and milder.
tgt_text.5116: All the senate then and the two consuls taking it ill that he would destroy their old laws, all rushed upon him, and stabbed him with their daggers in their senate-house.
tgt_text.5118: After Rome had been built seven hundred and sixty years, Octavianus succeeded to the dominion of the Romans, with­ out their concurrence, after the slaying of Julius his kins­ man;
tgt_text.5119: because Julius had previously confirmed to him by writings, that he after him should succeed to all his acquisi­ tions ;
tgt_text.5120: because he had, on account of kinship, instructed and - educated him.
tgt_text.5121: And he afterwards most royally fought in and carried on four wars, as Julius, his kinsman, had done before;
tgt_text.5122: one against Pompey, the second against the consul Anthony, the third against Cassius, the fourth against Lepidus, though he quickly after became his friend ;
tgt_text.5123: and he also acted so that Anthony became his friend, so that he gave his daughter to Octavianus to wife, and also that Octavianus gave his sister to Anthony.
tgt_text.5124: aAfterwards Anthony reduced all Asia under his power.
tgt_text.5125: After that he forsook the sister of Octavianus, and declared war and open hostility against himself;
tgt_text.5126: and he commanded the queen Cleopatra to be fetched to him for a wife, whom Julius had previously had, and on that account had given to her all Egypt.
tgt_text.5127: Immediately after, Octavianus led an army against Anthony;
tgt_text.5128: and speedily put him to flight after they had come together.
tgt_text.5129: After this, they fought for three days out at sea.
tgt_text.5130: Octavianus had thirty ships and two hundred of the large triremes, on board of which were faring eight legions, and Anthony had eighty ships, on board of which were faring ten legions;
tgt_text.5131: because by so many as he had fewer, by so much were they better and larger;
tgt_text.5132: for they were so constructed that they could not be overloaded with men, being ten feet high above the watery
tgt_text.5133: The battle was very great, though Octavianus had victory.
tgt_text.5134: Of Anthony's people there were slain twelve thousand, and Cleopatra, his queen, was put to flight when they engaged with her army.
tgt_text.5135: After that, Octavianus fought against Anthony and against Cleo­ patra, and put them to flight:
tgt_text.5136: it was at that time the first of August, on the day that we call Lammas.
tgt_text.5137: Octavianus was afterwards called Augustus, because he at that time had victory.
tgt_text.5138: After that, Anthony and Cleopatra collected a naval force on the Red Sea;
tgt_text.5139: but when it was told them that Octavianus was [coming] thitherward, all their people turned to Octavianus, and they themselves fled to a little army.
tgt_text.5140: Cleopatra then ordered her sepulchre to be dug, and entered into it.
tgt_text.5141: When she was laid in it, she then commanded an adder to be taken up and applied to her arm, that it might bite her;
tgt_text.5142: because it is the nature of the adder, that everycreature that it bites will end its life in sleep.
tgt_text.5143: And she did so because she would not be driven before a triumph towards Rome.
tgt_text.5144: When Anthony saw that she was preparing herself for death, he stabbed himself, and commanded, thus half dead, to be laid in the same sepulchre.
tgt_text.5145: When Octavianus came thither, he commanded another kind of adder to be taken, called psyllus, which can draw every kind of poison out of a man, if it be applied in time.
tgt_text.5146: But she had expired before he came thither.
tgt_text.5147: After that, Octavianus got Alexandria, the chief city of Egypt, and with its treasures greatly enriched Rome, so that every commodity might be bought better by twofold than it could previously.
tgt_text.5148: After Rome had been built seven hundred and thirty-five years, it came to pass that Octavianus Cæsar, in his fifth consulship, closed the doors of Janus;
tgt_text.5149: and it betel that he had dominion of all the earth.
tgt_text.5150: That was manifestly betokened when he was a boy, and was brought to Rome after the slay­ ing of Julius.
tgt_text.5151: On the same day on which he was appointed consul, it happened that there was seen about the sun as it were a golden ring, and within the city of Rome, a spring, for a whole day, welled forth oil.
tgt_text.5152: By the ring was betokened that in his days there should be born he who is lighter and brighter than the sun then was;
tgt_text.5153: and the oil betokened mercy to all mankind.
tgt_text.5154: So he [Octavianus] also himself made many a sign, which afterwards came to pass, though he un­ wittingly did them, by God's incitement.
tgt_text.5155: One was, first, that he commanded, over all the earth, that every nation, after the course of a year, should come together, that every man might know the more readily where he had peace.
tgt_text.5156: That betokened, that in his days should be born he who has invited us all to one kindred meeting, which will be in the life to come.
